questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding the Employees State Insurance (ESI) act.

choices.text: The state government provides 1/8th of the medical care expenses
Medical benefit is given in the form of no cash benefit
The maximum amount given under funeral benefit is Rs 15,000

questions.solution:
The employee contributes 0.75% of the wage according to the ESI Act. Hence, option A is false. 

The Employees State Insurance (ESI) Act of 1948 (revised in 2022) is essential to our country's social security and health insurance. It provides several benefits to insured persons, such as medical, sickness, and maternity benefits.

The ESI scheme is run by contributions from employees, employers, and grants from central and state governments.

These contributions include the following:

  • Wage bills:
    • Employer contributes 3.25% of the total wage bills
    • Employee contributes 0.75% of the wages
  • Medical bills:
    • State government provides 1/8th of the total medical expenses (option B)
    • ESI corporation provides the remaining 7/8th of medical expenses

The medical benefits are provided in the form of no cash benefit, i.e., the insured persons can avail of full medical care free of cost (option C). This includes hospitalization in cases of sickness, employment injury, or maternity. Medical care is provided either directly through ESI hospitals and dispensaries, or indirectly through private insurance medical practitioners.

The funeral benefit under the ESI Act is a cash payment given on the death of an insured person for funeral expenses to a maximum amount of Rs. 15,000 (option D).  

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: You notice the following test is being performed by your senior on a 30-year-old patient having an Alvarado score of 7. The patient complained of pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen on performing the test. What is the name given to this clinical sign?
questions.solution:
The name given to this clinical sign is the Psoas sign.

The Alvarado score is a clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. A score of 7, as seen in this patient, suggests probable appendicitis. 

Various clinical signs have been described which are used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. Abdominal pain with hyperextension of the right hip is known as the Psoas sign. This is because of psoas muscle spasm, due to the inflamed appendix being in contact with this muscle. The patient often lies in a posture with the right hip flexed for pain relief.

Other options-

Option (B): Rovsing sign: Presence of pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen during palpation of the left lower quadrant of the abdomen.

Option (C): Dunphy’s sign: Abdominal pain on coughing.

Option (D): Aaron's sign- Firm pressure over McBurney's point in acute appendicitis causing pain in the epigastrium, left hypochondrium, umbilical and precordial regions.

If the score is 4-6, an an adjunctive CT scan would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with sadness, anxiety, insomnia, poor concentration,  loss of appetite, social withdrawal, and thoughts of self-harm for 15 days. The symptoms started 1 month after the delivery of her first baby. She has a family history of mood disorders. What is the treatment of choice for her in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features presenting one month postpartum, along with a family history of mood disorders is suggestive of postpartum depression. The preferred treatment for her condition is selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like fluoxetine and paroxetine.

Postpartum depression is characterized by the presence of at least five depressive symptoms for at least 2 weeks. Depressive symptoms include- low mood (subjective or observed) for most of the day, loss of interest or pleasure, insomnia or hypersomnia, psychomotor retardation or agitation, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, loss of energy or fatigue, suicidal ideation or attempt, impaired concentration or indecisiveness, and changes in weight or appetite.

The first-line therapy includes psychotherapy and SSRIs like fluoxetine and paroxetine. Once an effective dose is reached, treatment should be continued for 6-12 months to prevent relapse.

Other options-

Option (B): SNRIs (selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors) can be used as second-line management if the patient does not respond to SSRIs.

Option (C): Atypical antipsychotics are not used in the treatment of postpartum depression.

Option (D): ECT (electroconvulsive therapy) can be tried if four consecutive trials of medical management have failed. It is useful in patients with suicidal/infanticidal thoughts, those who are refusing to eat, those with psychotic symptoms, etc.

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

10-15%

0.1-0.2%

Note: Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is found to have colonic cancer on routine colonoscopy and biopsy. His father had developed a similar colonic cancer and died at the age of 40. His family history is remarkable for endometrial and urothelial cancer. There is no history of familial adenomatous polyposis. Abnormality in which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is responsible for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Regulated genomic instability in lymphoid cells

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of Lynch syndrome/Hereditary non-polyposis colonic cancer (HNPCC). HNPCC results from a defect in the DNA mismatch repair system.

HNPCC is an autosomal dominant disorder that leads to the development of carcinoma in the cecum and proximal colon. One defective copy of the gene is inherited while the other gene undergoes a loss of function mutation.  

DNA mismatch repair proteins function as spell checkers during DNA replication by correcting the incorrect pairing. In HNPCC, the proofreading function is lost leading to the accumulation of errors throughout the genome and microsatellite instability. A microsatellite is a sequence of 1-6 nucleotides found repeated throughout the genome. They are found in normal individuals at a constant length. In patients with DNA mismatch repair, these lengths are variable leading to mutated alleles. 

Other options: 

Option A: Patients with regulated genomic instability in lymphoid cells develop T and B cell neoplasia. 

Option C: Patients with a defect in the nucleotide excision repair pathway develop xeroderma pigmentosum.

Option D: Patients with defects in the homologous recombination DNA repair system may develop Bloom syndrome, ataxia-telangiectasia, and Fanconi anemia.

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

questions.text: During a FAST(focused assessment with sonography for trauma) examination in the emergency department, the faculty on-call asks you to examine Morrison's pouch for free fluid. Which anatomical region would you be checking?
questions.solution:
To examine Morrison's pouch on a FAST scan, you would be checking the perihepatic region in the abdomen.

Morrison's pouch refers to the hepatorenal pouch. It is present between the inferior surface of the liver and the upper pole of the right kidney. In the supine position, this pouch forms the most dependent part, where pathological fluid collection is most likely to occur. Hence, this pouch becomes significant during a FAST scan. 

Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) is an emergency ultrasound procedure used in critical care, to look for free fluid in the abdomen. It is helpful in performing a quick assessment as soon as the patient arrives in the emergency department. It can detect more than 100mL of free fluid (blood) in the abdominal cavity.

An extended version of the same called the eFAST is now being used to detect fluid/ air in the intrapleural spaces as well. This investigation has the advantage of being non-invasive, rapid, and inexpensive.

The person performing this scan usually assesses areas of potential free fluid collection in the following order:

  • Sub-xiphoid: pericardium
  • Perihepatic/ right upper quadrant/ Morrison's pouch
  • Left upper quadrant/ perisplenic
  • Suprapubic: rectovesical pouch or rectouterine pouch

FAST is used as a rapid diagnostic tool in emergency situations, but it cannot replace the CT scan and its accuracy in detecting pathology, as FAST is user dependent.

questions.text: A 38-year-old P2L2 lady with heavy menstrual bleeding for 8 months did not show a response to hormonal therapy. She asks for information on other treatment options, one of which is shown below. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to the procedure shown?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is uterine artery embolization, for which pelvic inflammatory disease is an absolute contraindication.

Uterine artery embolization can be done pre-operatively to a definitive surgery to reduce vascularity and fibroid size. ~90% patients get relief from the menorrhagia and pressure symptoms are relieved in ~70% patients. 

It is best suited for menorrhagia in a multiparous woman. 

Advantages-

  • No major surgery
  • No intraoperative bleeding
  • Shorter hospital stay
  • Less adhesions 
  • Higher patient satisfaction  

Indications-

  • Fibroids 
  • Arteriovenous malformations
  • Increased uterine vascularity 
  • Postpartum hemorrahge 
  • Placenta accreta syndromes 

Complications-

  • Fever, Infection 
  • Vaginal discharge, Bleeding
  • Ischemic pain (indicates success of procedure, but requires analgesia)
  • Pulmonary Embolism
  • Ovarian failure and premature menopause 
  • Reduced fertility 
  • Failure of procedure 
  • Contrast induced complications 
  • Radiation exposure 
  • Femoral site hematoma
  • Extrusion of fibroid into peritoneum 
  • Intraperitoneal adhesions 

Related Pearl: Contraindications to uterine artery embolization

Absolute contraindications:

  • GnRH agonist use
  • Asymptomatic fibroids
  • Pregnancy
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine malignancy
  • Calcified fibroid

Relative contraindications:

  • Patient desirous of future pregnancy: UAE causes poor uterine perfusion and pelvic adhesions, decreasing fertility. 
  • Postmenopausal women: Fibroids regress naturally, after menopause. Fibroid enlargement post-menopause raises the suspicion of malignancy.
  • Subserosal or submucosal fibroids: Pedunculated subtypes may detach intraperitoneally or within the uterine cavity. This may lead to sterile peritonitis or intrauterine infection.
  • Size or number of fibroids: Large fibroids or a greater number of fibroids can cause large amounts of necrosis following UAE. This may lead to post-op pain or infection. 
  • Contraindications to radiologic contrast agents.

questions.text: The following image shows the superior surface of the first cervical vertebra. The part of the bone marked as 1 gives attachment to:
questions.solution:
The part of the first cervical vertebra (C1) or Atlas that is marked as the number 1 is the posterior tubercle, and it gives attachment to ligamentum nuchae.

Atlas or C1 articulates with the occipital condyles of the skull above and with the axis (C2) below to form the atlantooccipital joint. The atlantooccipital joint allows for the nodding movement of the head on the vertebral column. There is no intervertebral disc between C1 and C2.

Features of the atlas:

  • No vertebral body
  • 2 lateral masses - with upper and lower articular facets
  • 2 arches- anterior and posterior arches 
  • 2 large transverse processes

Important attachments:

The anterior arch carries a roughened anterior tubercle on the anterior surface which attaches to the anterior longitudinal ligament. The posterior surface of the anterior arch articulates with the dens. The transverse ligament retains the dens against the anterior arch. The upper and lower borders provide attachment for the anterior atlantooccipital membrane and the diverging lateral parts of the anterior longitudinal ligament.

The superior border of the posterior arch attaches to the posterior atlantooccipital membrane. The inferior border is attached to ligamentum flavum. The posterior tubercle provides attachment for ligamentum nuchae.

questions.text: You have been asked to present a case on homicide, with pictorial representations. You added the following image in your presentation. Which of the following is the mechanism of death in this form of homicide?
questions.solution:
The image shows smothering with a pillow, which involves the blockage of the external air passages. It can be performed by a hand as well. Death in smothering with a pillow is due to slow hypoxia.

Smothering is defined as a form of asphyxia that is caused by closing the external respiratory orifices either by the hand or by other means or blocking up the cavities of the nose and mouth by the introduction of a foreign substance. Smothering can be either accidental, suicidal, or homicidal.

Accidental smothering makes up most of the fatal smotherings. A person suffering from epilepsy or intoxicated by alcohol might accidentally lie in a position that restricts the airway which might consequently cause death. Falling into a large quantity of semisolid or fine material might also cause asphyxia by covering the openings of the airway. Children may be suffocated accidentally while playing with plastic bags and is seen often in people who are addicted to glue-sniffing.

Suicide by smothering is not possible using the hand. Psychiatric patients or prisoners might attempt suicide by burying their faces in a mattress or in their clothing. It can be attempted by tying a polythene bag over the head as well.

Homicidal smothering is a simple and convenient method of homicide because it is extremely difficult to prove as it may not leave any evidence. The mouth and nose are closed by a hand or cloth, or the face may be pressed into a pillow (gentle homicide).

Bruising of the inner surface of the lips may be seen if greater force is applied during smothering. At times, mucus and squamous respiratory epithelium from the victim may be found in the smothering material. In most cases, death is due to slow asphyxia where death occurs between three to five minutes. However, death in plastic bag suffocation is rapid due to reflex cardiac arrest, rather than a purely hypoxic process. (Option C)

Other options-

Option (A) and (D) both relate to causes of death which are observed in hanging.

Option (A): Cerebral anemia occurs when the noose of the rope is placed at the nape of the neck which causes compression of the large vessels (both arteries and veins). This causes death within 10 to 15 seconds due to cerebral anemia and consequent coma.

Option (D): Venous congestion is seen in cases where the knot is situated over the chin causing compression of the jugular veins. This in-turn stops cerebral circulation leading to a rise in the venous pressure in the head and subsequent loss of consciousness. A tension of 2kgs is required to occlude the jugular veins.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy was brought with progressive right hip pain for 1 month. He had many episodes of pain and swelling of his hands. His brother had a stroke at age 6. Physical examination shows tenderness over the right hip with no gross skin changes. His blood smear shows the findings in the picture. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hip pain?

Vitals and Labs:

BP: 116/76 mm of Hg

Pulse: 80 bpm

Temp: 99 F

TLC: 5,000 /mm3
questions.solution:
The findings of dactylitis and family history of stroke at a young age, along with sickle cells in the blood smear, are suggestive of sickle cell disease (SCD).

This patient's hip pain in the absence of fever and normal leukocyte count is due to infarction or avascular necrosis (AVN) of the hip joint due to vaso-occlusion by sickle cells. The AVN of the hip may cause limp and leg-length discrepancies. 

Manifestations of sickle cell disease include:

  • Acute splenic sequestration due to venous obstruction, necessitating emergency transfusion/splenectomy
  • Painful ischemic crises due to vaso-occlusion in connective and musculoskeletal tissue
  • Renal papillary necrosis
  • Cerebrovascular strokes
  • Chronic lower leg ulcers
  • Priapism in males

The cardinal clinical feature of sickle cell anemia is acute vaso-occlusive pain, due to ischemia of the tissues. Vasoocclusive crisis can cause dactylitis, splenic infarction (shrunken spleen over time), AVN, etc. Most commonly, the femoral head is affected in AVN. Other sites affected include the humeral head and mandible.

Dactylitis referred to as a hand-foot syndrome, is often the first manifestation of pain in infants and young children with sickle cell anemia. Dactylitis often manifests with symmetric or unilateral swelling of the hands and/or feet.  

Other Options:

Option B- Septic arthritis manifests as fever, unilateral joint pain, and restricted motion. Although SCD patients have a higher risk of septic arthritis but no evidence of fever, joint swelling, and normal leukocyte count, rules out this diagnosis.

Option C- Patients with osteomyelitis often have a longer duration of fever and pain, swelling of the affected area, fewer or only 1 location of pain and tenderness, higher white blood cell counts, and an elevated C-reactive protein. Blood cultures, when positive, are helpful. Both Salmonella spp. and S. aureus causes osteomyelitis in children with sickle cell anemia, which is often in the diaphysis of long bones.

Option D-  Pseudogout or gout occurs due to crystal deposition in the joint. It also presents with unilateral joint pain. But there is also the presence of skin erythema and joint swelling with usually an acute onset. This patient has had pain in the joint for 1 month.

questions.text:
You are attending the ENT practical examination. Your external examiner gives you the following instrument in your viva station and asks you to state the uses of the same. Which of the following would constitute the part of your answer?
  1. It is used to depress the tongue
  2. Used for examining both the oral cavity and oropharynx.
  3. Assists while performing posterior rhinoscopy
  4. It can aid in the diagnosis of septic tonsillitis
  5. It can aid in performing Cottle's test
questions.solution:
The given image shows Lack's tongue depressor.

These are available in different sizes for adults and children. It is a very commonly used instrument in the field of ENT.

Uses:

  • It is used to depress the tongue
  • Used for examining both the oral cavity and oropharynx.
  • Lateral gutters are better examined by two tongue depressors; one retracting the tongue and the other retracting the cheek.
  • It can be used to examine the floor of the mouth by medially pushing down the lateral surface of the tongue. Thereby it also aids in the examination of the gums and oral buccal mucosa.
  • It is used to check the patency of the nose by spatula test.
  • Assists while performing posterior rhinoscopy.
  • It can aid in the diagnosis of septic tonsillitis. Pressure on the anterior pillar with the edge of the tongue depressor may express cheesy material from the crypts (normal) of frank fluid pus (septic tonsil). 

The above image shows Cottle test where cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly.
If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve.

The images below depict the method of performing posterior rhinoscopy and the various structures visualised in the posterior rhinoscopy mirror. 

The image attached below depicts the spatula test.  A cold tongue depressor is used to perform the spatula test. A tongue depressor is held below the nostrils to look for the area of mist formation, when the patient exhales, the two sides are compared.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for neurogenic diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Desmopressin is the drug of choice for neurogenic diabetes insipidus. 

Desmopressin is a selective vasopressin V2 receptor agonist.

V2 receptors are present throughout the collecting ducts. The V2 receptor is a G-protein coupled receptor, which, when activated, results in a signalling cascade of adenyl-cyclase, prompting an increase in cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) in the renal tubule cells, ultimately resulting in increased water permeability. This activity leads to a decrease in urine volume and an increase in urine osmolality.

Extrarenal V2-like receptors are involved in the release of coagulation factor VIII and von Willebrand factor, which increases platelet aggregation.

Desmopressin is used for the management of nocturnal polyuria, hemophilia A, central diabetes insipidus, and von Willebrand disease.

Desmopressin can be administered orally at high doses and is contraindicated in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Its major adverse effect is water intoxication. It can also give rise to flushing and transient headache.

Other options:

Option A: Vasopressin cannot be used in the management of diabetes insipidus, especially in the long term, owing to its short duration of action and side effects due to its action on V1 receptors as well, which include vasoconstriction, glycogenolysis, platelet aggregation and ACTH release.

Option C: Terlipressin is a vasopressin analogue that acts selectively on V1 receptors and is used in the management of bleeding oesophageal varices and hepatorenal syndrome.

Option D: Lypressin, like vasopressin, acts on both V1 and V2 receptors and is less potent than vasopressin. It is chiefly used for its V1 receptor-mediated actions.

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of diarrhea for the past 3 days. On examination, he is tachypneic. His laboratory investigations are given below. What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?
pH 7.2
pCO2 20 mmHg
HCO3- 7 mEq/L
Cl- 120 mEq/L
Na+ 135 mEq/L

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with increased anion gap

questions.solution:
The acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

Diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.20 indicates acidosis. The normal pH is 7.35-7.45. 

Step 2: Bicarbonate level of 7 mEq/L (normal = 22-28) together with low pH indicates that acidosis is due to loss of bicarbonate (i.e. base). Hence this is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: PCO2 levels of 20 mmHg indicate respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in PCO2 with a decrease in pH indicates that it is a compensatory mechanism. Hence the patient has metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.

Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- {(Cl-)+(HCO3-)}

=135-(120+7)

=8 mEq/L

The normal anion gap is 6-12 mEq/L. Hence the anion gap is within the normal range.

Diarrhea causes metabolic acidosis due to intestinal loss of bicarbonate-rich fluid.

Other options:

Option B: Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap is seen if the anion gap is >12 mEq/L. It occurs in conditions such as methanol poisoning, uremia, diabetic ketoacidosis, paracetamol poisoning, lactic acidosis, salicylate poisoning, etc. 

Option C: Respiratory acidosis occurs in conditions in which decreased ventilation (hypoventilation) increases the concentration of carbon dioxide in the blood and decreases the blood's pH. 

Option D: Lactic acidosis causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: In a group of 50 adult males, the mean height is 170 cm. The standard deviation is 2.5 cms. How many will have height between 170 to 172.5 cm, if the distribution is normal?
questions.solution:
17 men will have height between 170 to 172.5 cm.

According to the empirical rule of normal distribution, 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean.

In this case,

S.D = 2.5 cm, mean = 170 cm

170 + 2.5 = 172.5 cm, 170 – 2.5 cm = 167.5 cm

Hence 68% men will have height between 167.5 cm and 172.5 cms. And 34% men will have height between 170 cm and 172.5 cms.

34/100 × 50 = 17 men will have height between 170 cms and 172.5 cms. 

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: The given ECG depicts which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows a premature ventricular complex (PVC) that occurs every second beat (ventricular bigeminy).

PVCs exhibit premature timing by arising before the anticipated occurrence of the subsequent regular heartbeat. They display an aberrant QRS-T appearance, where the QRS complex appears unusually wide (0.12 sec or longer), and the T wave and QRS complex point in opposite orientations (discordant).

Frequent PVCs can manifest in different patterns. When two PVCs occur consecutively, they are termed a pair or couplet.

If three or more PVCs occur in succession (triplet), it is classified as ventricular tachycardia (VT). The repetitive pattern of one normal beat followed by one PVC is known as ventricular bigeminy.

When the repeating sequence involves two normal beats followed by a PVC, it is called ventricular trigeminy. Similarly, if three normal beats are followed by a PVC, it is referred to as ventricular quadrigeminy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old sewer worker was trapped in the sewer lines without any mask or protective equipment. He was brought dead to the casualty by his co-worker. The doctor observed an odor of rotten eggs emanating from the victim's body.  Which of the following complexes of the electron transport chain is inhibited by sewer gas?
questions.solution:
Sewer gas is a common name used for hydrogen sulfide which causes the characteristic smell of rotten eggs on poisoning, as seen in this patient. Hydrogen sulfide inhibits complex IV of the electron transport chain (ETC) and arrests the respiratory chain. 

The electron transport chain (ETC) is a specialized set of electron carriers that can accept electrons resulting from the oxidation of energy-rich molecules like glucose. The intermediate substrates in these reactions can pass on electrons to certain coenzymes such as nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH2).

The reduced forms can then donate electrons to the ETC by which they lose most of their free energy which is used to move H+ through the inner mitochondrial membrane. The H+ gradient thus produced results in the production of ATP. ATP synthesis together with electron transport is known as oxidative phosphorylation.

The reactions in oxidative phosphorylation and the arrangement of complexes that form the ETC are shown below.

questions.text: A patient with long-standing corticosteroid use was admitted for rhinocerebral mucormycosis. Which of the following is seen on microscopic examination?

choices.text: Broad hyphae with uneven thickness and irregular branching
Spherical budding yeast surrounded by a thick capsule

questions.solution:
Under the microscope, mucormycosis is seen as broad hyphae with uneven thickness and irregular branching.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungus that can be found in patients with acidosis, such as diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies. The most common agent is Rhizopus oryzae. The common clinical form is rhinocerebral mucormycosis, in which the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, the eyes, and the brain invade, causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. Treatment is by surgical debridement and amphotericin B administration.

Other options:

Option B: Long conidiophores with terminal vesicles: Aspergillus

Option C: Spherical budding yeast surrounded by a thick capsule: Cryptococcus neoformans

Option D: Oval, budding yeast cells: Candida

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 26-year-old lady with G2P1L1 at 34 weeks of gestation came for a regular check-up. On examination, her fundal height corresponds to 28 weeks of gestation. Doppler scan was done and showed the following flow pattern of umbilical arteries. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given flow pattern of umbilical arteries represents an absence of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical arteries, leading to a diagnosis of intrauterine growth restriction.

Other common flow patterns are shown below-

(a): Normal diastolic flow.

(b): Absence of end-diastolic flow seen in IUGR.

(c): Reversal of end-diastolic flow seen in impending IUD.

Umbilical artery vessels:

Characterised by forward, low resistance flow.
As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the resistance indices, so the amount of forward diastolic flow increases.
S/D ratio decreases as the period of gestation increases.

Abnormal flow patterns in umbilical artery:

Reduced End diastolic flow: Uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases)
Absent End diastolic flow: Fetal compromise (hence terminate the pregnancy by cesarean section if >34 weeks)
Reverse end diastolic flow: Impending doom of death (terminate pregnancy irrespective of gestational age)

Middle cerebral artery:

This will show increased diastolic velocity in fetus with hypoxemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with painful genital ulcers for the past two weeks. Examination revealed multiple, bleeding, soft ulcers that are exquisitely tender and bleed easily. The inguinal lymph nodes are tender and fluctuant. Which of the following would be a suitable culture medium for the suspected organism?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Among the given options, chocolate agar with IsoVitaleX is the most suitable culture media for isolating the organism. 

H. ducreyi are gram-negative bacilli. On staining, they are sometimes seen arranged in a characteristic 'school of fish' or 'railroad track' appearance. 

Clinically, patients develop an H. ducreyi infection from sexual contact with an infected person. Following this, they develop a papule that progresses to a pustule and finally a circumscribed ulcer. This is called chancroid or 'soft sore' and it may be single or multiple, very painful, bleeds easily, and is non-indurated. The infection then spreads to the lymph nodes which become tender, inflamed, and then suppurated. 

Diagnosis is established by isolating the organism on culture. The specimen may include scrapings from the ulcer base and aspirate from the suppurated lymph node. Culture is difficult but they can be grown on chocolate agar enriched with IsoVitaleX and vancomycin, fresh clotted rabbit blood, or on the chorioallantoic membrane of the chick embryo. H. ducreyi requires media enriched with the X factor, but not the V factor for growth. 

Treatment is with a single oral dose of 1g of azithromycin. Other options include oral ciprofloxacin, IM ceftriaxone, and oral erythromycin. Sexual contacts of these patients must be treated regardless of whether they are symptomatic or not. 

Other options-

Option A - Thayer Martin medium is used for the isolation of Neisseria species. Neisseria meningitidis causes meningitis and meningococcemia presenting as acute fever with chills, malaise, and prostration. Neisseria gonorrhea causes urethritis, proctitis, vulvovaginitis, conjunctivitis, and disseminated gonococcal infection. 

Option B - Tellurite blood agar is used for the isolation of Corynebacterium species. Corynebacterium diphtheria causes diphtheria with variable presentation. It can lead to asphyxia, circulatory failure, toxemia and local necrotic changes. 

Option D - Ashdown's medium is used for the isolation of Burkholderia pseudomallei species. This bacteria causes melioidosis. It may be acute presenting as acute septicemia and typhoid or pneumonia-like disease. In the chronic form, it presents with multiple caseous or suppurative foci.

A mother brings her infant expressing concern that the baby turns blue whenever he cries. With respect to Nadas' criteria, all of the following findings are used in diagnosing congenital heart disease, except:

ABG - Arterial blood gas

questions.solution:
Abnormal ABG finding is not included in Nadas' criteria.

Nadas' criteria are used to diagnose congenital heart disease in children clinically. The presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease.

The major criteria include:

  • Systolic murmur grade 3 or more
  • Any diastolic murmur
  • Cyanosis
  • Congestive cardiac failure

The minor criteria include:

  • Systolic murmur of grade 1 or 2
  • Abnormal second heart sound
  • Abnormal ECG
  • Abnormal chest X-ray findings

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient suffers from a myocardial infarction. Laboratory investigations reveal that troponin is elevated as a result of myocardial cell death. Which of the following features would not be seen in the cells of this patient?
questions.solution:
The manner of cell death seen in a patient with myocardial infarction is necrosis. Cell shrinkage is seen in apoptosis. 

Necrosis occurs due to severe injury. It can occur due to ischemia, exposure to toxins, burns, chemical and physical injury, and conditions that cause proteases to leak out of cells and damage the surrounding tissue. 

It is characterized by denaturation of cellular proteins, leakage of cellular contents through damaged membranes, local inflammation, enzymatic digestion of the cell. 

Necrosis occurs when damage to the cell is severe and irreversible. This leads to the entrance of lysosomal enzymes into the cytoplasm causing digestion. The contents of the cells may also enter the extracellular space and damage the surrounding tissue via inflammation. 

Some molecules called damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) such as ATP, uric acid that is present within healthy cells but are released during severe cell injury. These molecules trigger macrophages leading to phagocytosis of debris and the production of inflammatory cytokines. 

Necrosis can lead to the leakage of intracellular proteins into the circulation. These proteins can be detected as part of diagnostic tests for specific organ injuries. Examples include troponins for cardiac cell death, alkaline phosphatase for bile duct epithelium, and transaminases for hepatocytes. 

Some morphological features of necrosis are as follows: 

  • Nuclear changes following one of three patterns:
    • Karyolysis - decreased basophilic nature of chromatin due to enzymatic degradation of DNA by endonucleases
    • Pyknosis - nuclear shrinkage and increased basophilia
    • Karyorrhexis - fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus
  • Increase eosinophilia
  • Glassy homogenous appearance of the cell due to loss of glycogen
  • Myelin figures replacing dead cells that get further degraded
  • Discontinuities in plasma, organelle membranes
  • Dilation of mitochondria

The nucleus disappears within 1-2 days.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presents with complaints of pain and stiffness in the small joints of the hands. On examination, there is swelling of the metacarpophalangeal joints and proximal interphalangeal joints but the distal interphalangeal joints are normal. There is no involvement of the skin, hair, or nails. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The characteristic involvement of metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints with sparing of distal interphalangeal joints in a 34-year-old female is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis.

Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease. Its incidence increases between 25 and 55 years of age.

Signs and symptoms -

  • Swelling and pain of the small joints of the hands initially- metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are commonly involved. Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint involvement is usually due to coexistent osteoarthritis.
  • Morning stiffness
  • Swan-neck deformity - Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint
  • Boutonnière deformity - Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint,
  • Z-line deformity - Subluxation of the first MCP joint with hyperextension of the first interphalangeal (IP) joint 
  • Ulnar deviation of fingers
  • Constitutional findings such as fever, weight loss, etc
  • Monoarthritis of large joints can occur later
  • Tenosynovitis of palm(trigger finger)
  • Atlantoaxial joint involvement

Joints commonly affected in Rheumatoid Arthritis: (bilateral and symmetrically involved) 

  • MCP joints
  • Wrists
  • PIP joints
  • MTP joints
  • Atlantoaxial joint

Laboratory investigations - Detection of Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies help in differentiating this condition from other forms of arthritis.

Diagnosis is made with clinical signs and symptoms with corroboration from lab and imaging findings.

Other options-

Option (A): Gout is characterized by episodic acute arthritis or chronic arthritis due to the deposition of monosodium urate(MSU) crystals in the joints and connective tissue. It commonly affects postmenopausal women and middle-aged to elderly men. The metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP) of the first toe is commonly involved. Other joints that are commonly affected include the tarsal joints, ankle, and knee.

Option (B): Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis with a high prevalence in the elderly population. Commonly involved joints are the knee, hip, first MTP, and the cervical and lumbosacral spine. In the hands, the DIP and PIP joints and the base of the thumb are commonly involved. The wrist, elbow, and ankle are usually spared. 

Option (D): Psoriatic arthritis- In most cases psoriasis precedes arthritis but in some cases, both of them present in a span of 1 year or arthritis precedes psoriasis. There can be involvement of DIP and PIP joints and the joint involvement tend to follow "ray "distribution. Ray distribution refers to the involvement of all the joints of one finger while the adjacent finger is totally spared. Nail changes in the affected fingers are a differentiating feature of this condition.

questions.text: The best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution are:

choices.text: Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles
Sulfur dioxide, lead, and particulate matter

questions.solution:
The best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution are sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles.

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.

Effects of indoor air pollution:

  • Lung infections including pneumonia, tuberculosis, ALRI
  • Stroke
  • Ischemic heart disease
  • COPD
  • Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers
  • Pregnancy problems like low birth weight

Indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulfur dioxide - one of the best indicator of air pollution
  • Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter
  • Grit and dust measurement 
  • The co-efficient of haze - assessment of the amount of smoke or other aerosols in the air
  • Air pollution index - measure of pollution severity
  • Suspended particle matter (SPM) 

In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with loss of memory, urinary incontinence, and decreased ability to perform day-to-day activities. She is oriented to time and place, but not to person. On gait assessment, you notice a hypokinetic magnetic gait. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic triad of dementia, hypokinetic magnetic gait, and urinary incontinence seen in this patient suggest normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a communicating hydrocephalus caused by delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid. Meningeal scarring is seen in some patients, due to previous history of meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or head trauma.

It presents with the characteristic triad of

  • Dementia (mostly executive function),
  • Ataxic or apractic gait, and
  • Urinary incontinence (sometimes urgency too).

It is classified as idiopathic (primary) or symptomatic (secondary) occurring due to prior brain infection, injury, radiation, or hemorrhage. 

The etiology is poorly understood but is thought to be related to the hyperdynamic flow of CSF in the aqueduct, reduced compliance of the subarachnoid space, increased CSF pulse pressure, and reduced reabsorption of CSF. 

Diagnosis: 

  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the Sylvian fissures can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy due to the propped open (so-called “boxcarring”) appearance.
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure.
  • Another confirmatory test performed is the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) tap test, which shows marked improvement of symptoms with spinal fluid removal.

Treatment: Ventriculoperitoneal shunting: It is done to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Complications of the shunting procedure include shunt obstruction, infection, intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage, malposition or breakage of the shunt, etc.

Other options:

Option B - Frontotemporal dementia is a group of syndromes that is characterized by frontotemporal lobar degeneration. The most common variant, the behavioral variant, presents with social and emotional dysfunction which manifests as apathy, disinhibition, compulsivity, loss of empathy, overeating, and may have deficits in executive control.

Option C - Parkinson disease is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by tremors at rest, rigidity, bradykinesia, gait dysfunction, postural instability, speech difficulty, swallowing impairment, and autonomic disturbances. 

Option D - Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a degenerative brain disorder due to prions that leads to rapid mental deterioration, usually within a few months with associated myoclonus and behavioral changes.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male, a chronic smoker, presented with fever, a painful lump over his left cheek just below the ear, and difficulty in swallowing or talking. The patient also complained of mild testicular pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of painful swelling in the parotid region (parotitis) together with testicular pain (orchitis) are most likely suggestive of mumps.

Mumps is a paramyxoviral disease, which spreads by respiratory droplets.

Patients experience prodromal symptoms followed by parotitis. It develops in 24 hours and is often bilateral. Other salivary glands such as submaxillary and sublingual glands may also be involved, but are less likely than parotid. Patients complain of earaches and difficulty in eating, swallowing, or talking. Epididymo-orchitis is the 2nd common presentation. The testis is painful and tender and may enlarge up to several times its normal size. Other manifestations may include CSF pleocytosis, encephalitis, pancreatitis, and myocarditis.

Diagnosis is made by the detection of viral RNA by reverse-transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) or serology.

Treatment: The disease is self-limiting. Analgesics and application of warm or cold compress over the parotid and testicular swellings may help relieve the symptoms.

Other options:

Option A: Cervical tuberculosis may present as unilateral single or multiple painless lumps, usually in the posterior cervical or supraclavicular area. Night sweats, weakness, cough, and fever may be also seen.

Option B: Diphtheria presents with a sore throat and adherent tonsillar, pharyngeal, or nasal pseudomembranous lesions with low-grade fever. A few patients develop a bull neck. This results from submandibular and paratracheal edema and is associated with foul breath, thick speech, and stridor. Cutaneous diphtheria is characterized by punched-out ulcerative lesions with necrotic slough or a pseudomembrane.

Option D: Lymphomas present with enlarging lymphadenopathy centrally or peripherally depending on the type. They may be associated with B symptoms -fevers, drenching night sweats, and unintentional weight loss.

questions.text: A person is being exposed to different grades of temperature. In which of the following thermal grades will he experience the sensation of pain?
questions.solution:
The person experiences the sensation of pain in both freezing cold and burning hot temperature.

Thermal gradations are differentiated by three types of sensory receptors - cold receptors, warmth receptors, and pain receptors. The receptors are located in different areas and are differently concentrated.

In very cold temperatures, only the cold-pain fibers are stimulated. As the temperature rises to +10°C to 15°C, the cold-pain impulses cease, but the cold receptors begin to be stimulated, reaching peak stimulation at about 24°C and fading out slightly above 40°C.

Above about 30°C, the warmth receptor begins to be stimulated, but these also fade out at about 49°C. Finally, at around 45°C, the heat-pain fibers begin to be stimulated by heat.

This is the reason, why extreme degrees of both cold and heat can be painful.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology department with the following complaint. Which of the following forms the first line of management for the patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows esotropia (convergent squint),  commonly seen in children with hyperopia (also known as hypermetropia). The first line of management in the treatment of esotropia includes refractive error correction with glasses. 

In a child with associated accommodation issues and non-compliance to glasses, miotics are generally used. Di-isopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) or echothiophate (Option-A) is commonly used for this condition. Long-term usage causes secondary iris cysts. Prevention of these secondary iris cysts can be achieved by the concomitant use of phenylephrine. So, in such cases, both echothiophate + phenylephrine eye drops are prescribed (Option-B)

Further treatment may include orthoptic training (Option-D) or surgical correction of the squint.

Accommodative esotropia is a common type of squint due to the overaction of convergence associated with accommodation. This overaction is usually to overcome a hyperopic refractive error. It presents at around 2 to 3 years of age.

Types of accommodative esotropia include:

  • Refractive
    • Associated with high hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D)
    • Fully correctable by spectacles
  • Non-refractive type 
    • Occurs independent of refractive errors
    • A small increase in accommodation is accompanied by a dis­proportionately large increase in convergence
    • Abnormal accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio
    • Fully corrected by bifocal glasses

Image: Accommodative esotropia with and without correction

Mnemonic

The algorithm for the management of accommodative esotropia is as follows:

  • R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics
  • O: Orthoptics/Occlusion: for amblyopia
  • O: Operative correction: for non-accommodative component
  • P: Prism correction: for remaining error

The given image shows an iris pigment epithelial (IPE) cyst near the pupillary margin seen clinically secondary to echothiophate use.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common location of Ghon's focus?
questions.solution:
Primary bronchus does not describe the location of Ghon's focus as the tubercle bacilli implants in distal air spaces, not proximal.

Ghon's focus is the gray-white inflammation with consolidation. It is seen in primary tuberculosis. The common location of Ghon's focus is the lower part of the upper lobe or the upper part of the lower lobe, usually close to the pleura. Ghon's focus along with the nodal involvement is called the Ghon's complex.

The following image shows the presence of Ghon's complex on chest X-ray :

 

Primary tuberculosis occurs on first exposure. The following findings may be seen:

Ghon's focus - focus of infection located subpleurally
Ghon's complex - Ghon's focus with lymph node involvement
Ranke complex - a calcified Ghon's complex

Secondary tuberculosis occurs due to the reactivation of TB. It affects the apex. The following findings may be seen:

Puhl's complex - supraclavicular lesion
Assmann's complex - infraclavicular lesion

Disseminated or miliary tuberculosis is characterised by 1-2 mm disseminated lesions all over the lung. The following findings may be associated:

Simon's focus - early hematogenous seeding in the apex of lungs
Rich focus - tuberculous caseous foci in brain, meninges and spinal cord

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with acute onset of blurry vision in the right eye since morning. She also complains of pain on movement of the right eye for two days.  She gives a history of weakness in her right upper limb one month ago, which resolved spontaneously. On examination, the following finding is elicited. What is the next step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect. This finding along with the clinical scenario is suggestive of an acute relapse of multiple sclerosis, and methylprednisolone is used for immediate management.

The patients' symptoms of blurry vision and pain on movement of the eye are suggestive of optic neuritis. The above image shows a relative afferent pupillary defect (Marcus-Gunn pupil) on the swinging flashlight test. On shining the torchlight to the normal eye, both the pupils constrict due to intact direct and indirect light reflexes to the stimulus carried by the normal optic nerve. On swinging and shining the torchlight to the diseased eye, both the pupils appear to dilate. This is due to the damage to the optic nerve carrying the afferent fibers in the diseased eye, resulting in the loss of direct and indirect light reflexes. This phenomenon is seen in cases of unilateral optic nerve damage, like in this patient's optic neuritis.

High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for five days is the drug of choice for acute exacerbation of multiple sclerosis.

Other options:

Options B and C: Plasma exchange can be used for an acute relapse of MS but is not the first preferred treatment. It can be used along with steroids or in case of poor response to steroids. Beta Interferon can be used in relapsing MS to slow the attack rate and reduce disability. It is not suitable for an acute episode of optic myelitis.

Option D: Acyclovir is an antiviral and is not effective in the treatment of optic neuritis due to acute MS. 

2017 revised, McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. The McDonald’s criteria takes into consideration the clinical attacks and objective lesions. In addition, it also involves an assessment of the lesions based on MRI and other imaging techniques.

questions.text: A patient with an acute attack of trigeminal neuralgia was treated with an anti-epileptic drug intravenously. The next day, he developed pain, swelling, and purple discolouration of his hand, distal to the site of injection as shown below. Identify the drug administered.
questions.solution:
The drug administered was phenytoin.

The clinical vignette of the patient developing pain, swelling, and purple discoloration of the skin, subsequent to intravenous administration of an antiepileptic drug for trigeminal neuralgia are indicative of purple glove syndrome due to phenytoin.

Purple glove syndrome is a rare complication that may follow the intravenous administration of phenytoin. It typically presents with pain, edema, and discoloration at the injection site that spreads distally.

Phenytoin is a hydantoin derivative that acts by slowing the rate of recovery of voltage-gated Na+ channels from inactivation and subsequently limits the repetitive firing of action potentials.

Phenytoin is extensively bound to plasma proteins, mainly albumin, and is metabolized by hepatic CYPs.

Despite its narrow therapeutic index, phenytoin is used in the treatment of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, complex partial seizures, status epilepticus, trigeminal neuralgia, and behavioral disorders.

 

Due to its ability to induce various CYPs, treatment with phenytoin can increase the metabolism of oral contraceptives that are metabolized by CYP3A4 and can lead to contraceptive failure.

It is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy as it can lead to fetal hydantoin syndrome. This syndrome is characterized by craniofacial anomalies like hypertelorism and epicanthal folds, short nose, and deep nasal bridge, malformed and low set ears, short neck, hypoplastic distal phalanges and underdevelopment of nails of fingers and toes, growth retardation, cognitive deficits and motor developmental delay. 

Other side effects of phenytoin include behavioural changes, increased frequency of seizures, gingival hyperplasia, megaloblastic anaemia, osteomalacia, hirsutism and hypersensitivity reactions.

Other options:

Option A: Carbamazepine is a sodium channel modulator like phenytoin used in the management of different types of focal and generalised tonic-clonic seizures. Its side effects include drowsiness, vertigo, ataxia, blurred vision and an increase in seizure frequency.

Option B: Zonisamide is a T-type calcium channel blocker used in the management of focal aware seizures and focal seizures with impaired awareness. Its side effects include somnolence, ataxia, anorexia, fatigue.

Option D: Clonazepam is a GABA receptor allosteric modulator that belongs to the benzodiazepine class of drugs and is used in the management of generalised absence seizures. It can result in lethargy, drowsiness, behavioural disturbances, withdrawal seizures and tolerance.

questions.text: The table shows the examination findings of various psychiatric emergencies presenting with fever and altered sensorium. Which of the following is corresponding to the findings seen in serotonin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option (B) i.e. row 2 has findings corresponding to Serotonin syndrome.  

Serotonin syndrome is a serious condition occurring due to serotonin overstimulation. Clinical features include diarrhea, restlessness, agitation, hyperreflexia, autonomic instability with fluctuations in vital signs, myoclonus, seizures, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, rigidity, delirium, coma, status epilepticus, cardiovascular collapse, and death. 

It can occur with any drug that increases serum serotonin levels like MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors), SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants), tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA (amphetamine), dextromethorphan, etc.

It is treated with cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist). 

Other options-

Option (A): Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a rare condition that occurs on administration of neuroleptic (antipsychotic) drugs. It presents with autonomic instability, hyperpyrrexia, rigidity, and delirium. Sustained rigidity leads to muscle breakdown and elevated creatinine kinase levels. NMS will not show the hyperreflexia and clonus seen in serotonin syndrome. The causative drug should be stopped immediately and treatment can be started with dantrolene and bromocriptine.

Option (C): Anticholinergic syndrome can occur due to concurrent use or use of higher doses of strong anticholinergic drugs like cyproheptadine or diphenhydramine. It will present with anticholinergic symptoms like blurring of vision, dry mouth, constipation, etc. Hyperreflexia and hypertonia would not be seen in this condition. 

Option (D): Malignant hyperthermia is seen in the setting of neuromuscular blockade administration in the operating room, such as succinylcholine. It presents with elevated body temperature, muscle rigidity, hypotension, muscle breakdown, etc. The drug of choice to treat this condition is intravenous dantrolene.

questions.text:
An elderly lady presented with weight gain. On examination, her limbs appeared thin, and her blood pressure was 180/100 mm Hg. She is also noticed to have the following findings, as shown in the image below. Her lab investigation findings are given below. This condition is likely to be due to
  • 24h urinary free cortisol- elevated 
  • Plasma cortisol after administration of 1mg dexamethasone - elevated
  • Plasma ACTH levels- elevated
  • Corticotropin-releasing hormone test- negative
  • High-dose dexamethasone test- negative
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing buffalo hump, central obesity, and purple stretch marks, is suggestive of Cushing's syndrome. It is likely to be due to ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production.

Cushing's syndrome refers to a group of clinical features that result from chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids. It can be ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent.

Clinical features of Cushing’s syndrome are attributed to the increased glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and sex steroid actions of cortisol. They include:

System Clinical features
Body fat
  • Central or truncal obesity (most common)
  • Buffalo hump (fat deposition behind the neck)
  • Moon facies  
Skin
  • Purple striae (over abdomen & flanks)
  • Acne and Hirsutism 
  • Easy bruising 
  • Facial plethora
  • Hyperpigmentation 
Musculoskeletal
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Osteoporosis
Metabolic
  • Poorly controlled hyperglycemia
  • Dyslipidemia
Reproductive
  • Oligomenorrhea
  • Amenorrhea
Renal
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
CVS
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Diastolic Hypertension 
  • Edema 
  • Hypertension
Hematologic
  • Hypercoagulable state 
  • Lymphopenia
  • Neutrophilia
  • Eosinopenia
CNS
  • Depression
  • Psychosis 
  • Anxiety

The image given below shows the clinical features seen in Cushing's syndrome.

Once Cushing's syndrome is suspected, laboratory investigations are useful in the diagnosis. Patients will have elevated 24-hour urinary cortisol levels; they have elevated levels of plasma cortisol, which are not suppressed by dexamethasone. If these are elevated, it confirms that the patient has elevated levels of cortisol.

The next step is to evaluate if the elevated cortisol levels are due to elevated ACTH or are independent of ACTH levels. In this patient, the ACTH levels are elevated, which means that increased ACTH has caused increased production of cortisol. Increased ACTH can be due to a pituitary tumor that produces ACTH or ectopic ACTH production that is seen in tumors like bronchial or pancreatic carcinoids, medullary thyroid carcinoma, etc.

The source of ACTH production can be identified using an MRI of the pituitary, a corticotropin-releasing hormone test, and a high-dose dexamethasone test. If the ACTH production is due to an adenoma in the pituitary, it responds to the administration of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) and is suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone. In this patient, both of these tests are negative, which means that ACTH production is not from the pituitary but is due to ectopic production of ACTH. The patient has to be evaluated for underlying tumours. 

Other options:

Option A: Pituitary adenoma has elevated levels of cortisol and is normal to high ACTH levels. The pituitary MRI might show the presence of a tumor. CRH test and high-dose dexamethasone tests are positive.

Option B: In bilateral adrenal hyperplasia, there are increased levels of cortisol. However, the ACTH levels are low due to negative feedback to the hypothalamus and pituitary.

Option C: In adrenocortical adenoma also, cortisol levels are associated with a decrease in ACTH levels.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese woman presented with a low-grade fever and colicky pain in the right hypochondrium. Scleral icterus and tenderness in the right hypochondrium were noted. Ultrasound showed the following finding in the enlarged common bile duct (measuring 9 mm). Investigations reveal deranged liver function tests. Which of the following would be best suited for her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasonograph indicate a diagnosis of choledocholithiasis. The next best step in the management of this patient is endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).

Symptoms of fever and obstructive jaundice symptoms such as scleral icterus, light-colored stools, and dark-colored urine point toward a diagnosis of choledocholithiasis.

The first investigation, in this case, is a USG to look for biliary duct dilation and determine whether it is intra- or extrahepatic. Once this is confirmed, ERCP can be done as it can remove the stone without operative intervention. 

Common indications for ERCP:

  • Relief of biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease (can present as unexplained jaundice)
  • Biliary drainage
  • Biliary stenting for strictures and leakage
  • Biliary or pancreatic ductal system tissue sampling
  • Balloon dilation of the duodenal papilla or ductal strictures
  • Sphincterotomy
  • Sphincter of Oddi manometry

ERCP utilizes a side-viewing endoscope through which it identifies and is able to cannulate the Ampulla of Vater. A water-soluble contrast is then injected into the common bile duct. It helps in identifying stones or strictures.

Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) is used in case of unsuccessful ERCP or anatomical difficulty for EŖCP.

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient presents to the clinic for bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain for the past week. Colonoscopy shows continuous involvement with inflammation involving mucosa and submucosa. Pseudopolyps are observed. Microscopic evaluation of biopsy specimens shows crypt abscesses with no granulomas. A diagnosis is made based on a biopsy. Which of the following is not an extra-intestinal manifestation of this condition?

The given clinical scenario points to ulcerative colitis and primary biliary cholangitis is not an extraintestinal manifestation of ulcerative colitis.

The clinical vignette describing chronic diarrhea with colonoscopic findings showing friable mucosa with continuous involvement, pseudopolyps, and microscopic findings showing crypt abscesses is suggestive of ulcerative colitis.

Ulcerative colitis is characterized by recurring episodes of inflammation limited to the mucosa of the colon and rectum. The diagnosis of ulcerative colitis is based on the history of diarrhea with the identification of colonoscopic and biopsy findings.

    • pleuropericarditis

questions.text:
An 18-year old girl was diagnosed with acute intermittent porphyria. She was told that attacks of the illness can be prevented by avoiding known precipitating drugs like griseofulvin and barbiturates. What is the biochemical basis for the precipitation of such an exacerbation?
(ALA synthase- Aminolevulinic acid synthase)
questions.solution:
The biochemical basis of precipitation of porphyria by barbiturates is the derepression of ALA synthase.(ALAS- 1)

Mechanism: Barbiturates increase the synthesis of CYP450, which increases the consumption of heme. This decrease in heme concentration in the liver leads to the de-repression or induction of ALA synthase. This increases the synthesis of heme precursors, which exacerbates the attacks.

Acute intermittent porphyria is due to a defect in HMB synthase, usually inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. Under conditions where heme synthesis is increased in the liver, HMB- synthase activity may become limiting. This leads to the accumulation and excretion of ALA, PBG, and other heme pathway intermediates. Precipitating factors include:

  • Endogenous and exogenous steroids, including oral contraceptives
  • Porphyrinogenic drugs - like barbiturates, griseofulvin, etc
  • Alcohol
  • Low-calorie diets for weight loss
  • Fasting
  • Infections
  • Surgery

It is a type of hepatic porphyria characterized by neurovisceral symptoms, abdominal pain, and peripheral neuropathies. Diagnosis is based on elevated ALA and porphobilinogen in the urine and plasma.
