questions.text: Which of the following is the electrocardiograph changes seen in early stages of acute pericarditis?

choices.text: ST-segment depression with flat T waves
ST-segment elevation with PR segment depression

questions.solution:
ECG showing diffuse ST-segment elevation with PR segment depression is seen in early stages of acute pericarditis.

The ECG changes in acute pericarditis evolves through four stages:

  • Stage 1- Generalized ST-segment elevation with upward concavity with reciprocal depressions only in aVR and V1 and PR segment depression. 
  • Stage 2 - The ST segments return to normal
  • Stage 3 - Diffuse T wave inversion
  • Stage 4 - ECG returns to normal in weeks or months

Echocardiography findings are usually normal or may show evidence of a pericardial effusion. If abnormal, regular echocardiographic monitoring is recommended.

The ECG below shows acute pericarditis causing diffuse ST-segment elevations in leads I, II, aVF, and V2 to V6, with reciprocal ST depressions in lead aVR.

Other options:

Option A: ST-segment depression with flat T waves are seen in hypokalemia. Prolongation of QT interval is also seen.

ECG given below shows ST depression and broad flat T waves seen in hypokalemia.

Option B: Electrical alternans of P, QRS, and T waves are seen in cardiac tamponade.

ECG given below shows electrical alterans seen in cardiac tamponade.

Option D: Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia.

ECG given below shows tall peaked T waves seen in hyperkalemia.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man came with progressive difficulty in swallowing food. Barium study showed marked dilatation of the esophagus proximal to the obstruction. Further investigations reveal incomplete relaxation of the LES in response to swallowing, high resting LES pressure, and absent esophageal peristalsis. Which among the following is responsible for this?

LES- Lower esophageal sphincter
VIP- Vasoactive intestinal peptide
NO- Nitric oxide
ACh- Acetylcholine
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of achalasia cardia. In this condition, VIP and NO are decreased causing failure of the LES to relax.

Achalasia cardia is a condition in which food accumulates in the esophagus. It leads to massive dilatation as a result of increased resting LES tone and incomplete relaxation on swallowing. The myenteric plexus of the esophagus is deficient at the LES and the release of NO and VIP is decreased.

Normally, the tone of the LES is under neural control. The release of acetylcholine from vagal endings causes the intrinsic sphincter to contract, and the release of NO and VIP from interneurons causes it to relax. The crural portion of the diaphragm is innervated by the phrenic nerves. Its contraction is coordinated with respiration and contractions of the chest and abdominal muscles. Thus, the intrinsic and extrinsic sphincters operate together. This permits the orderly flow of food into the stomach and prevents reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: A patient who has dental caries develops an earache. Which of the following nerves is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The pain from dental caries is referred to the ear via the auriculotemporal branch of the trigeminal nerve.

Otalgia refers to pain in the ear. It can be due to local causes, referred causes, or psychogenic.

The ear receives nerve supply from multiple nerves, which also supply adjacent areas of the head and neck region. Thus, conditions causing pain in the adjacent areas can also cause pain in the ear. This is termed referred otalgia. 

Referred otalgia is mediated by the following nerves:

Auriculotemporal branch of the trigeminal nerve (V nerve):

  • Dental - impacted teeth, caries, Costen syndrome
  • Oral cavity - ulcerative or benign lesions of tongue and oral mucosa
  • Temporomandibular joint - osteoarthritis, bruxism, dislocation, dentures
  • Sphenopalatine neuralgia

Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve (IX nerve):

  • Oropharynx - lesions of the palate, and tonsil including the tonsillar pillars
  • The base of tongue - tuberculosis or malignancy
  • Eagle's syndrome - elongated styloid process

Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (X nerve):

  • Lesions of esophagus
  • Lesions of larynx

Greater auricular nerve (C2, C3 nerve)/Lesser occipital nerve (C2 nerve):

  • Cervical spondylosis
  • Caries spine
  • Spinal lesions

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman, who is a farmer by occupation, presents with the following lesion. Biopsy reveals full‐thickness epidermal dysplasia. Choose the incorrect statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: Periungual Bowen disease is highly recurrent

questions.solution:
The above image shows a red, scaly plaque-like lesion suggestive of Bowen disease. The incorrect statement about this condition is that abdomen is the commonest site of lesions. The lower part of the legs is the common site for Bowen disease.

It is an intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma characterized by a persistent, non‐elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque. It is commonly seen in women after the sixth decade of life. It usually grows progressively but sometimes undergoes spontaneous partial resolution. It can occur anywhere, but it occurs more in the sun-exposed areas like lower legs, and head and neck region. Human papillomavirus 16 and 18 infections are associated with it. 

Bowen's disease when subungual or periungual affects younger women and is associated with a high risk of invasion and recurrence.

Histologically, it is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia.

questions.text: Given below is a dissected heart specimen of a middle-aged man showing the internal structure of the right atrium and ventricle. The structures marked as 1 and 2 are the remnants of which of the following structures respectively?
questions.solution:
The structures marked as 1 and 2 are the limbus and floor of fossa ovalis, which are the remnants of septum secundum and septum primum respectively.

Fossa ovalis is an oval-shaped depression in the septal wall of the right atrium just above the opening of the inferior vena cava. It marks the location of the embryonic foramen ovale. 

  • The floor of fossa ovalis is the remnant of the septum primum.
  • The limbus of the fossa ovalis is the prominent upper margin of the fossa ovalis. It is a remnant of the septum secundum.

Related Pearl: Development of Interatrial septum

  • The Inter-atrial septum develops from Septum Primum and Septum Secundum
  • The septum primum begins to develop at 28 days. It is a thin, crescentic fold of endocardium that arises craniodorsally and grows down to the AV cushions, leaving an ostium primum below its free edge.
  • Septum primum fuses with the AV cushions at approximately 35 days, obliterating the ostium primum.
  • The ostium secundum is an opening in the upper part of the septum primum. It forms at about 33 days, i.e., before the ostium primum closes.
  • The septum secundum is a thick muscular septum that arises to the right of the septum primum. It grows from the roof of the atrium but does not reach the AV cushion. The gap between the two septa is known as foramen ovale.
  • After birth, the foramen ovale is obliterated by the fusion of the septum primum with the septum secundum.
  • In terms of adult anatomy, the annulus ovalis/limbus of fossa ovalis is the lower free edge of the septum secundum, while the floor of fossa ovalis represents the septum primum.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents with numbness and paraesthesia along the anterolateral thigh two days after vaginal delivery. Which among the following nerve injury causes her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of meralgia paraesthetica which is caused by injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve.

The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is at risk of injury during prolonged pushing with hip flexion as the nerve is compressed under the inguinal ligament.

Other options-

Option A- The peroneal nerve can get compressed under the flexed knee during prolonged lithotomy positioning during labor. It can also occur when the patient's knees are resting against a firm surface like the hospital bed rails or stirrups during labor.

Options B and C- The iliohypogastric nerve and ilioinguinal nerve are most commonly injured during cesarean section.

questions.text: A 30-year-old P3L3 lady complained of bright red bleeding per vagina 15 days after the vaginal delivery of her 3rd baby. Which among the following options could be the likely cause of this bleeding?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with bright red vaginal bleeding on the 15th day of postpartum is secondary postpartum hemorrhage, which can be caused by a placental polyp.

Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) occurring between 24 hours and 12 weeks after delivery is called secondary or late PPH.

Causes of secondary PPH include:

  • Placental polyp: Retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and eventually form a placental polyp, which on detachment from the myometrium causes brisk hemorrhage.
  • Abnormal involution of the placental site.
  • Retention of placental cotyledon or products of conception.
  • Uterine artery pseudoaneurysm.
  • Endometritis
  • Coagulopathy

It is treated with oxytocin, methyler­gonovine, or a prostaglandin analog if the patient is stable and sonography reveals an empty uterine cavity. Antimicrobials are given if a uterine infection is suspected. Gentle suction curettage can be done if large clots are seen in the uter­ine cavity on sonography, or if bleeding persists after medical management.

Other options: 

Option A: Multiparity can lead to inadequate retraction and frequently adherent placenta and cause primary PPH.

Option B: Perineal lacerations and an atonic uterus are causes of primary PPH. 

Option C: Atonic uterus is one of the causes of primary PPH.

questions.text:
You are a part of a research team working on a new rapid diagnostic screening test for COVID. The following table shows the results of 10,000 people who took the new screening test. Calculate the positive predictive value of this screening test.
  Disease - Present Disease - Absent
Screening test - Positive 40 20
Screening test - Negative 100 9840
questions.solution:
The positive predictive value of this screening test is 66.6%. Positive predictive value implies the probability of a person with a positive test, actually having the disease. 

This is calculated using the following formula :

(TP/TP+FP) x 100

where,

TP - True positive (Screening test and diagnosis is positive for the disease)

FP - False positive (Screening test is positive but the diagnosis is negative)

In this scenario :

(40/40+20) x 100 = (40/60) x 100 = 0.666 x 100 = 66.6%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient becomes confused and drowsy and has one episode of vomiting post thyroidectomy surgery. On examination, she has a temperature of 100 degrees F along with tremors of the hand. Laboratory reports reveal elevated thyroid hormone levels. The best drug for the immediate management of this condition is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with features of fever, CNS depression, vomiting, and elevated thyroid hormones following surgery is suggestive of thyroid storm. Propylthiouracil, which inhibits thyroid synthesis and also inhibits peripheral conversion of T4 to T3, is the best drug for the immediate management of this case.

Thyroid storm/ Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is a rare but severe life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism induced by the release of excessive thyroid hormones.

Causes:

  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Infection
  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy.
  • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
  • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Amiodarone administration
  • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
  • Following RAI (radioactive iodine) therapy

Features:

  • They present 12–24 hours after surgery with hyperpyrexia and severe dehydration
  • Cardiovascular: Circulatory collapse, hypotension, palpitations, tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure
  • GI symptoms: vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice.
  • Neurological symptoms: restlessness, irritability, delirium, tremor, convulsions, and coma 

Treatment:

  • Supportive measures – rehydration by proper fluid therapy, tepid sponging, cooling blankets
  • Thionamides like Propylthiouracil (PTU) or methimazole or carbimazole are used. They inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis. Propylthiouracil also inhibits the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Hence, PTU is the preferred drug in thyroid storm. However, the risk for severe liver injury and acute liver failure associated with PTU therapy makes either carbimazole or methimazole first-choice thionamide in patients with deranged liver function tests.
  • Lugol’s iodide is given one hour after intake of thionamides. They inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis by Wolff- Chaikoff effect. Large doses of iodide inhibit organic binding of the iodide and hence decrease thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Propranolol is used to reduce tachycardia and other adrenergic manifestations. It also reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
  • Glucocorticoids – reduce the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and controls the shock. 
  • Digitoxin, cardiac monitoring is crucial.

As per the references, there are certain discrepancies over the drug of choice being an anti-thyroid drug (PTU) or a beta-blocker(Propranolol). However, as per the recent updates, PROPRANOLOL is primarily indicated in HYPERTHYROIDISM (not in thyroid crisis) because it has limited effect and slow onset for reducing serum T3 conversion. Additionally, in cases where deiodinase inhibition is significant (in cases of severe hyperthyroidism) like in THYROID CRISIS/ THYROTOXICOSIS an anti-thyroid drug is considered as the therapeutic drug (DOC), thus the answer to this MCQ is PTU and NOT PROPRANOLOL.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

questions.text: The egg shown below belongs to:

questions.text: The following graph shows the response to 4 drugs at different concentrations. Arrange these drugs in the decreasing order of their efficacy.
questions.solution:
In the given image, drug B has maximum efficacy (maximum height) followed by drug A> drug D> drug C.

Efficacy is the capacity of a drug to activate a receptor and generate a cellular response. If the response is more, the drug is said to be more efficacious. Since the response of drug B (height) is maximum in the given graph, it has the highest efficacy.

The potency of the drug is defined as the concentration of the drug which produces half of the maximal effect. The drug which produces half of the maximum effect in the least concentration is said to be more potent. More the curve is towards the left, more is the potency. Therefore, in the graph drug A has maximum potency followed by drug B> drug C> drug D.

Efficacy reflects the capacity of a drug to activate a receptor and generate a cellular response. With respect to the efficacy, a drug can be called as

  • Full agonist- The drug has very high efficacy.
  • Partial agonist- The drug has low efficacy
  • Antagonist- The drug binds to the receptor but has zero efficacy

questions.text: Which among the following is COVID appropriate behaviour?

choices.text: Maintain a distance of at least 2 feet in all public places
Remove the upper string of the mask first followed by the lower string
Tie the lower string of the mask first followed by upper string
The external pleats of the mask should face downwards

questions.solution:
The external pleats of the mask should face downwards is the only COVID appropriate behaviour in the above options.

 COVID appropriate behaviours prevent the transmission of COVID 19 infection. Important ones are:

  • Greet without physical contact
  • Maintain a distance of at least 6 feet in all public places.
  • Wear reusable hand-made face-cover or mask, at all times.
    • The nasal clip should be present over the nose and external pleats should face downwards. 
    • Open the mask pleats so that the mask covers the mouth and nose. 
    • Tie the upper strings of the mask first followed by lower strings.
    • Do not touch the front of the mask.
    • Replace the mask every 8 hours or when damp.
    • While removing, the mask, remove the lower string of the mask first followed by the upper string.
    • Dispose the mask and wash your hands.
  • Avoid touching eyes, nose, and mouth
  • Maintain respiratory hygiene. Cover your nose and mouth when you cough or sneeze with a tissue or handkerchief. If there is no tissue or handkerchief, always cover your nose and mouth with a bent elbow before coughing or sneezing. Immediately wash your hands after that.
  • Wash hands frequently and thoroughly or sanitise with alcohol-based sanitiser.
  • Regularly clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces by wearing gloves.
  • Do not spit in the open
  • Avoid unnecessary travel and discourage crowd and social gatherings.

questions.text: Identify the test which is being demonstrated in the video given below:
questions.solution:
The video shows an examination being performed with the knee flexed to about 20 degrees which indicates that it is the Lachman test. The presence of free gliding indicates that it is a positive Lachman test.

Lachman test: The patient’s knee is flexed to 20 degrees.  The lower part of the thigh is grasped with one hand and the upper part of the leg with the other hand. The joint surfaces are shifted backward and forward upon each other.  If the knee is stable, there should be no gliding. The presence of gliding indicates the laxity of the anterior cruciate ligament.

Other options:

Anterior and posterior drawer test: The test is performed with the patient’s knees flexed to 90 degrees, and the feet resting on the examining bed. The examiner then grasps the upper part of the leg with both hands and rocks it forward and backward. Excessive anterior movement denotes anterior cruciate laxity (anterior drawer test) Excessive posterior movement denotes posterior cruciate laxity (posterior drawer test). 

McMurray’s test: The test is used to identify torn meniscus. The knee is flexed as far as possible and the joint is stabilized with one hand. With the other hand, the examiner rotates the leg medially and laterally. If there is a clicking sound while rotating the leg, the test is positive. The sound is produced due to the trapping of the loose tag of the torn meniscus between the articular surfaces.

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triad of the knee. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to a lateral blow to the knee.

It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

The image below shows the unhappy triad of the knee joint on MRI (PDW SPIR):

  1. Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
  2. Rupture of the medial collateral ligament
  3. Inner meniscal tear (image shows complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with pain, swelling, and redness in his right leg for the past 2 weeks. On examination, purulent discharge was observed exuding from the proximal end of the right tibia. There is no history of any chronic illness or trauma. What is the radiological investigation of choice for the early stage of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with symptoms of pain, swelling, and redness of the lower limb which was later associated with the development of a discharging sinus is suffering from osteomyelitis. MRI is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of osteomyelitis. 

The characteristic early signs of osteomyelitis include bone marrow edema. This is seen as a low T1 signal in the bone marrow, along with a high signal on T2 MRI.

Abscesses are the walled pockets of infection serving as complications in both the early and late stages of osteomyelitis. They appear as well-demarcated low-signal collections on T1 and high signal collections similar to fluid on T2 images. Usual locations include the bone itself, adjacent soft tissue, and subperiosteal spaces.

X-rays are not useful in early acute osteomyelitis because of minimal findings. Exposure to ionizing radiation and limited soft-tissue contrast is the main disadvantage of CT that makes it less useful. 

Osteomyelitis is an acute or chronic inflammatory process involving the bone and its structures secondary to infection with pyogenic organisms, including bacteria, fungi, and mycobacteria. The bone becomes susceptible to disease due to large inoculation of microorganisms, from trauma, ischemia, or the presence of foreign bodies because bone sites to which microorganisms can bind are exposed.

The bone can get infected by a hematogenous route through bacteremia seeding of a bone infection from a distant source of infection, contiguous spread from surrounding tissue and joints, or direct inoculation of bone from trauma or surgery. The most common pathogen of acute and chronic hematogenous osteomyelitis in adults and children is Staphylococcus aureus. Other common pathogens are:

  • Coagulase-negative staphylococcus
  • Beta-hemolytic streptococcus
  • Enterococci
  • Aerobic gram-negative bacilli (including pseudomonas species, Enterobacter species, Escherichia coli)
  • Anaerobic gram-negative bacilli (such as peptostreptococcus, Clostridium species, Bacteroides)

Osteomyelitis can be classified as acute or chronic based on histopathological findings rather than the duration of illness. Infection occurring before the development of sequestra is referred to as acute osteomyelitis. It usually takes place within two weeks of disease onset. The infection is considered chronic following the development of necrotic bone and the formation of sequestra. Acute infections generally present with pain, swelling, and redness of the affected area associated with systemic illness while discharging sinuses may be present in chronic infections.

Surgical debridement of all diseased bone is required as antibiotics penetrate poorly into infected fluid collections such as abscesses and injured or necrotic bone. Thus, the removal of necrotic tissue and bone is usually indicated where feasible. The cornerstone of treatment for osteomyelitis is prolonged antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate is being evaluated for the findings shown below. Which of the following is the gold standard for diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clip depicts neonatal seizure of focal clonic type. Video electroencephalogram (EEG) is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Neonatal seizures are defined as the occurrence of sudden, paroxysmal, abnormal alteration of electrographic activity at any point from birth to the end of the neonatal period. It can be focal clonic, focal tonic, myoclonic seizure, or epileptic spasm. 

 A focal clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups of the limbs, face, or trunk, and-

  • Maybe unifocal or multifocal.
  • May occur synchronously or asynchronously in muscle groups on one side of the body
  • May occur simultaneously but asynchronously on both sides.
  • It cannot be suppressed by restraint.
  • Focal clonic seizures may be unifocal, confined to specific muscle groups including those of the proximal or distal limbs, trunk or neck, or regions of the face
  • These seizures may migrate from one region to another according to traditional Jacksonian features

Video-EEG is the gold standard for diagnosis and quantification of seizures in neonates. The diagnosis is based on clinical observation combined with EEG monitoring

Magnetic resonance imaging (option C) is a preferred modality to evaluate for evidence of hypoxic-ischemic injury, intracranial hemorrhage, ischemic stroke, or brain malformations

Genetic testing for evidence of KCNQ2 (Option D) mutations is positive in a large majority of patients. It also helps in specific treatments for some associated syndromes. 

Computed tomography (Option A) is generally avoided in neonates since MRI provides superior resolution with no exposure to ionizing radiation. 

WHO recommendation:

  • Clinically apparent seizures in the neonate should be treated if they last >3 minutes or are brief serial seizures.
  • If electroencephalography (EEG) is possible, all electrical seizures should also be treated, even in the absence of clinically apparent conditions.
  • In all neonates with seizures, hypoglycemia, CNS infection, and hypocalcemia should be ruled out before anti-epileptic drug treatment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady with a known case of hypothyroidism presents with pain and burning of the lateral half of the palm. On examination, her palms appear as shown below and Phalen's test is positive. What is the likely structure under which the affected nerve is compressed?
questions.solution:
The image shows atrophy of thenar eminence as seen in carpal tunnel syndrome. It is due to compression of the median nerve where it passes under the flexor retinaculum in the wrist.

Patients present with pain and paresthesia over the distribution of the median nerve. There may be a weakness of thumb opposition. In chronic cases, the thenar eminence is wasted.

Tinel's sign will be positive. This sign is elicited by percussing over the median nerve, reproducing symptoms. In Phalen's test,  the symptoms are reproduced by holding the wrists in full flexion for 60 seconds.

Carpal tunnel syndrome can be associated with rheumatoid arthritis, pregnancy, chronic renal failure, acromegaly, hypothyroidism, and gout. The diagnosis is usually made on clinical grounds but nerve conduction studies can confirm the diagnosis.

The following image shows Phalen's test.

Other options 

Option A- Ligament of Struthers connects the medial epicondyle and the humerus. It is associated with pronator syndrome due to the involvement of the median nerve and produces similar symptoms as carpal tunnel syndrome. However, Phalen's test is negative.

Option B- Bicipital aponeurosis is the insertion of the biceps in the cubital fossa. It is also associated with pronator syndrome due to the involvement of the median nerve. Phalen's test is negative.

Option C- Guyon's canal: The ulnar nerve can get compressed while passing through Guyon's canal.

questions.text: You are a medical practitioner in a remote rural area. You remove a Guinea worm from a patient by rolling it over a stick as shown below. The intermediate host of this parasite is also implicated in which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the way Guinea worm (Dracunculiasis) is removed by rolling them out over a small stick. It is transmitted by the cyclops which also serves as the intermediate host for Diphyllobothrium latum/fish tapeworm.

Dracunculiasis/Guinea worm disease is a vector-borne parasitic disease caused by Dracunculus medinensis. Transmission occurs by consumption of water containing cyclops harbouring infective stages of the parasite. This disease is totally a water-based disease and has no alternate way of transmission.

Life cycle of Dracunculus medinensis/Gunea worm :

Treatment:

  • No drug cures the infection 
  • Worms are removed by sequentially rolling them out over a small stick.
  • A simple surgical procedure can be done to remove the worm.
  • Topical antibiotics may be used to limit bacterial superinfection

Life cycle of fish tapeworm :

Diphyllobothrium latum requires 3 hosts – definitive host: man; first intermediate host: cyclops; and second intermediate host: cyclops and fish. The infective form to humans is the third stage plerocercoid larvae. It possesses a rudimentary scolex.

They are known to cause deficiency of vitamin B12 (Bothriocephalus anemia). The anemia develops because the tapeworm absorbs a large quantity of Vitamin B12 and interferes with its ileal absorption leading to Vitamin B12 deficiency. In severe cases, patients may exhibit neurologic sequelae of vitamin B12 deficiency.

Treatment for  Diphyllobothrum latum infection is Praziquantel.

Other options :

Option A: Hymenolepis nana is the only cestode that completes its life cycle in a single host. There is no intermediate host.

Option C: Multiceps multiceps/Taenia Multiceps is a cestode that has dogs as its primary host and sheep and rodents serve as the intermediate hosts.

Option D: Schistosoma haematobium / blood fluke completes its life cycle with freshwater snails are intermediate hosts.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman was diagnosed with right leg cellulitis and was admitted to the hospital for 3 days. She was prescribed clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, she developed diarrhea and abdominal pain. Her temperature was 38.8 degrees Celcius. Her blood reports are given below. What is the most probable etiological agent?
  • Hemoglobin- 12 g/dL
  • WBC count of 18,000/mm3
  • CRP of 160 mg/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with hospital-acquired diarrhea (nosocomial) following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridium difficile. 

Clostridium difficile is the most common cause of infectious diarrhea in nosocomial infection. 

It is the most common antibiotic-associated diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to colonization of C. difficile.

Clinical features:

  • Lower abdominal pain with loose watery diarrhea.
  • Fever, leukocytosis
  • In some patients, the disease may progress to life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis

Investigations:

  • Nucleic acid amplification tests, including polymerase chain reaction assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool 
  • Stool culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating toxin by cell cytotoxin cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy reveals a characteristic pseudomembrane.

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool, have now been approved for diagnostic purposes and appear to be both rapid and sensitive while retaining high specificity.

Oral vancomycin, metronidazole, and fidaxomicin are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

First choice treatment of C. difficile colitis:

Severity Treatment
Mild to moderate Oral vancomycin OR fidaxomicin
Severe (WBC >15,000/cu.mm, Creatinine >1.5 times baseline) Oral vancomycin OR fidaxomicin
Severe, complicated (shock, ileus, toxic megacolon) Oral vancomycin + IV metronidazole ± Rectal vancomycin
Recurrent/ multiple episodes Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT)

Recent update: Harrison's 20th edition recommends the use of vancomycin over metronidazole in the treatment of initial episodes which are mild to moderate in severity. Metronidazole is recommended only if vancomycin or fidaxomicin is not accessible. Oral metronidazole is less effective than the other options and may necessitate a longer treatment course for a response.

Other options: Escherichia coli, Norovirus, Rotavirus are all causes of Traveller's diarrhea.

Other causes of Nosocomial diarrhea:

  • Clostridium perfringens,
  • Klebsiella oxytoca,
  • Staphylococcus aureus.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the medicine OPD with complaints of muscle weakness and blurring of vision following exertion. On examination, the patient had ptosis. What is the drug that can be used in the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Edrophonium, a short-acting anticholinesterase agent is used for diagnosing myasthenia gravis. It is also called the tensilon test.

Initially, 2 mg is administered. If improvements of symptoms do not occur within 45 seconds, an additional 8 mg can be administered. Improvement of strength unaccompanied by lingual fasciculations (generally present in non-myasthenics) is a positive test.

Edrophonium is short-acting because:

  • The binding site of edrophonium to acetylcholine esterase - choline subsite of the active center
  • No reaction with the enzyme - reversible binding only
  • Quaternary structure - rapid elimination

Note: An excessive dose of anti-cholinesterase drugs results in a cholinergic crisis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is admitted for multiple skin infections. He also has a history of recurrent bouts of infections with catalase-positive microorganisms such as Staphylococcus aureus, Burkholderia,  and Aspergillus. The nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient has chronic granulomatous disease which occurs due to the defect in NADPH oxidase.

The child has had recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms and has a defect in generating oxygen radicals intracellularly in his phagocytic cells (the negative nitroblue tetrazolium test). This interferes with the killing of bacteria by the oxidative burst. 

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is an inherited defect in microbiocidal activity. In this condition, there is a failure in the formation of reactive oxygen species due to defective phagocytes NADPH oxidase. This leads to the phagocytic inability to kill specific microbes.

Catalase is an enzyme that inactivates hydrogen peroxide. When these patients are infected with catalase-negative organisms, the patient's immune system can use hydrogen peroxide produced by the organism to create reactive oxygen species. However, in catalase-positive organisms, the hydrogen peroxide produced is rapidly destroyed by catalase, and therefore, the patient's immune response cannot use it to produce reactive oxygen species. Thus, most patients present with pneumonia due to catalase-positive organisms like Staphylococcus aureus, Burkholderia cepacia, Serratia marcescens, Nocardia, and Aspergillus species. 

Patients have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections. The symptoms begin within the first two years of life, affecting the pulmonary, gastrointestinal, skin, and lymphatic drainage of these organs. 

Nitroblue tetrazolium is used as a diagnostic test.

Other options:

Option A - X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia is characterized by the failure of B-cell maturation. It is associated with mutations in a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase called Bruton tyrosine kinase (Btk). Patients have decreased levels of B cells. They have recurrent infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, or Staphylococcus aureus.

Option B - Leukocyte adhesion defect leads to an inability of the leukocytes to migrate to the site of infection. There are two types. Type 1 occurs due to a defect in the β2 chain present in integrins LFA-1 and Mac-1. Type 2 occurs due to the absence of sialyl-Lewis X.  Both of these present with recurrent bacterial infections.

Option C - Job syndrome is characterized by atopic dermatitis, recurrent skin staphylococcal infections, and recurrent pulmonary infections. It is also known as hyper-IgE syndrome.

questions.text: Mr.Rajesh presents with complaints of hyperacusis after a surgical procedure. Which of the following nerves could be responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The facial nerve, marked as 3 in the image could be responsible for hyperacusis.

The tensor tympani and the stapedius are the muscles of the middle ear and they are innervated by branches of V and VII cranial nerves respectively. Both these muscles contract in response to loud noises and thereby dampen the sound. The tensor tympani increases the tension of the tympanic membrane and reduces the force of vibration. Stapedius pulls the stapes posteriorly and reduces the oscillations.

Paralysis of the stapedius causes increased sensitivity to the sounds, a condition known as hyperacusis.

  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: At a screening camp for coronary heart disease, four individuals are identified as having certain risk factors. Who among them is at the lowest risk for developing this disease?

choices.text: A person with type B personality
An obese person with sedentary lifestyle
A person with type A personality

questions.solution:
A person with a type B personality has the least risk of developing coronary heart disease (CHD). Patients with a type A personality, obesity, sedentary lifestyles, and/or a history of diabetes mellitus are at a greater risk of developing CHD.

Type A personality is associated with competitiveness, restlessness, hostility, and a sense of urgency or impatience. These individuals are more prone to CHD than the Type B personality which is calmer, and more philosophical.

Risk factors for coronary heart disease are modifiable and non-modifiable:

  • Modifiable:
    • Cigarette smoking
    • High blood pressure
    • Elevated serum cholesterol level
    • Diabetes
    • Obesity
    • Sedentary habits
    • Stress
  • Non-modifiable:
    • Age
    • Sex
    • Family history
    • Genetic factors
    • Personality

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Atherosclerosis

  • Genetic abnormalities
  • Family history
  • Increasing age
  • Male gender

Modifiable:

  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hypertension
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Diabetes

questions.text: An epidemiologist has to survey an area for conducting a sterilization program. He is plotting a population pyramid of the area. Identify the false statement regarding population pyramids.

choices.text: They show the distribution of ages across a population
They can be used to compare the male and female populations
Youngest of the population is represented at the bottom
Narrow base and wide middle are typical of developing countries

questions.solution:
Population pyramids of developing countries show a broad base and a tapering top. Hence, option D is false.

Population pyramids of developed countries typically show a narrow base and wide middle.

A population pyramid is a graphical representation of the age and sex of the population; therefore, it is also called an age and sex pyramid.

The youngest of the population is represented at the bottom and the oldest at the top of the pyramid.

Besides showing the distribution of ages across a population, the pyramid is divided across the center to separate the male and female members of the population; therefore, it can be used to compare the difference between the male and female populations of a given area.

It also shows the number of dependents in the population at any given time.

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with an unsteady gait, forgetfulness, and labile moods.  Physical examination is remarkable for the ocular Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring and examination findings as shown below. Which of the following options correctly indicate the gene most likely mutated in this condition and its location?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Wilson's disease. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder is caused by a mutation in the ATP7B gene located on chromosome 13.

The ATP7B gene encodes a transmembrane copper-transporting ATPase, expressed on the hepatocyte canalicular membrane. In Wilson disease, there is a deficiency in the ATP7B protein. This causes a decrease in copper excretion into the bile, impairs its incorporation into ceruloplasmin, and inhibits ceruloplasmin secretion into the blood, leading to the accumulation of toxic levels of copper in the liver, brain, and eye.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing beating tremor(shown in the gif in question)- It is a low‐frequency, high‐amplitude, tremor, elicited by sustained abduction of the arms, with flexed elbows and palms facing downwards.
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring - It is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea

The image below shows the ocular KF ring.

 

Diagnosis:

    • Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

Treatment: Trientine and zinc are the first choice of drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

Note: 

Menkes disease is an X-linked metabolic disturbance of copper metabolism caused by mutations in the copper-transporting ATP7A gene.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with compensated cirrhosis is being posted for a liver transplantation. As an anesthetist on duty, which of the following induction agents will you use?
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane and isoflurane are commonly used for induction in patients with liver disease.

Hepatic arterial blood flow is reduced in cirrhosis. Sevoflurane and isoflurane are known to maintain hepatic blood flow and improve oxygen delivery to the liver.

Sevoflurane due to its nonpungency and rapid onset makes it an excellent choice for smooth and rapid inhalation inductions in pediatric and adult patients.

Compound A is the nephrotoxic end product formed by the interaction of sevoflurane with CO2-absorbent soda lime. Accumulation of this product occurs on long-duration anesthesia, high sevoflurane concentrations, and dry barium hydroxide absorbent.

Other options-

Option (A): Methoxyflurane is a hepatotoxic and highly nephrotoxic drug. Its use gradually declined after the 1970s. 

Option (B): Thiopentone, also known as thiopental, is a barbiturate that is excreted primarily via the liver. Hence, it would lead to toxicity is used in patients with liver disease.

Option (D): Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic agent that accumulates in the liver and undergoes rapid metabolism. It is also known to cause hepatotoxicity which presents as an elevation in liver enzymes. These two reasons make ketamine unsuitable for use in patients with liver disease.

questions.text: What is the pathological mechanism responsible for the RBC shape shown in this peripheral smear?

choices.text: Mutations in genes encoding for ankyrin, spectrin, and band proteins
Acquired mutation in the PIGA gene
Point mutation in the beta-globin gene

questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows bite cells or degmacytes, characteristically associated with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD deficiency), an X-linked recessive condition.

Reduced glutathione is required to protect the cells against oxidant injury. This glutathione is kept in a reduced state by NADPH. Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is required to generate NADPH while oxidizing glucose-6-phosphate. G6PD deficiency results in reduced levels of NADPH which subsequently reduces the level of reduced glutathione. Therefore, in conditions like infections, which increase the production of oxygen free radicals, the red blood cells are damaged. 

Other triggers that lead to oxidative stress are drugs like sulphonamides, antimalarials, and fava beans.

Increased oxidative damage to RBCs leads to the formation of denatured precipitates known as Heinz bodies. These bodies can damage the RBC membrane leading to intravascular hemolysis. Additionally, when such RBCs pass through the splenic cords, macrophages pluck out these precipitates, giving them the characteristic appearance of bite cells. 

Other features of the peripheral smear include anisocytes, polychromatic cells, and poikilocytes with unevenly distributed hemoglobin (hemighosts). 

Other options:

Option A: Mutations in the genes coding for ankyrin, spectrin, and band proteins are responsible for hereditary spherocytosis (HS). It is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by poor interaction between the mutated RBC membrane proteins. This leads to the loss of membrane fragments relative to the cytoplasm, thereby causing the RBC to assume the least possible diameter for a given volume. Peripheral smear shows characteristic spherocytes that appear dark, with no central pallor. Howell- Jolly bodies can also be seen.

A slide showing spherocytes in peripheral smear:

 

Option B: Acquired mutation of PIGA gene is responsible for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). This condition causes complement-mediated destruction of RBCs due to the absence/ impaired production of membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins CD59 and CD55. PNH is characterized by a triad of hemolysis, pancytopenia, and venous thrombosis. The peripheral smear reveals RBCs that are usually normo-macrocytic but may become microcytic due to chronic iron loss through hemoglobinuria. 

Option C: Point mutation in the beta-globin gene is responsible for sickle cell anemia. This autosomal recessive disorder is characterized by the polymerization of the abnormal HbS hemoglobin during conditions of low oxygen tension (acidosis, hypoxia) which leads to sickling of the red blood cell, hemolysis, and microvascular obstruction (may lead to vaso-occlusive crises and autosplenectomy). Peripheral smear findings reveal sickled RBCs, reticulocytosis, and Howell-Jolly bodies (small nuclear remnants in RBCs that are usually removed by a functional spleen). 

A slide showing sickled RBCs in a peripheral smear:

2. Based on the sites of hemolysis:

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with a 2-week history of vulval swelling with increasing pain and fever for the past two days. Local examination revealed a right-sided erythematous, tender swelling on the posterior half of the labium majus similar to that seen in the image given below. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Involved structure is homologous to male glands of Littre.
Biopsy should be done in elderly with recurrence.

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of infection of the Bartholin gland i.e. Bartholin abscess. Bartholin glands are not homologous to the male glands of Littre.

Bartholin glands are the homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. The ducts of these glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. These glands are stimulated by sexual arousal. Contraction of the bulbospongiosus muscle expresses gland secretions. The glands contain columnar cells that secrete mucus with lubricant properties.  

The male glands of Littre are homologous to mucous secreting periurethral glands in females.

Clinical conditions associated with the Bartholin gland are Bartholin cyst and Bartholin abscess. The cyst is caused by obstruction of the Bartholin ducts by proteinaceous material or by inflammation due to infection. An infected Bartholin cyst can lead to an abscess.

These infections commonly involve the duct and are most commonly sexually transmitted. It is generally polymicrobial. (Option A)Bacteroides species, Peptostreptococcus species, Escherichia coli, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae are frequently encountered in the culture of purulent drainage. Less often, Chlamydia trachomatis may be identified.

Larger cysts can cause vaginal discomfort and dyspareunia. Abscesses will show erythema with tenderness. The cystic swelling and the abscess are both fluctuant. Bartholin cysts are transilluminating due to the clear fluid they contain. 

Treatment:

  • Analgesics for pain
  • Antibiotic for combating infections.
  • Specific treatment:
    1. Drainage under anesthesia: Generally conservative method, chances of re-infection and formation of granulation tissue can happen.
    2. Marsupialization Complete excision of sac and cyst along with drainage of the substance. The edges are also clearly approximated. This is the ideal management. (Option C) The advantages of marsupialization over other methods include:
      • Simple procedure
      • Can be done even under local anesthesia.
      • Shorter hospital stay (24 hours).
      • The postoperative complication is almost nil.
      • Gland function (moisture) remains intact. 
    3. Incision and drainage with Word catheter placement: A deflated Word catheter is used to tuck the vagina here and prevent it from damage that can happen during movement of the perineum and thus avert re-infection and granulation tissue formation. Alternatively, a 14 F foley catheter can also be used.
    4. Bartholinectomy: This is a very invasive surgery and carries a greater morbidity profile. This is also associated with loss of lubricant function. 

In older women with recurrent Bartholin cyst, a suspicion of Bartholin gland cancer should arise and the cyst wall should be sent for biopsy. (Option D)

questions.text: An autopsy is done on a plastic factory worker. The gross specimen of the liver is shown in the image below. Reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces (arrows) are present. The asterisk marks the normal liver tissue. Which of the following compounds is most likely to have played a role in the pathogenesis of the involved tumor?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen of the liver shows greyish-white lesions, with multiple reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces (arrows) which are seen with hepatic angiosarcoma. Exposure to polyvinyl chloride, arsenic, and thorotrast can lead to this condition.

Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm that has equal gender predilection. The tumor may occur at any site, but most often involves skin, soft tissue, breast, and liver. They are locally invasive and can readily metastasize.

Hepatic angiosarcomas are associated with exposure to carcinogens.

Examples of carcinogenic agents:

  • Arsenic - in pesticides
  • Thorotrast - a radioactive contrast agent formerly used for radiologic imaging
  • Polyvinyl chloride - a widely used plastic

Hepatic tumors and associated agents

Carcinoma

Carcinogens

Hepatocellular adenoma

Oral contraceptives, anabolic steroids

Hepatocellular carcinoma 

Alcohol, thorotrast

Cholangiocarcinoma

Thorotrast

Angiosarcoma

Thorotrast, vinyl chloride, Arsenic

The given histopathological image shows abundant small blood vessels lined by large atypical endothelial cells and atypical mitoses seen in angiosarcoma. The endothelial origin of these tumors can be demonstrated by immunohistochemical staining for CD31 or von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: Which of the following patients requires antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent infective endocarditis?

choices.text: A 28-year-old man with successful repair of a cyanotic congenital heart defect 26 years ago, undergoing tooth extraction
A 30-year-old woman with a prosthetic aortic valve, undergoing replantation of the avulsed teeth
A 50-year-old woman who received a prosthetic mitral valve one year ago undergoing a screening colonoscopy
A 23-year-old man with no history of cardiovascular disease undergoing routine dental cleaning

questions.solution:
A prosthetic heart valve is one of the indications for antibiotic prophylaxis in patients undergoing dental procedures.

The American Heart Association and European Cardiac Society have recommended antibiotic prophylaxis for patients undergoing invasive dental procedures that involve the manipulation of gingival tissue or periapical region or perforation of the oral mucosa when performed on patients with high-risk cardiac lesions.

Some invasive dental procedures:

  • Tooth extraction
  • Periodontal surgery, subgingival scaling, and root planing
  • Replantation of avulsed teeth
  • Other surgical procedures such as implant placement or apicoectomy

High-risk cardiac lesions:

  • Prosthetic heart valves or prosthetic material used for valve repair    
  • History of endocarditis
  • Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, including palliative shunts or conduits.
  • Completely repaired congenital heart defects during the first 6 months after repair.
  • Incompletely repaired congenital heart disease with residual shunt or valvular regurgitation
  • Surgical or transcatheter pulmonary artery valve or conduit placement.
  • Valvulopathy developing after cardiac transplantation (recommended only by the American Heart Association)

Antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended for patients undergoing gastrointestinal or genitourinary procedures; however, if there is a genitourinary tract infection, the infection is to be treated prior to the procedure.

Other options:

Option A: Antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated if the invasive dental procedure is done only within 6 months of complete repair. As the patient has undergone successful repair of the defect 26 years ago, antibiotic prophylaxis is not needed.

Option C: Antibiotic prophylaxis is not required for a screening colonoscopy (gastrointestinal procedure).

Option D: Dental cleaning does not routinely need antibiotic prophylaxis in patients without a history of cardiac disease.

Related Pearl: Cardiac conditions requiring antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis

High risk cardiac conditions for development of Infective endocarditis and require antibiotic prophylaxis are:

  • Prosthetic valves
  • History of infective endocarditis
  • Few congenital heart diseases which include:
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD, including palliative shunts and conduit
    • Completely repaired congenital heart defect with prosthetic material or device, whether placed by surgery or by catheter intervention, during the first 6 months after the procedure
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects at the site or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
  • Cardiac transplantation recipients with cardiac valvular disease

questions.text: A teenage girl is brought in for evaluation of truncal asymmetry. The findings of the physical examination and x-ray imaging are shown in the image below. Which of the following radiological signs could be helpful in assessing skeletal maturity in such cases?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with the image showing a positive Adams (forward bend) test and lateral curvature of the spine seen on the radiograph, is suggestive of scoliosis. Risser's sign evaluates skeletal maturation using the ossification of the iliac apophysis in the evaluation of scoliosis. 

Risser's sign

The iliac apophysis is divided into four quadrants. Ossification of iliac apophyses normally proceeds from the lateral to the medial side and from the anterior superior iliac spine to the posterior superior iliac spine. The Risser grades correspond to the degree of ossification, ranging from grade 0 (no ossification) to grade 4 (ossification of all four quadrants). When the apophysis has fused completely with the ilium, ossification is graded as Risser grade 5 and the patient is considered skeletally mature. 

Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS)

AIS is the most common type of scoliosis and develops in children over the age of 10 years until they reach skeletal maturity. It is asymptomatic and usually identified on routine physical examination. The spine may have obviously deviated from the mid-line or a prominence may become apparent when the patient bends forward (the Adams test).

Confirmation of the diagnosis is through full-length lateral and PA x-rays. A Cobb angle of >10° is diagnostic. It is a measure of the degree of curvature using projected lines from the top of the uppermost and bottom of the lowermost vertebral bodies.

Use in scoliosis: Risser's grade 5 (fusion with the ilium) corresponds to the fusion of the apophysis in the vertebral ring. Once this occurs, there is no possibility of further progression of the scoliosis curve.

Other options - 

Option B - Lasegue's sign or straight leg raising test (SLRT) is used to diagnose radicular pain.

Option C - Kanavel's sign comprises the four cardinal signs of flexor tendon sheath infection:

  • Finger held in slight flexion
  • Uniform swelling of the digit
  • Tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath
  • Pain with passive extension of the digit

Option D - Froment's sign is used to test for ulnar nerve palsy. Abnormality is present when there is an inability to hold a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger of the affected hand as the examiner tries to pull it away.

questions.text: Which of the following studies shown in the image below is performed for peptic ulcers?
questions.solution:
Peptic ulcers can be visualized using barium meal study. This investigation is depicted in image 2- showing contrast medium filling the stomach and duodenum.

Barium meal study is employed in conditions like gastric and peptic ulcers and gastric outlet obstruction.

Other options:

Image one shows a normal barium enema study. It is used in conditions like acute colitis, colonic fistula, colorectal cancer, ileocaecal tuberculosis, ulcerative colitis and ileocolic intussusception.

 

Image 3 is a barium swallow study in a case of eosinophilic esophagitis used to visualize the esophagus. It is used for the diagnosis of conditions like achalasia cardia, diffuse esophageal spasm, hiatus hernia, Zenker's diverticulum, esophageal webs, eosinophilic esophagitis, etc.

 

Image 4 shows a normal barium meal follow-through study which is performed for conditions like strictures, diverticula, masses and small bowel obstructions.

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used)

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum. (95% BaSO4 is used)

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine (25% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male patient recently diagnosed with renal vein thrombosis is being evaluated. He had past history of weight gain, generalized edema, and hypertension. Urinary examination shows gross proteinuria and the presence of multiple RBCs with normal morphology and no casts. Anti-PLA2R antibodies are present. Which of the following is likely to be seen on renal biopsy in this patient?

GBM - Glomerular basement membrane

choices.text: Diffuse thickening of the GBM with spike and dome pattern

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of nephrotic syndrome. Anti PLA2R antibodies are seen in membranous nephropathy which is seen as diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) on light microscopy examination. On electron microscopy, there are irregular spikes protruding from the GBM.

Membranous nephropathy is characterized by nephrotic syndrome and proteinuria. It occurs due to the accumulation of deposits containing immunoglobulins along the subepithelial portion of the glomerular basement membrane. Most of the cases (75%) are primary and are linked to an autoimmune phenomenon. The remaining are associated with the following: 

  • Drugs - Penicillamine, captopril, gold, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
  • Underlying malignancies like carcinoma of the lung, colon, melanoma
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Infections such as chronic hepatitis B and C, syphilis
  • Autoimmune conditions like thyroiditis

M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) antibodies are seen in the majority of these cases. 

Membranous nephropathy can present with insidious onset of nephrotic syndrome or a hypercoagulable state such as pulmonary embolism, renal vein thrombosis, deep venous thrombosis, and symptoms of heart failure. The hypercoagulable state occurs due to the loss of antithrombin 3 from the urine.

On light microscopy, the glomeruli may be normal or have a uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. Electron microscopy will reveal spike and dome patterns. Immunofluorescence microscopy demonstrates that the granular deposits contain both immunoglobulins and complement.

The image below shows the light microscopic findings in membranous nephropathy.

Other options:

Options B and D- Tram-track appearance of the glomerular basement membrane and large and hypercellular glomeruli are seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. It presents as nephrotic syndrome and along with features of nephritic component manifested by hematuria or as mild proteinuria.

Option C- Mesangial deposition of IgA is seen in IgA nephropathy (Berger disease).

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old post-menopausal woman with a family history of breast cancer presents with persistent lower backache. Her bone mineral density is measured, and the T-score is -2.6. She is prescribed raloxifene. Which of the following effects of this drug should the patient be informed about?
questions.solution:
This post-menopausal patient with a family history of breast cancer, with osteoporosis (low back pain, a T-score of -2.6), has been recommended to take raloxifene. Raloxifene causes a 3-fold increase in deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) with the following actions-

Agonist actions:

  • Bone: Increases bone mineral density and reduces the risk of vertebral fractures
  • Lipids: Reduces total cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein. However, it does not increase HDL cholesterol.
  • Increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. 

Antagonist action:

  • Breast: Incidence of breast carcinoma is reduced (option D). Raloxifene has an antiproliferative effect on ER-positive breast tumors and significantly reduces the risk of ER-positive but not ER-negative breast cancer.
  • Uterus: does not stimulate endometrial proliferation (option B)

Note: Raloxifene does not help with vasomotor symptoms, and some people might experience hot flashes (option A).

SERM Effect on breast  Effect on endometrium Effect on bone
Tamoxifen Inhibits proliferation Stimulates proliferation Antiresorptive
Raloxifene Inhibits proliferation Inhibits proliferation Antiresorptive

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

Risk factor for osteoporosis
Low BMI
Family history of osteoporosis
