Previous fragility fracture
Chronic use of glucocorticoids
Family history of hip fractures
Smoking and alcohol intake
Drugs like anticonvulsants, anticoagulants and thyroid replacement therapy
Hyperparathyroidism, multiple myeloma, and malabsorption syndrome

questions.text: A newborn child presents with the following finding in the right eye as shown in the image below. The left eye is normal. What is the ideal age to take this patient up for elective surgery?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dense unilateral congenital cataract. Ideally, unilateral dense cataract merits urgent surgery and it is at 6 weeks when elective surgery should be performed.

Generally, it is not advisable to operate on lamellar cataracts until the child is 1 or preferably 2 years old. But when the lens is completely opaque, or the pupil will not dilate, and when squint or nystagmus is developing, it is wise to operate at an earlier age. Moreover, the results of surgery in unilateral cataracts in children are universally poor, unless the operation is carried out within the first 6 weeks of birth.

This is because the critical period for developing the fixation reflex in both unilateral and bilateral visual deprivation disorders is between 2 and 4 months of age. Thus, any cataract dense enough to impair vision must be dealt with before this age and the earliest possible time is preferred. 

Surgery involves anterior capsulorhexis, aspiration of lens matter, capsulorhexis of the posterior capsule, limited anterior vitrectomy, and IOL implantation, if appropriate. It is important to correct associated refractive errors.

Related Pearl: Types of Congenital Cataract

Punctate cataract: Blue-dot cataract, most common congenital cataract

 

Zonular/Lamellar cataract: Most common congenital cataract with diminished vision; Spokes of a wheel appearance (Rider’s Cataract) A, B, and C

 

Fusiform/coralliform cataract: Anteroposterior spindle shaped appearance. 

 

Nuclear cataract: Most common type of cataract seen in congenital rubella syndrome

 

Coronary cataract: Appears as a corona of club-shaped opacities near the periphery of the lens.

 

Anterior polar cataract: May arise either due to delayed development of anterior chamber or due to corneal perforation

 

Posterior polar cataract: Progressive form of posterior polar cataract, which typically shows an "onion whorl appearance"

questions.text: Given below is an image of the oldest non-service type of latrines in India. The incorrect statement regarding the same is:

choices.text: Fly breeding is common and the soiled mass is a source of infection
It is a bore-hole latrine introduced to combat hookworm infections.
This type of latrine is dug using an equipment called auger
No staff needed for upkeep as the used one is closed, another one is dug elsewhere

questions.solution:
The image is of a borehole latrine and the incorrect statement is that fly breeding is common and the soiled mass is a source of infection. (Option A is incorrect)

The forerunner of non-service type of latrines in India is the borehole latrine and was introduced in the 1930s to combat hookworm infections. Special equipment called auger is used to dig a borehole latrine.

Advantages

  • No special staff is needed for upkeep as after using the latrine is closed and another hole is dug elsewhere
  • As the pit is dark, the breeding of flies is less. Anaerobic digestion of the nightsoil converts it into a harmless mass
  • No water pollution when located far from a water source.

Demerits:

  • It fills up rapidly
  • Augers may not be readily available
  • Difficulty in digging deeper holes in areas of loose soil and high subsoil water levels

questions.text: A young man presents with intermittent episodes of vertigo, lasting for a few hours, over three weeks. He also complains of ringing and fullness in his right ear. Rinne's test is positive bilaterally and the Weber test shows lateralization to the left ear. He works at a car showroom and has episodes of vertigo when the cars honk too loudly. This symptom is best described as:
questions.solution:
This symptom is best described as the Tullio phenomenon.

Tullio phenomenon describes the vertiginous episodes associated with exposure to loud noise in a patient with Meniere's disease. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Meniere's disease (MD) or endolymphatic hydrops is a disorder of the inner ear caused by impaired endolymph resorption. It is characterized by an episodic sudden onset of vertigo, low-frequency hearing loss (in the early stages of the disorder), low-frequency roaring tinnitus, and sensation of fullness in the affected ear.

The treatment of Meniere's disease includes:

  • General measures like cessation of smoking, a low salt diet and avoiding excessive intake of water, lifestyle changes to avoid stress and avoiding activities like scuba diving which require good body balance
  • Management of an acute attack by the administration of intravenous fluids and electrolytes, vestibular sedatives like promethazine, dimenhydrinate and prochlorperazine, vasodilators like carbogen that also improve labyrinthine circulation, diazepam to suppress the activity of medial vestibular nucleus and bed rest.
  • Management of chronic phase by administration of vasodilators like betahistine that increase labyrinthine blood flow, vestibular sedatives like prochlorperazine, diuretics such as furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide to control recurrent attacks and propantheline bromide, an anticholinergic agent. Chemical labyrinthectomy by intratympanic gentamicin therapy is also done.
  • Surgical treatment by conservative procedures like decompression of endolymphatic sac, endolymphatic shunt operation, sacculotomy or Fick's operation, the section of vestibular nerve and destruction of the vestibular labyrinth by ultrasound. Destructive procedures like labyrinthectomy are done when the cochlear function is not serviceable. Intermittent low-pressure pulse therapy, also known as Meniett device therapy helps relieve the symptoms.

Other options- 

Option A: Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. 

Option C: Lermoyez syndrome includes symptoms of Meniere's disease seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.

Option D: Vestibular hydrops includes typical episodes of vertigo while cochlear function remaining intact.

questions.text: For the engineering team project, Mr. X and Mr. Y were paired up. Mr. X, who is generally a lonely person,  requested a change of partner. When the tutor asked for an explanation for requesting this change, Mr. X replied, 'Mr. Y wants to be left alone.' Which of the following defense mechanisms best explains Mr. X's response?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, Mr. X's response can be best explained by the defense mechanism of projection. Projection is when you attribute your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings to someone else.

Mr. X is projecting his wishes by stating that Mr. Y wants to be left alone when in reality it is he who wants to be left alone. Mr. X could have probably done this because of severe prejudice against Mr. Y, or because he senses danger or a bad outcome when paired with Mr. Y. 

Other options-

Option (A): Rationalization is making excuses for your behavior. Had that been the answer, he would have made excuses, such as he’s uncomfortable with Mr. Y. 

Option (C): Displacement would have been the correct answer if Mr. X had shouted at Mr. Y for the tutor having paired them together. Displacement is the shifting of emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

Option (D): Repression refers to subconsciously forgetting something. The scenario does not convey this mechanism.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms that operate in various diseases

  • OCD - reaction formation, undoing
  • Phobia - displacement
  • Neurosis - repression
  • Grief - denial
  • Borderline personality - Splitting
  • Schizophrenia - projection
  • Enuresis - Regression

questions.text: An elderly man presented with language deficits, loss of mathematical skills and motor skills. His family reports that his symptoms began many years ago with forgetfulness and memory disturbances. He is now apathetic, withdrawn, agitated, and is prone to wandering. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an elderly male with forgetfulness, memory disturbances, language deficits, loss of mathematical skills and motor skills, apathy, withdrawal, agitation, and wandering is likely to have Alzheimer's disease. Spongiform transformation of the cerebral cortex is seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. 

Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. Its incidence increases with age. It has an insidious onset with deficits developing over the course of 5-10 years. Initially, the patient presents with forgetfulness but then progresses to language deficits, loss of mathematical skills, and motor skills. In the end stages, the patient becomes mute, incontinent, unable to walk. They usually develop pneumonia. 

The pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease involves the accumulation of Aβ amyloid and tau in the brain. The hallmarks of this condition are amyloid plaques comprised of aggregated Aβ amyloid and neurofibrillary tangles. Neurofibrillary tangles are the cytoplasmic accumulation of tau filaments. Neuritic plaques are focal collections of axonal or dendritic processes around a central amyloid core. In pyramidal neurons, they appear as flame-shaped. These lesions lead to neuronal death. 

On gross examination, the brain shows cortical atrophy which can be seen with gyral narrowing and sulcal widening in the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes. This will lead to compensatory enlargement of the ventricles. 

The following image shows the neurofibrillary tangles seen in Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal care clinic at 30 weeks of gestation. You are asked to perform a detailed physical examination on her and document the findings in the case sheet. Which of the following cardiovascular findings would be specific to a pathological cardiac condition, if documented?
questions.solution:
Grade 4 early diastolic murmur documented is specific to a pathologic cardiac condition in a pregnant female. Any diastolic murmur is never a part of the physiological change in pregnancy. 

Physiological changes in pregnancy

Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)

Clinical examination

  • Pulse rate: Increases
  • Pedal edema: although it can be a sign of cardiac disease, it is also a normal physiological change in pregnancy. (Option A)
  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • Diastolic BP: Decreases
  • Jugular venous distension and venous hum
  • The heart is displaced upwards and to the left
  • Mammary soufflé: Continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
  • S1 M increased and widely split
  • S2 P increased; S2 split
  • Occasional but prominent S3 at mitral area (Option D)
  • Murmurs
    • Ejection systolic murmur at the left sternal border. (Option B)
    • Continuous murmur at 2nd-4th intercostal space (known as mammary souffle)

ECG changes

  • Left axis deviation (due to elevation of the diaphragm)
  • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement.
  • Mild ST changes in the inferior leads.
  • Premature atrial and ventricular contractions are relatively frequent.

Electrocardiography

  • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement
  • Dysrhythmias
  • As the diaphragm is elevated in advancing pregnancy, there is a left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen.
  • Atrial and ventricular premature contractions are relatively frequent
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension 
  • Increased left ventricular mass

X-ray:

X-ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex).

Clinical indicators of heart disease during the pregnancy

Symptoms:

  • Progressive dyspnea or orthopnea
  • Nocturnal cough
  • Hemoptysis
  • Syncope
  • Chest pain 

Clinical signs:

  • Cyanosis
  • Clubbing of fingers
  • Persistent neck vein distention
  • Systolic murmur grade 3/6 or greater
  • Diastolic murmur
  • Cardiomegaly
  • Persistent tachycardia and/or arrhythmia
  • Persistently split S2
  • Fourth heart sound (S4)
  • Features of pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: A 25-year-old overweight male patient was referred for the evaluation of renal stones. He complains of severe abdominal pain and urinary disturbances. His urine microscopy shows the following type of crystals and an ultrasound of the kidney revealed a renal stone of size 2.5 cm. What is the preferred treatment for this man?
questions.solution:
Urine microscopy shows hexagonal crystals, typical of cystine stones that are radio-opaque (due to high sulfur content). The preferred treatment for a cystine renal calculus of size 2.5 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) as cystine stones are relatively resistant to ESWL (extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy) due to their hardness.

PCNL is the preferred treatment for -large renal stones of a diameter of more than 1.5-2.5 cm, in the presence of multiple stones, and in cases like this patient where it is a smaller, harder stone, not responsive to ESWL (like cystine, struvite, and calcium oxalate stones). 

Technique: Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique and stones are removed.

Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include haemorrhage from the punctured renal parenchyma, perforation of the collecting system with extravasation of saline irrigant, and perforation of the colon or pleural cavity during placement of the percutaneous track. 

Cystinuria occurs due to a hereditary defect in an amino acid transporter in the renal proximal convoluted tubule and intestine. This prevents the reabsorption of amino acids like cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine. The only known complication of this disease is the formation of calculi, because of the low solubility of cystine in the urine. Cystine is more likely to precipitate in acidic urine.

Prevention of stone formation in patients with cystinuria can be done by increasing fluid intake and alkalinization of the urine with sodium bicarbonate or sodium citrate. Chelating agents such as penicillamine have also been found to be useful. Tiopronin is currently the best choice drug for cystine reduction, but side effects like nephrotic syndrome may limit its long-term use. A diet low in methionine may theoretically reduce the excretion of cystine in the urine by directly reducing its formation.

Other options-

Option (A): Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the most common method of treating urinary tract stones. Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Cystine stones which are are often multiple, and very hard are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness.

 Option (C): Open surgery- A longstanding obstructing calculus can result in chronic inflammatory change in the kidney. Open surgeries are generally indicated for xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP). Generally, in such cases, a subcapsular nephrectomy is performed. In extremely rare cases where both PCNL and ESWL are contraindicated, one might resort to open/laparoscopic surgery. 

Option (D): Ureteroscopic removal- Semi-rigid ureteroscopes are frequently used to directly visualize ureteric calculi. Advances in the design of ureterorenoscopy have made it easier to access these stones by endoscopic examination.  Stones can also be fragmented using mechanical disintegration using the lithoclast. This method is generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter.

The image below summarizes how the Dormia basket works with ureteroscopy-

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

Related Pearl: Management of renal and ureteric calculi

ESWL: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy

PCNL: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy

URS: Ureteroscopic retrieval of stones

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and barking cough for the past 5 days. Examination reveals a hoarse voice, a moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly increased respiratory rate. His chest X-ray showed subglottic narrowing appearing like a steeple. Which among the following is not indicated in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child with a barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever, and increased respiratory rate and an X-ray showing subglottic narrowing appearing like a steeple is suggestive of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis). Parenteral cefotaxime is not indicated in its treatment.

The median age for laryngotracheobronchitis is 3 months to 5 years. It is caused due to viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions. Patients present with low-grade fever,  barking cough, hoarseness of voice, and inspiratory stridor. 

The image below shows a steeple sign, seen in croup.

Treatment of croup involves:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization - It constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption from the interstitial space and reduction of edema. The indications for the administration of nebulized epinephrine are:
    • moderate to severe stridor at rest
    • the possible need for intubation
    • respiratory distress
    • hypoxia
  • Oral dexamethasone - Indicated in all the grades of croup. Corticosteroids reduce laryngeal edema through their anti-inflammatory action. IM dexamethasone and nebulized budesonide have an equal clinical effect. Corticosteroids should not be administered to children with varicella or tuberculosis as they may worsen the disease.
  • A helium-oxygen mixture (heliox) may be considered for severe croup when intubation is being considered. Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.

Most children that have croup can be managed safely at home. Indications for hospitalization:

  • Progressive stridor
  • Severe stridor at rest
  • Respiratory distress
  • Hypoxia
  • Cyanosis
  • Depressed mental status
  • Poor oral intake
  • Need for reliable observation

NOTE:

As the duration of action of racemic epinephrine is only less than 2 hours, it is mandatory to place the patient on observation for 2-3 hours to watch for the reappearance of symptoms. The patient can be discharged home if he has:

  • No stridor at rest
  • Normal air entry
  • Normal O2 saturation
  • Normal level of consciousness
  • Received steroids

questions.text: A child presents at 6 weeks of age for vaccination and the clinician decides to give a combination vaccine of diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus toxoid. How does this affect the body's immune response against tetanus toxoid compared to if it was given alone?

choices.text: Remains the same whether given alone or in combination as DTP
Decreases as the immune system is divided to make antibodies against 3 antigens instead of one
Increases as multiple antigens increases the immune response

questions.solution:
The immune response against the tetanus toxoid increases if given as a combination of DTP when compared to given singly.

Since this vaccine is given for the first time, the response to tetanus toxoid would be enhanced. If it was given to an older child with a history of other vaccinations, immune response would differ.

The immune response is variable in response to multiple antigens depending on the antigenic competition.

  • If 2 bacterial vaccines (say cholera and typhoid) are given, antibodies are produced as if they are given separately.
  • If 2 toxoids (say tetanus and diphtheria) are given with one in excess, the antibody response to the other is diminished
  • If a toxoid is given with a bacterial vaccine (say DTP vaccine), the antibody response to the toxoid is potentiated
  • If a toxoid is administered earlier (say diphtheria toxoid), and then later given as a triple vaccine (DTP), the antibody response to the pertussis and tetanus antigens will be diminished.

Other factors may also play a role in antibody response:

  • Size and number of doses - a minimum critical dose is required, to elicit a response against an antigen. It increases with an increase in dose, up to a certain point, after which it rather induces tolerance.
  • Route of administration- parenteral route induces a better antibody response compared to the oral or nasal route.

questions.text: As a public health officer, you are evaluating the implementation of the expanded program on immunization (EPI) covering 9 diseases. You assess the proportion of infants in the community who are fully immunized under this program. This is an example of:
questions.solution:
The proportion of fully immunized infants against the 9 Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI) diseases is an example of utilization rates.

Utilization of services is expressed as the proportion of people in need of a service who actually receive it in a given period. It gives an indication of the care needed and the health status of a population. The utilization rates are affected by the availability and accessibility of health services and public health awareness. 

The following are examples of utilization rates:

  • The proportion of infants immunized against 9 diseases in the expanded program on immunization (EPI)
  • The proportion of pregnant women receiving antenatal care and supervised delivery 
  • Percentage of population using family planning methods
  • Bed occupancy rate (average daily in-patient census) at a healthcare facility 
  • Average length of stay at a hospital
  • Bed turnover ratio (discharges/average beds) at a hospital

Other options:

Option A: Health care delivery indicators reflect the provision of health care and the equity of distribution of health resources in different parts of the country. Examples: Doctor- population ratio, Doctor-nurse ratio

Option B: Indicators of quality of life are difficult to define or measure. The physical quality of life index is an example that consolidates three indicators, i.e., infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy. 

Option D: Basic needs indicators are indicators involving "basic needs performance," i.e; calorie consumption, access to water, life expectancy, deaths due to disease, illiteracy, etc

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was recently diagnosed with secondary syphilis and was started on treatment. He was admitted to the hospital with complaints of fever with chills, headache, and myalgia noticed 3 days after starting treatment. His pulse rate is 92/min and his blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. What is the next line of management in this case?

choices.text: Decreasing the dose of the offending drug
Treatment with antipyretics for symptomatic relief

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of fever with chills and headache after treatment with a drug for secondary syphilis is suggestive of Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction and is associated with the use of penicillin in syphilis disease.

Symptomatic management of pyrexia with antipyretics is the next line of management. Penicillin treatment need not be interrupted during the course of the treatment and thereafter. Steroids are usually not indicated.

Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a host immune reaction due to the release of spirochetal antigen by the dying T.pallidum on treatment with penicillin. This occurs in primary and in most cases of secondary syphilis after several hours of the first dose of penicillin.

It is characterized by fever, shivering, myalgia,headache and exacerbation of lesions. Physical findings of tachycardia, increased respiratory rate and vasodilation with mild hypotension can be observed. Additionally, increased neutrophil count may be present.

The treatment of syphilis is based on the CDC’s 2015 guidelines:

questions.text: Identify the virus in the transmission cycle shown in the given image:
questions.solution:
The transmission cycle of the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus is shown in the image. 

Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission. Humans are the dead-end hosts, pigs are the amplifier hosts, and herons act as reservoir hosts. The disease is transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India)

Clinical features include high fever, headache, and vomiting. Signs of encephalitis such as convulsions, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium appear after 1-6 days. Measures like mosquito control, and locating piggeries away from houses can be done.

Inactivated vero cell culture-derived SA-14-14-2 vaccine is approved for use in India. JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunization Schedule. 

Other options:

Option-A: Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus, which is transmitted from pigs to humans. Fruit bats are the natural hosts. It causes severe encephalitis with high mortality. 

The image given below depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus:

 

Option B: Ebola virus belongs to the family Filoviridae and is transmitted by bats. Human-to-human transmission through blood or body fluids can occur. It causes fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and hemorrhage. 

The image below shows the lifecycle of the ebola virus:

 

Option D: Zika virus is transmitted to human beings by the bite of an infected Aedes mosquito. It can also be transmitted trans-placentally, causing microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the hospital after being involved in a high-speed two-wheeler motor vehicle accident. Blood-tinged fluid spontaneously drips from both nostrils which increases on leaning forward. A CT scan reveals a fracture line passing through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, the floor of the orbit, the upper part of the maxillary sinus, and the pterygoid plate. Which of the following can be used to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of a patient experiencing leakage from their nose after suffering from a Le-Fort II fracture is likely to have cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea. β-2 transferrin can be used to diagnose this condition. 

β2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for detecting CSF rhinorrhea. Since it is absent in nasal secretions it helps to differentiate CSF from nasal secretions. It is also present in aqueous humor and perilymph.

Beta trace protein is another protein that is secreted by meninges and choroid plexus and is specific for CSF, but testing facilities are not widely available.

Glucose testing by oxidase peroxidase or biochemical estimation is no longer used.

History of head trauma along with nasal discharge that shows double target sign (central red blood spot and peripheral lighter halo) on a handkerchief/tissue paper is consistent with traumatic CSF rhinorrhea.

Although the beta-2-transferrin assay may confirm the diagnosis of CSF rhinorrhea, a high-resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) is required to localize the site of the defect causing the CSF leak. 

An intrathecal fluorescein study may be performed preoperatively or intraoperatively to confirm the site of the defect. 

Early cases of post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhea are managed conservatively by placing the patient in the semi-sitting position. Blowing of nose, sneezing, and straining should be avoided. Prophylactic antibiotics can be administered to prevent meningitis. Persistent cases may be treated surgically by the intracranial or nasal endoscopic approach. Nasal endoscopic approach is useful for leaks from the frontal sinus, cribriform plate, ethmoid or sphenoid sinuses.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic with thiamine deficiency developed lactic acidosis. While on rounds, the senior resident explains the biochemical basis for the development of this condition. He says an important enzyme complex is principally affected. Which of the following is not a component of the enzyme complex being spoken of here?
questions.solution:
The enzyme complex affected in an alcoholic with lactic acidosis is the pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) enzyme complex. Pyruvate kinase is not a part of this complex. 

The three enzyme components of the PDH complex:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase
  • Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

Thiamine is a cofactor of the pyruvate dehydrogenase component of the PDH complex. In thiamine deficiency, pyruvate dehydrogenase is inhibited. Many alcoholics are thiamine deficient because of a poor diet and also because alcohol inhibits thiamine absorption. 

In the state of thiamine deficiency, there is an impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA. This results in the accumulation of pyruvate. Pyruvate then gets converted into lactate by the enzyme lactate dehydrogenase. This results in increased plasma concentrations of lactate and pyruvate, leading to a state of lactic acidosis. 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane which catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. The cofactors are:

  • Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)
  • Lipoic acid
  • Coenzyme A
  • Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)
  • Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+)

The overall reaction is given as follows: Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2

Pyruvate dehydrogenase is inhibited:

  • by its end products- acetyl CoA and NADH.
  • when there is adequate ATP available.
  • when fatty acids are being oxidized.
  • by arsenite and mercuric ions that react with the -SH groups. 
  • by a dietary deficiency of thiamine, e.g. chronic alcoholics and beriberi.

Note- Pyruvate kinase is involved in substrate-level phosphorylation to form 2× ATP per molecule of glucose oxidized. The reaction of pyruvate kinase is essentially irreversible under physiological conditions. It is involved in the regulation of glycolysis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is being evaluated for precocious puberty. Pelvic ultrasound revealed a right-sided adnexal mass. Serum inhibin levels are elevated. The patient underwent staging laparotomy to remove the tumor and the histopathological image of the tumor is shown below. What is the finding in the given slide?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing features of precocious puberty in the presence of an ovarian tumor and elevated levels of inhibin is suggestive of granulosa cell tumor, an estrogen-secreting ovarian tumor. Histopathological image is showing characteristic Call-Exner bodies.

Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The majority of the time it is seen in post-menopausal women. 

These tumors are usually unilateral. In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. The presence of this tumor in prepubertal girls may lead to precocious puberty. The serum and tissue inhibin levels are elevated.

The cut section is soft and has a yellowish reticular or trabecular appearance with interstitial hemorrhage. On microscopy, Call- Exner bodies are seen which are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material recall immature follicles. 

Other options:

Option B: Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor is the second most common malignant ovarian tumor. Schiller -Duval bodies are pathognomonic on histopathology. This structure consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells.

The below image shows Schiller- Duval bodies.

Option C: Psammoma bodies are concentrically calcified structures seen in serous tumors of the ovary but are not specific for neoplasia. 

Option D: Signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. It is the carcinoma of the stomach metastasized to the ovary.

questions.text: After hitting your elbow against the wall, rubbing the affected area seems to relieve the pain. The stimulation of which of the following fibers is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The pain relief experienced after rubbing the affected area is due to the stimulation of Aβ sensory fibers.

The stimulation of large-type Aβ sensory fibers from peripheral tactile receptors depresses pain signal transmission from the same body area. This occurs due to local lateral inhibition in the spinal cord.

The activity of these cutaneous mechanosensitive afferents may reduce the responsiveness of dorsal horn neurons to the nociceptive input from afferent terminals. It explains why rubbing the skin near painful areas offers pain relief, and also explains why the local application of liniments relieves pain.

This is called the gate-control mechanism of pain modulation. It is the principle behind the use of transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) for pain relief. TENS uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibers near the injury.

Note:
Pain stimulus is transmitted by Aδ (fast pain) and C fibers (slow pain).

questions.text: Choose the correctly matched pair among the following nail changes with their respective diseases.
questions.solution:
Image 1 is correctly matched. It shows trachonychia, which is most commonly seen in alopecia areata.

Trachyonychia presents as a rough surface affecting the entire nail plate and up to 20 nails (20‐nail dystrophy). It is mainly associated with alopecia areata, psoriasis, and lichen planus.

Other nail findings in alopecia areata:
  • fine stippled pitting of the nails
  • atrophic dystrophy
 
Image 2 shows onychomycosis

Distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis is the most common pattern of infection. It usually presents as a yellow or white patch of discoloration, at the free edge of the nail plate, and near the lateral nail fold.

 
Image 3 shows nail pitting with subungual oil drops 

Nail pitting is the most frequent change seen in psoriasis. Nail bed disease can be seen as subungual oil drops which are pathognomonic for psoriasis.

 

Image 4 shows the pup tent sign, elevation of nail in shape of tent, which is seen in lichen planus.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text: Which of the following committees is responsible for establishing the Medical and Health Education Commission?
questions.solution:
The Shrivastav committee recommended the establishment of a Medical and Health Education Commission for planning and implementing the reforms needed in health and medical education on the lines of the University Grants Commission.

The Shrivastav Committee was formed in the year 1975 as a “group on medical education and support manpower”. The committee was established for the following purposes:

  • To devise a suitable curriculum for training a cadre of health assistants so that they can serve as a link between qualified medical practitioners and multipurpose workers
  • To suggest steps for improving the existing medical educational processes so as to provide due emphasis on the problems particularly relevant to national requirements

The group recommended immediate action for the following: 

  • Creation of bands of para-professional and semi-professional health workers from within the community itself (e.g., school teachers, postmasters, gram-sevaks) to provide simple, promotive, preventive, and curative health services needed by the community
  • Establishment of 2 cadres of health workers, namely multipurpose health workers and health assistants, between the community-level workers and doctors at the PHC
  • ROME scheme- Reorientation of Health Education
  • Establishment of the Medical and Health Education Commission
  • Development of a 'Referral Services Complex'

questions.text:
Match the following Darrow-Yannet diagrams with the fluid shift occurring in the given conditions.
  1. Infusion of 3% normal saline
  2. Infusion of 0.45% normal saline
  3. Infusion of 0.9% Normal saline
  4. Normal
questions.solution:
Option D is correct. 

Diagram 1 - Normal

Diagram 2 - Infusion of 0.9% normal saline

Diagram 3 - Infusion of 0.45% normal saline

Diagram 4 - Infusion of 3% normal saline

Darrow-Yannet diagrams depict the change in plasma osmolarity and plasma volume in various conditions. The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either addition or removal of fluid.

Diagram 1 - Normal extracellular fluid (ECF) and intracellular fluid (ICF) balance.

Diagram 2 - The addition of isotonic saline (0.9% normal saline) to ECF does not cause any fluid shift from the ICF. Hence, it only leads to an increase in ECF volume without causing any change in osmolarity.

Diagram 3 - Hypotonic saline (0.45% normal saline) leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a shift of fluid from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both the compartments become equal. The fluid influx leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ICF as well. Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume, increase in intracellular volume, and a fall in osmolarity in both the compartments.

Diagram 4 - The addition of hypertonic saline to ECF pulls the fluid from ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the graph shown below are true except?

choices.text: The first urge to void is felt at a volume of about 300 mL
The sense of fullness is felt at a volume of about 400 mL
The flatness of segment Ib is due to law of Laplace

questions.solution:
The above graph is a cystometrogram. The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL and not at 300 mL.

Cystometrogram is a  plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

  • Ia where an initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced
  • Ib where a long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced
  • II where a sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered

The flatness of segment Ib is a demonstration of the law of Laplace. The law of Laplace states that the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R

In the blad­der, the tension increases as the bladder get filled. But as the radius too increases the increase in pressure is slight until the bladder is relatively full. The marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of about 400 mL.

questions.text: A child presents for a well-child visit. You observe that he is sitting in a tripod position. He has stranger anxiety on seeing you and babbles in monosyllables. The fine motor milestones likely to be attained by the child at this age are:

choices.text: Tower of two blocks, imitates scribbling

questions.solution:
Sitting in a tripod fashion, recognizing strangers and having stranger anxiety, and speaking in monosyllables indicate that the child is most likely to be six months old. The fine motor milestones likely to be attained at this age are unidextrous reach and being able to transfer objects.

The developmental milestones at the age of six months are:

  • Fine motor and adaptive: reaches out for objects with one hand - unidextrous reach and transfers objects from one hand to another
  • Gross motor: Independently sits with arms forward for support - "tripod" fashion
  • Social and adaptive milestones: Recognises strangers, stranger anxiety
  • Language milestones: Monosyllables like ba, da, pa

Other options:

Option B: A child attains a mature pincer grasp only around 12 months of age. 

Option C: A child can build a tower of two blocks and imitate scribbling around 15 months of age.

Option D: A child can build a tower of three blocks and scribble around 18 months of age.

questions.text: In the experiment shown below, what role does the whistle play?
questions.solution:
The experiment shown in the image is that of classical conditioning by Ivan Pavlov. The whistle plays the role of a conditional stimulus.

Classical conditioning is the theory of learning where neutral stimuli are associated with psychologically significant events.

Events in the Pavlov experiment:

  • Food - Unconditional stimulus (Option B) as it elicits salivation before the experiment commences
  • Response to food - Salivation as a result of the unconditional stimulus is the unconditional response (Option A) as it is elicited before the commencement of the experiment.
  • Bell/Whistle - Conditional stimulus as it elicits salivation conditional to the pairing of the bell and food
  • Response to the bell/whistle - This is known as the conditional response (Option C) as the dog has been conditioned to react to the conditional stimulus.

This model usually deals with involuntary responses. It is also called learning by association or respondent conditioning. He's also known for his work on the physiology of digestion

The above image shows the Sengstaken Blakemore tube.

The given clinical scenario- a chronic alcoholic with hematemesis is suggestive of esophageal variceal bleeding, in which temporary hemostasis can be achieved with the help of balloon tamponades.

Sengstaken-Blakemore tube has 3 lumens. 1 suction tube and 2 inflation tubes. The 3 openings are the gastric balloon port, esophageal balloon port, and the gastric aspiration port

Sengstaken–Blakemore tube should be decompressed every 12 hours to prevent necrosis.

Option (C): Linton-Nachlas tube has only two ports and a single gastric balloon.

 

Option (D): Ewalds tube is used in situations such as poisoning, relief of obstruction, and emptying of the stomach prior to gastroscopy. it has only one aspiration port for the stomach.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female patient was diagnosed with carcinoma of the breast and is set to undergo radical mastectomy with dissection of levels 1, 2 and 3 lymph nodes. Which of the following represents level 3 lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
The lymph nodes marked as 1 belong to the level 3 axillary nodes.

Lymph nodes are divided into different levels on the basis of their relation to the pectoralis minor.

  • Level 1 lymph nodes: Lateral to the pectoralis minor
  • Level 2 lymph nodes: Superficial or deep to the pectoralis minor
  • Level 3 lymph nodes: Medial to or above the upper border of the pectoralis minor

 

Another method of axillary lymph node classification, as shown in the image below, is based on the anatomical regions that the specific nodes drain.

It can be classified into 5 groups- apical, central, lateral, anterior, and posterior. The apical group receives lymph from the other 4 groups, as well as from the upper part of the breast on the same side.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is being evaluated for generalized painless lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. Biopsy was suspicious of lymphoma and therefore immunohistochemistry was performed. The lymphoma cells expressed CD19, CD20, surface immunoglobulins, and CD5. They were negative for CD23. Overexpression of which of the following protooncogenes leads to this lymphoma?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient is suffering from mantle cell lymphoma. Overexpression of cyclin D1 leads to this lymphoma.

Mantle cell lymphoma is a lymphoid neoplasm in which tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells surrounding the germinal center. Translocation (11;14) causes overexpression of cyclin D1 proto-oncogene.

It usually presents in the fifth to sixth decades of life. Male patients are commonly affected.  The most common presentation is painless lymphadenopathy. They may also have hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. Mucosal involvement produces polyps-like lesions in the small intestine or colon. This is called lymphomatoid polyposis.

On histopathology, the tumors cells may be spread diffusely across the node or may surround the germinal centers to give a nodular appearance. The lymphocytes are small in size and contain a deeply cleaved nucleus (resemble centrocytes). This picture is similar to follicular lymphoma. However, follicular lymphoma also contains large cells resembling centroblasts. This feature can be used to differentiate mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma.

Mantle cell lymphomas express high levels of cyclin D1. These cells are positive for CD19, CD20, CD5, and surface immunoglobulins (Ig). They are negative for CD23. In cases, where cyclin D1 is negative, SOX11 marker can be used to identify this lymphoma.

Other options: 

Option B- Overexpression of TGFA is seen in astrocytomas.

Option C- Overexpression of NMYC is seen in neuroblastoma.

Option D- Overexpression of cyclin dependant kinases 4 (CDK4) is seen in glioblastoma, melanoma, and sarcoma.

questions.text: You are a part of a project that involves the quality improvement of patient care in the hospital. The plan of the project is given below. What is the duration of the critical pathway in the project?
questions.solution:
The critical pathway would take 11 days in the given project plan. 

The critical path is the longest path in the network analysis. Any delay in the critical path will delay the entire project. Here, the longest pathway consists of "Start---> task B---> task C---> Finish," which is (5+6) 11 days.

Although task D is the longest activity taking 7 days, it is not the longest pathway.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden-onset fever, chills, headache, and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is a history of rodent infestation at his farm. He is diagnosed with a disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image below. Identify the type of zoonosis and the type of biological transmission in this disease.
questions.solution:
The given image above is of a rat flea, which transmits plague bacilli. The type of zoonosis is meta-zoonosis, and the type of biological transmission is propagative transmission. In propagative biological transmission, the disease agent only multiplies in the vector but there is no change in form. Metazoonosis refers to zoonoses that require both vertebrates and invertebrates to complete their infectious cycle.

Zoonoses: These are diseases and infections that are naturally transmitted between other vertebrate animals and man.

Classification of zoonoses on the basis of their reservoir hosts:

  • Anthropozoonoses
  • Zoo-anthroponoses
  • Amphixenoses

Classification of zoonoses on the basis of the life cycle of the infecting agent:

Category

Mode

Example

Direct zoonoses

Direct contact/ fomite/mechanical vector

No essential developmental/ propagative changes during transmission

Rabies , Trichinosis, Brucellosis

Cyclozoonoses

Require more than one vertebrate host is needed to complete the developmental cycle and no invertebrate host

 Human taeniasis, Echinococcosis, Pentastomid infections

Metazoonoses

Transmitted by invertebrate vectors, in which the infective agent develops/multiplies and after a period of extrinsic period of incubation is transmitted to another vertebrate host.

Arboviral infections, Plague and Schistosomiasis

Saprozoonoses

Has both a vertebrate host and a non-animal (food, soil/ plants)developmental site/reservoir

Various forms of larva migrants and mycoses

Biological transmission in vector-borne diseases:

  • Propagative - The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form. e.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.
  • Cyclo-propagative - The agent changes in form and in number. e.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.
  • Cyclo-developmental - The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication. e.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.
  • Transovarial - The infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny. e.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.
  • Transstadial - The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next. e.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

Plague is a zoonotic disease. The plague bacillus is a natural parasite in rodents and the infection is transmitted amongst them by rat fleas. In the flea, the bacilli multiply and block the proventriculus. When such a blocked flea bites another rodent, the blood, mixed with the bacteria is regurgitated into the bite, transmitting the infection.

When a diseased rat dies (rat fall), the fleas may bite human beings, causing the plague, which usually manifests as sudden onset of fever and painful lymphadenopathy. Several species of fleas act as vectors. 

Human plague occurs in 3 clinical forms:

Bubonic plague is the most common variety. It is characterized by swollen lymph nodes, which typically develop within a week after an infected flea bite.

Pneumonic plague occurs when bubonic plague spreads to the lungs. It is the most virulent form of plague, and an infected person may transmit the disease via droplets to other humans.

Septicemic plague occurs when the bacteria enter the bloodstream directly and multiply there.

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male patient presented with meningoencephalitis. Laboratory workup for Herpes Simplex is negative. An increased rate of deaths in crows in the neighborhood has been reported. You suspect an arbovirus whose life cycle is shown below. It can be classified under which of the following family?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of West Nile encephalitis caused by the West Nile Virus belonging to the family Flaviviridae. Other important species under the genus flavivirus include:

  • Dengue virus
  • Japanese encephalitis virus
  • Yellow fever virus

West Nile Virus is a common viral febrile illness and is the most common cause of arboviral encephalitis in the United States. It is also seen in The Middle East, Europe, Africa, and Asia. In India, it is found in regions of Rajasthan to Karnataka.

The virus has a predominantly enzootic lifecycle involving birds and mosquitos, mostly belonging to the Culex species such as C. pipiens (although Aedes and Anopheles might also be rarely involved). Humans and other mammals such as horses are incidentally involved in the cycle. Very rarely, the virus may be transmitted through organ transplantation and blood transfusion. 

Clinically, the majority of the West Nile Virus infections are asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients present with fever, maculopapular rash, lymphadenopathy, myalgia, arthralgia, headache, and fatigue. The elderly, ill, and immunocompromised individuals may be affected more severely than the general population. They may develop neurological manifestations such as tremors, acute flaccid paralysis resembling polio, aseptic meningitis, and diffuse encephalitis. Very rarely, patients may develop features of transient parkinsonism. 

Note:

Arbovirus is a term used to refer to any viruses that are transmitted by arthropod vectors. There is no family or order by the name arbovirus. The word arbovirus is an acronym (Arthropod-Borne virus).

questions.text: Which of the following suture techniques is employed for the best cosmetic appearance after wound healing?
questions.solution:
The suture technique employed for the best cosmetic appearance after wound healing is the subcuticular suturing technique.

Subcuticular sutures: 

It is used for a better cosmetic appearance. It is also employed in situations where the edges of the wound are easily approximated. In this technique, small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound and then they are gently pulled together. This wound cause approximation of the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.

Both absorbable and non-absorbable suture materials can be used in this technique. A buried knot is secured at the ends of absorbable sutures when they are used. When non-absorbable sutures are used, a collar and bead are used to secure the ends of the suture.

The following image is a pictorial representation of the subcuticular suture technique-

 

 

Other options-

Option (A): Continuous sutures-  the first suture is inserted similar to an interrupted suture. The rest of the sutures are made in a continuous manner till the other end of the wound. Constant tension should be maintained to avoid excessive tension or slack and hence the use of an assistant is helpful in this technique. An Aberdeen knot is used to secure the end of the suture.

The image below shows continuous sutures-

 

Option (B): Mattress sutures - They can be vertical or horizontal and are used to evert or invert the wound edges. The initial suture is inserted in the same way as an interrupted suture, but then the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again as seen in the picture. The main advantage of the mattress suture is that it helps to approximate wound edges when this would not be easily possible otherwise.

The following image shows the vertical mattress suture technique-

 

Option (C): Interrupted sutures- In this technique the needle should be inserted at right angles and exit at right angles to the skin. The distance from the entry point of the suture to the edge of the wound should be similar to the depth of tissue that is sutured. Twice this distance should be there between two consecutive sutures.

questions.text: The skeleton remains of an unidentified body were brought to the forensic department for identification. The skull had bull-teeth, where the pulp cavity of molars was found to be wide and deep, and the roots were fused and bent. There was also a lack of the third upper molar. What race do you think the skeletal remains belong to?
questions.solution:
The condition of bull-tooth or ‘taurodontism’ suggests that the skeletal remains most probably belonged to a person from the Mongoloid race.

In bull-teeth, the pulp cavity of molars is wide and deep, and the roots are fused and bent. A congenital lack of the third upper molar is most common in Mongoloids. In Mongoloid teeth, enamel pearls, small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface, are much more frequent. 

 Features of Mongoloid dentition

  • Shovel-shaped upper central incisors - Posterior surfaces of these teeth have a depression centrally
  • Enamel pearls - Small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface
  • The pulp cavity of molars is wide and deep
  • A congenital lack of the third upper molar is common but nonspecific.

Other options-

Option (B): Caucasian race-  the lateral incisors in the upper jaw are usually smaller than the central. They also have long pointed canine roots. Small nodules on the lingual surface of maxillary molars, called ‘Carabelli’s cusp’, are most common in Caucasian races.

Option (C): Negroid races tend to have large teeth and often have more cusps on their molars, even up to eight, with two lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars as an additional common finding.

Option (D): Aboriginal races tend to have large teeth with wide crowns. They do not show taurodontism.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the hospital in a semi-conscious state. He is sweating profusely, has muscle weakness, breathlessness with an audible wheeze, and constricted pupils. On further evaluation, he is diagnosed with carbaryl poisoning. Which of the following should not be used for treatment?
questions.solution:
Pralidoxime should not be used for the treatment of carbaryl poisoning.

Oximes like pralidoxime are used to restore neuromuscular transmission in organophosphate anti­ChE poisoning. It attaches to the anionic site of the cholinesterase enzyme, which remains unoccupied in the presence of organophosphates. It binds and forms oxime-phosphonate which diffuses away, leaving the reactivated cholinesterase.

Pralidoxime is not an effective anti­dote to carbamates like carbaryl. This is because the anionic site of the cholinesterase enzyme is not free for attachment to pralidoxime. Hence, it does not reactivate the carbamylated enzyme. Carbamates spontaneously disassociate from AChE and recover in 24-48 hours.

Pralidoxime may potentiate the toxicity of carbaryl. Therefore, pralidoxime should be avoided in known single-agent carbaryl poisonings. However, pralidoxime is considered for use in mixed poisonings with an organophosphorus compound and a carbamate.   

Other options:

Option B: Atropine is the mainstay in the management of carbamate poisoning. It is the antidote of choice, given for muscarinic symptoms. Atropine is usually sufficient till the carbamylated acetylcholinesterase complex dissociates spontaneously and recovers function. This occurs usually within 24 hours.

Option C: Diazepam may be used for the management of seizures in carbaryl poisoning.

Option D: Activated charcoal can be used to perform gastric lavage in oral carbamate poisoning.

questions.text: As a first-year surgery resident, you have scrubbed in to assist a urologist on a TURP procedure. Up to what distal anatomical landmark do you expect him to resect?
questions.solution:
Verumontanum is used as the distal-most border of the resection in transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). This prevents damage to the external urethral sphincter which is located just distal to the verumontanum.

Damage to the external urethral sphincter leads to urinary incontinence.

The bladder neck is the proximal limit of resection.

questions.text: A woman from Himachal Pradesh,  presented with complaints of neck swelling for the past 1 year. On examination, a firm, non-tender, pulsatile mass was palpated on the left side of the neck. The mass is mobile from side to side, but not up and down. A carotid angiogram of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Shamblin classification is used for staging
FNAC is the initial investigation of choice

questions.solution:
The given scenario and carotid angiogram showing splaying of the bifurcation of the carotids, also known as lyre sign points to a diagnosis of chemodectoma. Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is contraindicated when a chemodectoma is suspected.

Chemodectoma is also known as carotid body tumor (aka potato tumor). It is a benign tumor of the neuroendocrine tissue of the carotid body. It has a higher incidence at high altitudes because of chronic hypoxia, which leads to carotid body hyperplasia.

The tumor presents as a slowly enlarging mass that is firm, rubbery, pulsatile, mobile from side to side but not up and down. A bruit may be heard. Family history can be present in 10% of the cases. 

Shamblin classification is used for staging carotid body tumors.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with the passage of blood-colored urine, pain during micturition, and increased frequency of urination for the last 2 days. After further investigations, he is diagnosed with acute hemorrhagic cystitis caused by adenovirus. Which of the following characteristics correctly describes this causative agent?
questions.solution:
This is a case of acute hemorrhagic cystitis, which is caused by adenovirus—a naked double-stranded DNA virus. 

Acute hemorrhagic cystitis is a viral urinary tract infection. It presents with cystitis and gross hematuria. 

Adenovirus types 7, 11, 34, and 35 are the common serotypes associated with this disease and can be recovered from the blood and urine of patients with hemorrhagic cystitis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with nausea, vomiting, and acute onset epigastric pain radiating to the back. Investigations revealed elevated levels of serum amylase and lipase. An abdominal X-ray showed the colon-cut off sign.  Which of the following criteria uses CT to stage the severity of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the abdominal radiograph showing the colon cut-off sign are suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Balthazar Scoring is used for staging the severity of acute pancreatitis based on CT findings.

The most common causes of acute pancreatitis are - gallstones, alcoholism, post-ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography), drugs (steroids, thiazides, azathioprine, etc.), hypercalcemia, etc. 

The classical presentation includes acute severe epigastric pain radiating to the back and relieved by leaning forward. Nausea and vomiting can also be present. Clinical signs such as hypotension, tachycardia, Grey Turner sign (bluish discoloration of the flanks), and Cullen’s sign (bluish discoloration around the umbilicus) can be present.

The Grey Turner sign is shown below:

Cullen's sign is shown below:

The below abdominal x-ray shows an abrupt transition from distended to collapsed colon just beyond the splenic flexure. This is known as a colon cut-off sign.

Laboratory findings include elevated serum amylase and serum lipase. Serum amylase levels are non-specific, while serum lipase is more specific, and lipase is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours from the onset of symptoms.

Management involves keeping the patient nil per oral, fluid replacement, and pain control. Antibiotics are rarely required unless the infection spreads.

Other options-

Option A: Modified Glasgow score uses 8 laboratory findings to predict the severity of acute pancreatitis (within 48 hours of treatment onset). It is not a CT-based scoring system.

Option C: APACHE II score (Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation score) is another clinical tool that assesses the risk of mortality and predicts prolonged intensive care treatment. It is also not CT-based.

Option D: Ranson's criteria uses 11 clinical and laboratory findings at admission and after 48 hours to assess clinical severity. It does not include CT scan findings.

questions.text: What does the blood-gas partition coefficient of an inhaled anesthetic indicate?
questions.solution:
The blood gas (B:G) partition coefficient of an inhaled anesthetic is an indicator of solubility in blood which determines the speed of induction and recovery.

An inhalational anesthetic with a lower blood gas partition (B:G) coefficient would have lower solubility in blood. This would mean a higher alveolar concentration which will lead to faster induction and recovery.

Xenon with a blood-gas partition coefficient of 0.115 has the fastest induction and emergence from anesthesia.

Methoxyflurane with a blood gas partition coefficient of 12 has the slowest induction and emergence from anesthesia.

The speed of induction and emergence:

Xenon > Desflurane > Sevoflurane> Isoflurane > Enflurane > Halothane > Methoxyflurane

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients.

Isoflurane 1.2 1.4

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

questions.text: A 23-year-old girl who is an alleged victim of rape is brought to the casualty. Samples are collected for the detection of semen. Which of the following tests is not useful in the detection of semen?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given tests, the Teichmann test is not used for semen detection. 

The Teichmann test or hemin crystal test is used to detect suspected bloodstains. It is performed by placing a small piece of suspected material on a glass slide. Then, 2-3 drops of glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride are added to the glass slide and covered with a coverslip. The slide is then heated.

If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear. When hydrogen peroxide is added, the hematin crystals produce bubbles of gas.

Other options:

Option B: P30 assay is a test to look for a glycoprotein produced by the prostate gland present in the semen (even of aspermic male), blood, and urine of a male. It may be found in the vagina up to 27 hours after intercourse. It is a reliable indicator of semen irrespective of acid phosphatase levels or the presence of sperm. 

Option C: Barberio test is used to detect seminal fluid and probably detect the presence of prostatic secretions. When a saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Option D: Acid phosphatase test detects the presence of high levels of acid phosphatase in seminal stains (low levels may be present in the vagina). Positive reactions are found till 36 hours, after which the levels fall and disappear within 72 hours.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male patient complains of a burning sensation in both legs and episodes of excruciating pain, tingling, and a sensation he describes as "pins and needles." Which of the following drugs is used in the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has painful diabetic neuropathy. Duloxetine is a selective serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SSNRI) and is one of the drugs used in the first-line treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy. 

Painful diabetic neuropathy manifests as a burning, excruciating, stabbing, or intractable type of pain or presents with tingling or numbness. The pathophysiology of this condition is due to primarily metabolic and vascular factors.

Treatment of painful sensory neuropathies:

 First line:

  • Lidoderm 5% patch
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline)
  • Gabapentin, Pregabalin
  • Duloxetine

Second line:

  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Venlafaxine
  • Tramadol

Third line:

  • Mexiletine

Optimal glucose control is considered the cornerstone for the treatment of diabetes and its complications. Intensive glucose control has been shown to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient comes to the emergency department complaining of high fever, chills, and abdominal pain for the past 5 days. Laboratory tests of blood and stool cultures show an oxidase-negative, motile, gram-negative bacillus which is cultured in the media pictured below.  Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative organism, in this case, is Salmonella typhi. Salmonella is a gram-negative rod that is motile, oxidase negative, and shows large black colonies, with a metallic sheen when cultured in Wilson and Blair bismuth sulfite medium.

Salmonella typhi reduces sulfite to sulfide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on the Wilson and Blair bismuth sulfite medium. It is an example of indicator media. It is also a selective media because inhibiting substances are added to inhibit the growth of unwanted bacteria.

On the Wilson-Blair medium, S. Typhi forms large black colonies, with a metallic sheen and S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

Other options-

Option A - Shigella can cause bloody diarrhea and present similarly to Salmonella species infection. They also are oxidase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods. However, Shigella species are non-motile, while Salmonella species are motile.

Option B - Escherichia coli (EHEC, EIEC) can cause bloody diarrhea. They are also gram-negative rods that are oxidase-negative. However, E. coli does not produce black colonies in a bismuth sulfite medium.

Option D- Pseudomonas aeruginosa does not cause bloody diarrhea. Although it is a gram-negative bacillus, it is oxidase-positive.

Match the following declarations to their significance.
