questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-B, 2-F, 3-E, 4-A, 5-D.

Declaration Significance
Istanbul Addresses problem statements with regards to the shortage of global organs for transplants and organ trafficking
Taipei Statements on ethical considerations involved in a health database and biobanks. 
Oslo Statement on therapeutic abortion.
Malta Statements related to hunger strikes.
Tokyo Guidelines for physicians concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detainment or imprisonment.
Helsinki Set of ethical principles directed to the medical community for human experimentation.

Related Pearl: Health-related International Declarations:

  1. Declaration of Alma-Ata (1978): Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All.
  2. Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion (1986): The aim of the conference was to continue to  achieve the objectives of the World Health Organization (WHO) Health for all by the year 2000.

3. Declaration of Oslo (1970): Related to therapeutic abortion.

4. Declaration of Tokyo (1975): Guidelines for medical doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment. (T – Tokyo – Torture)

5. Declaration of Helsinki (1975): Related to human experimentation. (H – Helsinki – Human experimentation)

6. Declaration of Geneva (1948): Most recent amendment was done on October 14, 2017 in Chicago. It gives the modern version of the 2500-year-old Hippocratic Oath which laid down the fundamental principles of medical ethics that any physician should follow.

7. Declaration of Malta (1991, revised in 1992): Related to hunger strikes.

8. Declaration of Lisbon: Related to rights of the patients like right to information, confidentiality, dignity, freedom of choice etc.

9. Declaration of Sydney on human death: It stated that the determination of death “will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids”, emphasising the EEG. Nonetheless, it asserted that “the overall judgment of the physician” could not be replaced by any ancillary test.

The statement also recommended that two or more physicians should make the diagnosis of death when organs were removed for transplantation.

10. Declaration of Istanbul: To address the urgent and growing problems of organ sales, transplant tourism and trafficking in organ donors in the context of the global shortage of organs.

11. Declaration of Taipei: Related to ethical considerations regarding health databases and biobanks.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to you with impaction of the fishbone in the area which forms the lateral channel for food. All of the following form the boundaries of this area except?
questions.solution:
The given scenario represents the impaction of fishbone in the pyriform fossa, which forms the lateral channel for food. The pyriform fossa is not bounded medially by the cuneiform cartilage.

Pyriform fossa:

It lies on either side of the larynx and extends from the pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of the esophagus. It is bounded laterally by the thyrohyoid membrane and the thyroid cartilage and medially by the aryepiglottic fold, posterolateral surfaces of arytenoid and cricoid cartilages. 

The internal laryngeal nerve runs submucosally in the lateral wall of the sinus and this is easily accessible for local anesthesia. It is also through this nerve that the pain is referred to as the ear in the carcinoma of the pyriform sinus.

Pyriform sinus is richly supplied by lymphatics and drains into the upper deep cervical group of lymph nodes. The lymphatics exit through the thyrohyoid membrane to drain into the upper jugular chain. 

The image below shows a cut section of the human larynx. Note the location of the pyriform fossa/sinus.

questions.text: A 22-year-old student presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CSF sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology?
questions.solution:
This patient has a high-grade fever and is a student, so he presumably spends a lot of time in crowded areas. The above image shows a purpuric rash. This patient's features are seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci. 

The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with the help of pili. From the nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.

Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial hemorrhages. Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

questions.text: A nurse is found to be seropositive for both HBsAg and HBeAg. These findings denote which of the following?

choices.text: Concurrent hepatitis B and hepatitis E infection

questions.solution:
Seropositivity for both HBsAg and HBeAg indicates an acute hepatitis B infection.

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is an objective marker of active HBV infection and is present for about 3-4 weeks. It may be present in a chronic carrier state (when it persists for longer than 6 months). Antibody to HBsAg (Anti-HBs) is detected 3-6 months after recovery from the initial infection or vaccination and confers immunity.

Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) is a marker of active viral replication in the liver. The persistence of HBeAg is an indicator of chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication. Anti-HBeAg antibodies are produced against these antigens.

In high infectivity chronic HBV, both HBsAg and HBeAg will be present but in low infectivity chronic HBV only HBsAg will be present.

questions.text: A female patient has a history of three miscarriages. Identify the investigation that was done from the image shown below.
questions.solution:
The investigation shown in the given image is hysterosalpingography. The given hysterosalpingogram shows a unicornuate uterus.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is an imaging modality in which radiopaque contrast is injected through the cervical canal to assess the endometrial cavity, the fallopian tubes, and the endocervical canal.

HSG should be done between days 5 and 10 of the menstrual cycle, in the preovulatory phase, as an outpatient procedure. Leech Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter no.14 is introduced into the endometrial cavity through the cervical os, and the contrast is injected. The uterine cavity and fallopian tubes are then visualized and X-rays are obtained.

HSG can be used for the following:

  • To assess tubal patency in infertility 
  • To detect uterine anomalies, synechiae, and polyps
  • To detect incompetence of the cervical os

Contraindications to HSG:

  • Acute pelvic infection 
  • Active uterine bleeding
  • Pregnancy/ suspected pregnancy
  • Contrast allergy
  • Premenstrual phase

HSG is a safe procedure, however, complications such as ascending spread of infection, chemical peritonitis, allergic reaction to the dye, or pelvic endometriosis may occur. 

Other options:

Option A: Hysteroscopy is an operative procedure in which the uterine cavity can be visualized by passing a fiberoptic telescope via the cervix. It can be diagnostic or therapeutic. A hysteroscopic image of a uterus with carcinoma is shown below.

Option B: Saline infusion sonography is a procedure where normal saline is injected into the uterine cavity and the uterus is imaged with transvaginal sonography. It is shown in the image below.

Option D: Transvaginal ultrasonography is a noninvasive imaging technique using the transvaginal approach. It provides a more detailed evaluation of the pelvic organs as compared to the transabdominal approach.

questions.text: A 2-week-old girl born at 35 weeks of gestation presents with lethargy and bilious vomiting for the past one day. She has diffuse abdominal distension and a sunken anterior fontanelle. Bowel movements were normal prior to this but she now has bloody stool. Her plain abdominal X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a premature infant presenting with lethargy, bilious vomiting, diffuse abdominal distension, dehydration, and bloody stool with an X-ray showing gas in the bowel wall is likely to have necrotizing enterocolitis.

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a rapidly progressing disease causing extensive bowel necrosis, infection, and perforation in newborns. Premature, low-birth-weight (LBW) infants are at an increased risk for developing this life-threatening emergency. 

Pathogenesis of this condition involves mucosal ischemia that progresses to necrosis. Subsequently, there is gaseous accumulation in the bowel submucosa termed as pneumatosis intestinalis that can be further complicated by perforation, peritonitis, sepsis, and eventual death. 

Patients have feeding intolerance, vomiting, and associated dehydration (sunken fontanelle), abdominal distension, occult/gross blood in stool, and temperature instability.

Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall). Gas may be sometimes visualized in the portal venous tree. NE cases complicated by perforation may show pneumoperitoneum (gas under diaphragm) on abdominal x-ray. 

Other options:

Option A- A duodenal atresia is a form of intestinal atresia that presents with symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction, bilious vomiting, and dehydration. Abdominal x-ray findings show a classic double-bubble sign due to duodenal and gastric distension with no air distal to the point of obstruction. 

Option B- Cystic fibrosis (CF) is associated with meconium ileus, wherein the meconium becomes impacted in the distal small bowel. There is a failure to pass meconium in the first 24 hours after birth. CF patients also present with abdominal distension and bilious emesis but abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

The below image shows a contrast enema image demonstrating a microcolon. 

Option D- Intussusception is characterized by the invagination of a proximal bowel segment (usually, the ileum) into the segment distal to it (ascending colon). It is commonly seen in children between the age of 6 to 9 months and presents with colicky abdominal pain and passage of red-currant-jelly stool. Barium enema findings include a classic claw sign or coiled spring sign that represents the telescoping intestinal segment. Ultrasound imaging demonstrates the target sign which shows the telescoping segment surrounded by the lumen of the adjacent intestinal segment. It is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 47-year-old P1L1 lady presented with complaints of excessive bleeding during menstruation, and a feeling of heaviness in her lower abdomen. On examination, the uterus appeared enlarged with free adnexa. A hysterectomy was performed and the histopathological slide is shown below.  Which is the most common type of this lesion?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of excessive menstrual bleeding, heaviness, and the enlarged uterus is suggestive of leiomyoma. The most common type is intramural leiomyoma. The stained histopathological image shows interlacing bundles of uniform spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with blunted nuclei.

Leiomyomas are benign uterine neoplasms, which are also known as myomas or fibroids. They are classified based on their location as:

  • Intramural or interstitial -most common, grows within the myometrial wall
  • Submucous- grows in the myometrium towards the endometrial cavity, and are covered only by a thin layer of endometrium
  • Subserous: grows from uterine serosa outwards towards the peritoneum
  • Other locations outside the uterus like the round ligament, the utero-ovarian and uterosacral ligaments, cervix, vagina, and the vulva.

When the leiomyoma is attached to a stalk, it is known as a pedunculated leiomyoma. Subserosal leiomyomas that attach themselves to nearby pelvic structures and derive vascular support are called parasitic leiomyomas.

Risk factors for developing fibroids include:

  • Increased risk:
    • Nulliparous women
    • Obesity
    • Hyper estrogenic states -endometriosis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma
    • African-American women.
  • Decreased risk in multiparous women.
  • Recent studies have shown no correlation between smoking and leiomyomas

Most women with leiomyomas are asymptomatic. However, affected women may complain of heavy menstrual bleeding, pain, pressure, or infertility.

Treatment:

  • Medical therapy: Drugs to reduce the size of the fibroid
    • Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone/RU-486
    • GnRH analogs
    • Agonists – goserelin, nafarelin
    • Antagonists – cetrorelix, ganirelix
    • Levonorgestrel releasing intrauterine system
    • Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM’s) – Asoprisnil
  • Uterine artery embolization
  • Myomectomy
  • Hysterectomy

questions.text: A term newborn does not cry at birth, despite stimulation. The heart rate doesn't improve even after 30 seconds of the bag and mask ventilation. Ventilation is continued and chest compressions are initiated at the lower third of the sternum. The compressions should be at the rate of
questions.solution:
The chest compressions should be at the rate of 90 compressions/min during neonatal resuscitation.
 
The response to neonatal resuscitation at various steps is assessed based on the heart rate.
  • If the heart rate is less than 100, PPV (positive pressure ventilation) is provided with bag and mask and SPO2 monitoring is done and adequate ventilation is ensured.
  • If the heart rate is below 60, then chest compressions are initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions/min.
  • Recommended rate of ventilation is 30 inflations/min. (90 compressions + 30 inflation = 120 events/ min). The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3: 1.
  • If the heart rate still remains <60, despite effective compressions and ventilation, then IV epinephrine is given.

 

Kindly note: Neonatal resuscitation is primarily to support a newborn during the transition from intrauterine to extrauterine life. AHA guidelines recommend 90 compressions/ min for neonatal resuscitation. Whereas, pediatric CPR is for cardiac arrest in infants and children. AHA guidelines recommend 100-120 compressions/ min for pediatric CPR.

questions.text: Which of the following is a property of the cell wall of the organism that stains as shown below?

choices.text: Absence of aromatic and sulphur containing amino acids

questions.solution:
The given image shows Gram-negative bacilli, the cell walls of which contain lipopolysaccharides.

The table below gives a comparison of the cell walls of gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.

  Gram-positive Gram-negative
Teichoic acid, lipoteichoic acid Present Absent
Thickness (Peptidoglycan) Thicker Thinner
Variety of amino acids Few Several
Aromatic and sulphur-containing amino acids Absent Present
Lipopolysaccharides and outer membrane Absent Present

Lipopolysaccharides present on the cell walls of gram-negative bacteria account for the endotoxic activity and O antigen specificity. The outermost layer of the gram-negative bacterial cell wall is called the outer membrane and contains several proteins called outer membrane proteins. 

Gram-positive bacteria contain teichoic acid, which is a major surface antigen containing ribitol or glycerol polymers.

The procedure of Gram staining :

  1. Primary staining with a pararosaniline dye such as crystal violet, methyl violet, or gentian violet.
  2. Application of a dilute solution of iodine - fixes the primary dye by forming a crystal violet-iodine complex to prevent easy removal of dye.
  3. Decolourisation with an organic solvent such as ethanol, acetone, or aniline
  4. Counterstaining with a dye of contrasting colour, such as carbol fuchsin, safranine, or neutral red

The gram-positive cell wall is thicker with several layers of peptidoglycan, which helps retain the primary stain and hence appear violet. The gram-negative cell wall has more lipids, which are dissolved by the decolourising agents, causing rapid decolourisation and taking up the counterstain, hence appearing red. 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).

Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text:
All of the following statements are true regarding oogenesis except:

LH- Luteinizing hormone

choices.text: Primary oocyte arrests in prophase of 1st meiotic division
Secondary oocyte arrests in metaphase of 1st meiotic division
Secondary oocyte arrests in metaphase of 2nd meiotic division
1st meiotic division of the secondary follicle resumes with LH surge

questions.solution:
The second statement i.e. that secondary oocytes arrest in metaphase of the first meiotic division is not true.

The secondary oocyte actually arrests in the metaphase of the second meiotic division. (Option C)

Other options-

Option (A): The primary oocyte arrests in the prophase of the 1st meiotic division (diplotene stage). These primary oocytes remain arrested in this manner until puberty. They become surrounded by a layer of flat epithelial cells and are then called primordial follicles.

Option (D): The 1st meiotic division of the secondary follicle resumes with the cyclical LH (luteinizing hormone) surge. This is the parameter required for ovulation to occur.

questions.text: All are true regarding Bartter’s syndrome except:

choices.text: Ion transporter defect is in thin ascending limb

questions.solution:
Bartter’s syndrome is associated with mutation of ion transporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

Bartter’s syndrome is a group of disorders associated with disturbances in electrolyte and acid/base balance, sometimes with nephrocalcinosis and other features. It is due to inactivating mutations of genes encoding Na-K-2Cl transport in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (TALH). 

Patients with classic BS typically suffer from polyuria and polydipsia, due to the reduction in renal concentrating ability. The combination of hypokalemia and alkalosis in a normotensive, nonedematous patient can be due to Bartter’s or Gitelman’s syndrome. Bartter’s syndrome is distinguished from Gitelman’s syndrome because of hypocalciuria in the latter disorder.

They may have an increase in urinary calcium excretion. Other features include marked activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis. Patients with antenatal BS suffer from a severe systemic disorder characterized by marked electrolyte wasting, polyhydramnios, and hypercalciuria with nephrocalcinosis; prostaglandin E2 synthesis and excretion are significantly increased, accounting for much of the systemic symptoms.

The form associated with sensorineural deafness has mutation in Barttin gene.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: You are a new intern posted in the department of ophthalmology. In the case file of a patient who had undergone a total penetrating keratoplasty, you see the ophthalmic examination findings saying that  'Khodadoust lines' are seen. In which of the conditions would you notice this finding?
questions.solution:
Khodadoust lines following penetrating keratoplasty are seen in a case of endothelial graft rejection. Khodadoust lines refer to a linear pattern of keratic precipitates associated with an area of inflammation at the graft margin.

Corneal graft rejection

The corneal graft is immunologically privileged, with an absence of blood vessels and lymphatics and the presence of relatively few antigen-presenting cells. Thus, they seldom are subject to graft failure or rejection. Predisposing factors for rejection include larger grafts >8 mm, infection, glaucoma, and previous keratoplasty.

Patients may have blurred vision, redness, photophobia, and pain. However, many patients remain asymptomatic until rejection is established. Corneal graft rejection can be of four types:

  • Epithelial rejection - elevated level of epithelium is noticed. 
  • Sub-epithelial rejection - usually due to residual adenoviral infection. These form infiltrative opacities called Krachmer spots. 
  • Stromal rejection - these present with deeper haziness.
  • Endothelial rejection - These are characterized by Khodadoust lines. It is the most common form of graft rejection leading to failure.

Stromal edema is indicative of graft failure and the presentation is almost always akin to anterior uveitis.

 

The other signs of anterior uveitis are as shown in the image below.

questions.text: Bifurcation of the aorta happens at the vertebral body level of :
questions.solution:
Bifurcation of the aorta happens at the vertebral body level of mid L4.

The aorta bifurcates into the right and left common iliac arteries at the level of L4. This bifurcation can be located on the anterior abdominal wall as a point approximately 2.5 cm below the umbilicus or with a line joining the highest points of the iliac crests.

The abdominal prevertebral plexus extends from the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm to the bifurcation of the aorta. At the bifurcation, it continues inferiorly as the superior hypogastric plexus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old postgraduate student comes to you with an intention to quit smoking. He has tried quitting multiple times in the past but could not control the craving. He recently read about nicotine chewing gums and seeks your advice on quitting smoking and the usage of nicotex. Which of the following is the right advice to give?

choices.text: Chew it just like any regular chewing gum and throw it within 15 minutes
Chew it slowly and keep it pressed on side of mouth till taste fades, then repeat
Nicotine replacement is as good as a placebo and should not be used
Switch to e-cigarette or vaping as it is harmless and free of smoke

questions.solution:
Nicotine gum has to be chewed slowly until there is a taste of nicotine and then kept pressed between the cheek and the teeth. This helps in the absorption of nicotine. This has to be repeated until it releases no more nicotine.

Nicotine withdrawal is characterized by mood changes, insomnia, poor concentration, restlessness, bradycardia, and weight gain. Withdrawal usually peaks at 1-3 days and lasts up to 3-4 weeks. This makes it difficult to maintain abstinence from cigarette smoking. 

Nicotine replacement therapy strategies have been developed to reduce nicotine withdrawal. Therapies include giving nicotine in the form of gums or patches for a period of 1 month to manage the withdrawal symptoms. It can then be gradually tapered.

Nicotine gum is useful in several ways. Firstly, it provides nicotine in low doses to avoid precipitation of withdrawal, which is usually the reason why patients use tobacco again. Secondly, it is free of smoke and other harmful additives. Thirdly, it provides an indirect measure of craving and how heavy tobacco usage was, in the first place.

Other options-

Option A: Chewing it like regular gum releases all of the nicotine at once, causing nausea.

Option C: Nicotine gum acts as a nicotine supplement and is better than a placebo. Any de-addiction requires motivation, and nicotine replacement might serve as a useful adjunct in motivated individuals.

Option D: Vaping or e-cigarettes have adverse effects on the cardiopulmonary system despite no smoke like conventional cigarettes. It consists of a battery-powered device, that converts a nicotine-containing liquid into vapor which the user inhales through the mouth, and exhales, just like a cigarette. It uses vapor instead of smoke, which is why it is referred to as vaping.

questions.text: The image given below is the structure of aggrecan, which is the principal proteoglycan found in cartilage. Identify the three glycosaminoglycans which are labeled as A, B, and C respectively.

choices.text: Hyaluronic acid, keratan sulfate, and chondroitin sulfate
Chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate, and keratan sulfate
Hyaluronic acid, keratan sulfate, and heparan sulfate
Heparan sulfate, chondroitin sulphate, and keratan sulfate

questions.solution:
Aggrecan contains glycosaminoglycans hyaluronic acid, chondroitin sulfate, and keratan sulfate along with link and core proteins. It is the principal proteoglycan found in cartilage.

Various glycosaminoglycans include: 

  • Hyaluronic acid: Present in the extracellular matrix of nearly all tissues, but more concentrated in the skin and umbilical cord, bone, cartilage, joints (synovial fluid), vitreous humor in the eye, as well as in embryonic tissues. It plays a role in cell migration during morphogenesis and wound repair. The high concentrations of hyaluronic acid together with chondroitin sulfates in the cartilage contribute to its compressibility.
  • Chondroitin Sulfates (Chondroitin 4-Sulfate & Chondroitin 6-Sulfate): The repeating disaccharide units are GlcUA and GalNAc. They maintain the structure of the extracellular matrix and are located in endochondral bone and cartilage. They are also found in high amounts in the ECM of the central nervous system. In addition to their structural function, they act as signaling molecules in the prevention of the repair of nerve endings after injury.
  • Keratan Sulfates I & II: They consist of repeating Gal-GlcNAc disaccharide units. They are found in the cornea and in the cartilage. Keratin sulfate I or II are differentiated based on the different linkage to the core protein. They play a critical role in corneal transparency. Changes in the proteoglycan composition are seen in corneal scars.
  • Heparin: Heparin is found in the granules of mast cells and also in the liver, lung, and skin and is an important anticoagulant. It is released into the blood from capillary walls by the action of lipoprotein lipase and it binds with factors IX and XI. Its most important interaction is with plasma antithrombin.
  • Heparan Sulfate: It is found on many extracellular cell surfaces. The predominant uronic acid is GlcUA. Heparan sulfates are associated with the plasma membrane of cells as receptors, and may also participate in the mediation of cell growth and cell-cell communication. It is also found in the basement membrane of the kidney and determines the charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration.
  • Dermatan Sulfate: Dermatan sulfate has a widespread distribution in tissues, and is the main GAG in the skin. It may also play a part in blood coagulation, wound repair, and resistance to infection.

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady with a known history of mitral stenosis presented with 8 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test. Which of the following is not true about labor and delivery in this case?

choices.text: Oxytocin is used to control hemorrhage

questions.solution:
From the given options, the false statement about the management of mitral valve stenosis is option D. 

Epidural analgesia is safe in most heart diseases and is not contraindicated.

Management during labor in heart diseases like mitral stenosis: 

Vaginal delivery is preferred over cesarean, and induction of labor is safe. Induction can be done with vaginal PGE2.

First stage of labor:

  • Lateral semirecumbent position
  • Oxygen administration (5 to 6 L/min)
  • Analgesia by epidural, combined epidural/spinal, or continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Fluids should not be infused at more than 75 mL/h
  • Prophylactic antibiotics for bacterial endocarditis during labor and 48 h after delivery
  • Central venous pressure monitoring

Second stage of labor:

  • No maternal pushing
  • Cut short second stage by forceps or ventouse under pudendal and/or perineal block anesthesia
  • Withhold IV ergometrine with the delivery of anterior shoulder

Third stage of labor:

  • Oxytocin by infusion

Cesarean delivery is reserved for obstetric indications such as:

  • Dilated aortic root >4cm
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Acute severe congestive heart failure
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis
  • Warfarin within 2 weeks of delivery
  • Emergency valve replacement immediately after delivery

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient is brought with ataxia. He recalls an episode of diarrhea last week. On examination, the patient has the eye findings shown below and absent knee jerk reflexes. Which of the following is true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: Antibodies against a ganglioside component will be present
The preceding diarrhea is unrelated to the condition
Electrodiagnostic study will reveal increased sensory response

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of ataxia, absent knee jerk, fixed and dilated pupil, and a history of diarrhea is likely to have Miller-Fisher syndrome (MFS). MFS is a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). In MFS, antibodies are seen against GQ1b, which is a ganglioside component of the nerve.

GBS is progressive, symmetric muscle weakness with absent or reduced deep tendon reflexes of variable severity. It is typically an ascending paralysis that may lead to severe respiratory muscle weakness.

In MFS, like GBS, symptoms may be preceded by a viral illness (upper respiratory tract infections or diarrhea). It classically presents as a triad of

  • Ataxia
  • Areflexia
  • Ophthalmoplegia.

The condition is usually not associated with weakness, and even if present, is very mild. It is strongly associated with antibodies to ganglioside. The prognosis for Miller-Fisher syndrome is usually good. Recovery occurs in 8-12 weeks. Some individuals are left with residual deficits. 

Electrodiagnostic studies will reveal reduced or absent sensory responses without slowing the conduction velocity. Motor nerve conduction abnormalities may be present if there is associated weakness. 

Treatment for Miller-Fisher syndrome is identical to treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome: intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis and supportive care.

  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman complains of excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden bouts of sleep. The symptoms began at the age of 11 and have been worsening. She couldn’t stay awake during her classes or exams and often dozed off standing up, while working. Eventually, she developed episodes of sudden loss of muscle tone, precipitated by strong emotions. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of narcolepsy.

It is characterized by the tetrad of: 

  1. Excessive daytime sleepiness
  2. Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone)
  3. Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations
  4. Sleep paralysis

The hallmark of narcolepsy is decreased REM latency, i.e. decreased latent period before the first REM period occurs. Normal REM latency is 90-100 minutes. In narcolepsy, REM-sleep usually occurs within 10 minutes of the onset of sleep (sleep onset REM).

Treatment: 

  • Sleep hygiene
  • Scheduled naps
  • Avoidance of alcohol and drugs that cause drowsiness
  • Drugs: 
    • Modafinil (wakefulness-promoting drug) is the drug of choice.
    • Amphetamines
    • Methylphenidate

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient with chronic kidney disease comes for a routine follow-up. His chest radiograph is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a mitral annular calcification. It is a chronic degenerative process affecting the mitral valve ring and can be a rheumatic sequela. 

The clinical vignette gives clues towards the multiple co-morbidities and complications that may be associated with MAC. 

  • Stroke
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Chronic Kidney Disease 
  • Mitral Regurgitation 
  • Mitral Stenosis 
  • Arrhythmias, atrial fibrillation 
  • Endocarditis 
  • Aortic Stenosis 

Surgical treatment is indicated only if concomitant stenosis or regurgitation is to be corrected. Severe MAC makes the surgery difficult. Isolated MAC does not require endocarditis prophylaxis. Anti-coagulation and anti-platelet medications are recommended within the guidelines of treatment of the comorbid conditions. 

Other options:

Option A - In aortic sclerosis, there can be aortic valvular calcifications with cardiomegaly. Signs of heart failure such as pulmonary venous congestion and pulmonary interstitial/alveolar edema can be seen. 

Option C - Atrial Myxomas have non-specific x-ray findings- 

  • Cardiomegaly: left atrial enlargement
  • Intracardiac tumoral calcification
  • Mitral valve obstruction evidence 
  • Elevated left atrial pressure findings- pulmonary edema

Option D - A calcified atrial thrombus is a rare entity that may show up as calcified lesions in the cardiac shadow on a chest x-ray. They are usually discovered by transthoracic echocardiography.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the dermatology clinic with the condition shown in the image below. The discoloration started as a streak in the nail which progressed proximally to involve the entire nail. Which among the following drugs is available as a nail lacquer for the treatment of a mild version of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem is suggestive of onychomycosis for which amorolfine, is available as a nail lacquer for the treatment. Oxiconazole, griseofulvin, and tioconazole are not available as nail lacquers.

Onychomycosis or tinea unguium refers to the invasion of the nail plate by dermatophytes, or other fungi like Neoscytalidium, non‐ dermatophyte molds, and Candida. 

Distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis (DLSO) is the most common and usually presents as a streak or a patch of yellow or white discoloration at the free edge of the nail plate. It then spreads towards the base of the nail and may become dark brown or black. There is an accumulation of soft subungual hyperkeratosis, thickening of the nail plate, and the nail may eventually crack.

Further invasion can lead to massive destruction of the nail plate,  known as total dystrophic onychomycosis. It can spread to other digits as well.

Treatment:

First-line drugs- Oral terbinafine for 6 weeks for fingernails and for 3 months for toenails. Itraconazole is given for 2-3 months for fingernails and 3-4 months for toenails.

Topical treatment can be used for mild infections affecting the distal nail plate only or non‐linear superficial onychomycosis. Amorolfine is available for nail lacquer that can be painted on the nail. It is applied after abrading the nail once or twice weekly. It is more effective when used with terbinafine or itraconazole as a combination therapy for onychomycosis.

Other options:

Option B: Oxiconazole is administered as a 1% cream or lotion for topical use.

Option C: Griseofulvin is administered orally.

Option D: Tioconazole is administered as a nail solution, ointment, or cream but not as a nail lacquer.

questions.text: A patient presents with ptosis and restricted ocular movements that have gotten progressively worse over a period of time. There is no exacerbation or remission. Initially, the upgaze was involved with subsequent lateral gaze involvement. The patient does not complain of diplopia and the pupils are not involved. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The classical presentation of ptosis with progressively declining ocular movement is characteristic of chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO).

CPEO may occur in isolation, in association with Kearns-Sayre syndrome (mitochondrial myopathy associated with mitochondrial DNA deletions), or oculopharyngeal dystrophy.

Isolated CPEO usually presents with bilateral ptosis as the first sign. It may be asymmetrical. It usually begins in young adulthood and is typically characterized by a progressive course without remission or exacerbation. At first, only the upgaze is involved, and later, the lateral gaze is also affected. Since the loss of eye movement is symmetrical, diplopia is rare. Pupils are not involved.

Electromyography shows myotonic and myopathic potentials and serum creatine kinase is elevated.

Treatment involves exercise and the prevention of contractures. A minority of patients with diplopia may benefit from surgery.

Other options:

Options A and D- In cranial nerve palsies, there would be associated diplopia.

Option C- In ocular myasthenia gravis, diplopia is very commonly seen.

questions.text: A group of scientists is studying a protein. They electrophorese the protein and transfer it to a membrane. The proteins are visualized by tagging them to specific antibodies. This procedure is called:
questions.solution:
The above procedure depicts Western blot technique. This technique is used to study protein molecules. The proteins undergo electrophoresis and then are transferred to a membrane. These proteins are then tagged with the specific antibodies and visualized. 

Northern blot technique is used to detect RNAs. The RNAs are separated by electrophoresis and then transferred to a membrane and bound to radiolabelled probes.

Southern blot technique is used to detect DNAs. In this technique, DNA is extracted from the cells and is cleaved into many fragments using a restriction enzyme. The resulting fragments are separated based on the size using electrophoresis. The DNA fragments are then denatured and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane for analysis. The DNA fragment of interest is then identified using the specific DNA probe.

questions.text: The body of a missing person was found tied up in a boat. During the autopsy, you notice the presence of the following organism in his brain tissue. Which of the following is not a possible cause for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a diatom. Postmortem drowning does not show diatoms in the brain tissue.

Diatoms are microscopic unicellular or colonial algae present in water. As the diatoms are found in both seawater and freshwater, their presence cannot differentiate between freshwater and seawater drowning.

The presence of diatoms in the brain tissue is suggestive of antemortem drowning, as only a living person can transport diatoms from the lungs to the viscera via circulation.

questions.text: A primigravida at 39 weeks of gestation presents with watery discharge per vagina and regular contractions. Physical examination reveals an adequately dilated and effaced cervix with rupture of membranes. Presentation is vertex, but labor stops progressing after the head has appeared in the vulva.  Which of the following maneuvers can be used to assist in the delivery of the head?
questions.solution:
Ritgen maneuver can be used to assist with the delivery of the head in normal labor.

When the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm, a gloved hand may be used for supporting the perineum in order to avoid expulsive delivery and to avoid perineal lacerations.

If the expulsive efforts are inadequate, the Ritgen maneuver is employed for assisted delivery of the head. This is accomplished by pushing the chin upward with the fingers of the right hand (positioned over the anococcygeal region), while the left hand exerts pressure on the occiput. Hence, the head is delivered by extension. 

The image below demonstrates the Ritgen maneuver:

 

Other options-

Option (A): Pinard maneuver is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of frank breech delivery.

Frank breech delivery (Pinard’s maneuver)—is done by intrauterine manipulation to convert a frank breech to a footing breech. Pinard maneuver is usually performed when the membranes have ruptured recently.

Technique:

  • The middle and index fingers are carried up to the popliteal fossa.
  • Then press and abduct the popliteal fossa so as to flex the fetal leg
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction and breech extraction is accomplished.

 

Option (B): Lovset maneuver used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

This technique is demonstrated in the images below-

 

Option (C): Modified Prague’s maneuver(shown below) is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was treated for a high-grade soft-tissue sarcoma with radiotherapy. Since he was not responding, he was shifted to chemotherapy. After initiating chemotherapy, he developed erythematous rashes over the areas where radiotherapy was administered earlier. Which of the following drugs is likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Doxorubicin can result in a radiation recall reaction where erythema and desquamation of skin are observed at sites of previous radiation injury. 

Radiation recall syndrome is an acute inflammatory response confined to the areas that are previously irradiated, which can be triggered by the administration of chemotherapeutic agents. Studies show that the common drugs causing this phenomenon are:

  • Doxorubicin
  • Docetaxel and paclitaxel
  • Gemcitabine and capecitabine

Radiation sensitization - This is more common than radiation recall. This is a period of enhanced sensitivity in the days after irradiation when the reaction to systemically administered drugs and the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is <7 days. Such reactions can be considered radiation enhancement or sensitization. 

Radiation recall - This is less common than radiation sensitization. When the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is >7 days, months, or even years.

The major side effects of doxorubicin are: 

  • Myelosuppression 
  • Cardiomyopathy.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old female patient has not attained menarche. Examination reveals short stature, webbed neck, low posterior hairline, widely spaced nipples, no axillary or pubic hair, and normal external genitalia. USG abdomen shows a small uterus and streak ovaries. FSH and LH are increased. What is the likely cause of amenorrhea?

USG - Ultrasound

FSH - Follicle-stimulating hormone

LH - Luteinizing hormone
questions.solution:
The likely cause of amenorrhea in this patient is primary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. 

Primary amenorrhea refers to the failure of onset of menstruation, beyond the age of 16 years regardless of the development of secondary sexual characteristics. This patient's clinical picture of amenorrhea, short stature, webbed neck, low posterior hairline, widely spaced nipples, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics is seen in Turner's syndrome. Turner's syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality with partial or complete monosomy of the X chromosome (45+XO).

In Turner's syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis causes primary ovarian failure that is hypogonadism. The levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH) are indicative of the cause of hypogonadism. Increased levels of FSH and LH as seen in this patient are indicative of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism is defined as 1) a decrease or absence in ovarian function and 2) due to absent negative sex-steroid feedback. 

The pathophysiology in Turner's syndrome is primary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism where there is oocyte atresia and the replacement of ovaries by fibrous streaks. This causes a decrease in serum estrogen levels which by negative feedback causes a rise in gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), FSH, and LH (gonadotropic hormones) as seen in this patient. Hypogonadism with a rise in gonadotropic hormones is known as hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

Other options-

Option (B): Secondary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism patients also present with primary ovarian failure with increased levels of FSH and LH. Secondary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism is seen in damage to the gonads as seen post-chemotherapy, radiation, infection, or in autoimmune disorders. This patient has no history suggestive of a secondary cause.

Options (C and D): Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism results when there is a primary abnormality in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. Loss of hypothalamic function causes a decrease in the production of GnRH or pituitary dysfunction causes decreased production of FSH and LH which results in decreased ovarian function and reduced serum estrogen levels. It can be divided into:

  • Inherited hypothalamic abnormalities: Kallmann's syndrome (Option C)
  • Acquired (functional) hypothalamic dysfunction: eating disorders, in patients who exercise excessively, and during periods of stress (Option D). Although this patient is an athlete, her FSH and LH levels are increased suggesting hypergonadotropism.

questions.text: A child was brought to a pediatrician with tense blisters, vesicles, and annular erythema. A biopsy of the lesion showed the linear deposition of IgA antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction. What is the first-line drug used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with tense blisters, vesicles, and annular erythema showing IgA antibodies deposition at dermo-epidermal junction is diagnostic of linear IgA disease. Dapsone is the first-line drug used in the management of this condition.

Linear IgA disease is a subepidermal blistering disease, characterized by tense blisters and annular erythema. It is commonly seen in infants and children. These blisters and vesicles develop in an annular pattern which gives rise to a string‐of‐pearls or crown of jewels pattern. Mucosal involvement is common.

The images below show linear IgA dermatosis at various sites. Image C shows a string-of-pearls pattern of blisters and crusts in the perioral area.


The biopsy will show the presence of linear deposits of IgA antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction. Dapsone is the first-line drug used in the management of this condition.

Direct immunofluorescence showing linear IgA deposition at the dermo-epidermal junction is seen in the image below.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the medical intensive care unit.  There is a patient admitted there with heart failure. He has low cardiac output with oliguria. Which of the following inotropes would be preferred in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Dopamine is used in the treatment of severe congestive heart failure, particularly in patients with oliguria as it improves renal function.

It is administered at 2–5 mcg/kg/min intravenously. Stimulation of dopaminergic and β-adrenergic receptors produces increased glomerular filtration, heart rate, and contractility.

Other options:

Option A: Epinephrine (adrenaline) is a potent stimulant of both α- and β-adrenergic receptors. It increases cardiac contractility but decreases renal perfusion. It is mainly used in anaphylactic shock.

Option B: Norepinephrine is a potent α and β1 agonist, with very little effect on the β2 receptor. It can be used to raise blood pressure in intensive care conditions, but since it decreases the renal blood flow, it is not preferred in the above clinical scenario.

Option D: Fenoldopam is an agonist for peripheral D1 receptors and is used to control hypertension.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient came to your orthopedic clinic with complaints of pain in the hips and knees. You suspect osteoarthritis of the hips and knees and request an X-ray, findings of which are attached below. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis of her incidental finding?
questions.solution:
The incidental X-ray findings showing extensive calcification of the femoral arteries in this patient which are strongly suggestive of Monckeberg medial sclerosis. It is caused due to calcification in the medial walls of muscular arteries starting at the internal elastic lamina.

It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. Since the calcifications do not encroach on the vessel lumen and are usually not clinically significant. Therefore, it is usually an incidental finding as in this case. 

Histopathological examination reveals calcification that is seen as the dark purple stained area on the H&E staining as shown in the image below.

 

Other options:

Option A- Injection sclerotherapy is used for the management of varicose veins. In this technique, a detergent-like sodium tetradecyl sulfate is injected directly into the superficial veins. It destroys the venous endothelium. Following this, an elastic bandage is wrapped around the limb to cause apposition of the vessel walls. Therefore, the radiograph of the patient does not appear like the above.

Option C- Leriche's syndrome is a rare form of the aortoiliac occlusive disease which presents with a triad of intermittent claudication, erectile dysfunction, and absent femoral pulses.

Option D- Deep vein thrombosis is caused due to 3 broad categories of risk factors (Virchow's triad):

  • Hemodynamic changes (stasis or turbulence)
  • Hypercoagulability 
  • Endothelial injury

DVT most commonly occurs in the calf veins. DVT is usually asymptomatic. Some patients may present with pain in the calf or thigh. Duplex ultrasound is used in identifying venous thrombosis.

questions.text: A patient was administered rocuronium as a muscle relaxant during surgery. However, the surgeon was able to finish the procedure sooner than expected. What specific reversal agent will you use?
questions.solution:
The specific reversal agent that can terminate the action of rocuronium is sugammadex.

Sugammadex is a cyclodextrin. It is the first selective relaxant binding agent. It acts by forming complexes with steroidal non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium, vecuronium).

Rocuronium at higher doses can be used in rapid sequence intubation. However, the only downside is its long duration of action. This obstacle can be overcome by sugammadex, which will reverse its effects.

Other options-

Option (A): Neostigmine reversal requires a baseline twitch response. Sugammadex, on the other hand, can be administered at any depth muscle blockade, thereby making it more useful.

Option (C) and Option (D): Atropine and glycopyrrolate are administered along with anticholinesterases pre-operatively to reduce muscarinic side effects like bradycardia. They are not used to reverse neuromuscular blockade.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic patient has an episode of seizure. He had a headache for 2 days and two episodes of vomiting. He had a right earache with discharge one week ago. He is drowsy, and has nystagmus and ataxia. A brain abscess is suspected. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical picture is suggestive of a brain abscess. The next best step in the management of this patient is to perform a neuroimaging study and MRI brain is superior to CT in diagnosing brain abscesses.

A brain abscess is a focal, suppurative infection within the brain parenchyma, typically surrounded by a vascularized capsule. The term cerebritis describes a nonencapsulated brain abscess.

The most common presenting symptom of a brain abscess is headache, which is a dull aching pain that progressively worsens and becomes refractory to therapy. Fever, headache, and focal neurological deficits from the classic triad of brain abscess are present in only half the patients. The expanding brain abscess increases the intracranial pressure which typically presents as the Cushing's triad - bradycardia, irregular respiration, and increased blood pressure with widened pulse pressure. 

This patient's ataxia and nystagmus suggest a cerebellar involvement. Further, this patient has a history of otitis media (earache and discharge) which is the most common source of infection for a cerebellar brain abscess.

MRI Brain is superior to diagnosing a brain abscess when compared to a CT scan, in evaluating abscesses in the posterior fossa. MRI is also superior to CT in the early cerebritis stage of development of brain abscess.

On contrast-enhanced T1-weighted MRI, a mature brain abscess has a capsule that enhances surrounding a hypointense center. It is surrounded by a hypointense area of edema. On T2-weighted MRI, there is a hyperintense central area of pus surrounded by a well-defined hypointense capsule and a hyperintense surrounding area of edema.

In patients with signs of increased intracranial pressure, lumbar puncture is contraindicated as it increases the risk of herniation. 

MRI Venography is used to confirm the diagnosis of septic thrombophlebitis of cerebral venous sinuses. The patients present similarly with fever, headache, signs of raised ICP, and focal neurological lesions. However, the next best step in the management of this patient even if septic venous thrombosis is suspected, is an MRI brain which shows an absent flow void within the affected venous sinus. This is further confirmed by MRI venography, CT angiogram, or the venous phase of cerebral angiography.

questions.text: A patient presented to the primary health center with symptoms of sneezing, runny nose, and red, itchy, watery eyes. He was prescribed azelastine after being diagnosed with allergic rhinitis. Select the preferred formulation of the drug in this patient.
questions.solution:
The preferred formulation of azelastine in this patient would be an intranasal spray. 

Azelastine is a second-generation antihistamine that has good topical activity. It is available as a nasal spray for treating symptoms of allergic or vasomotor rhinitis and is also available as an ophthalmic solution for allergic conjunctivitis.

On intranasal application, it downregulates ICAM-1 expression on the nasal mucosa. It has a long duration of action and is administered as a nasal spray to provide relief in cases of allergic rhinitis, with its effect lasting for up to 12 hours.

On local application, it can cause altered taste perception and stinging in the nose while oral administration can also result in weight gain. The metabolism of azelastine is inhibited by CYP3A4 inhibitors.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with a gestation of 8 weeks comes to your clinic. While examining her, you notice she has severe acne. She tells you she has been taking oral medication and was advised to avoid excessive sun exposure while taking this drug. Which of the following is not a potential teratogenic effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
Oral medication for acne is likely to be isotretinoin. Macrognathia is not a potential teratogenic effect of isotretinoin.

Vitamin A derivatives(isotretinoin, acitretin) belong amongst the drugs with high teratogenic effects. They result in retinoic acid embryopathy by inhibiting neural crest cell migration during embryogenesis. This causes cranial neural crest defects involving the central nervous system, face, thymus, and heart. 

Specific anomalies include

  • Ventriculomegaly
  • Maldevelopment of the facial bones and cranium
  • Microtia or anotia
  • Micrognathia
  • Cleft palate
  • Conotruncal heart defects
  • Thymic aplasia or hypoplasia

Systemic retinoids are highly teratogenic and are absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women, those planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding mothers. Two negative pregnancy tests (on separate occasions) are required for females of childbearing age before starting acitretin or isotretinoin.

Baseline evaluation of serum lipids, transaminases, and CBC should be done before starting any systemic retinoids. These values should be checked monthly for the first 3–6 months and once every 3 months thereafter. Monthly pregnancy tests should be done while on the drug. Female patients should avoid conception for 3 years after discontinuing acitretin treatment for cutaneous psoriasis.

questions.text: A man suffered from a stab injury to his hand and the muscle marked in the image below is injured. Which of the following movements will be affected in him?
questions.solution:
The muscle injured is the abductor pollicis brevis. Injury to this muscle will lead to loss of abduction of the thumb. Abduction of the thumb refers to the drawing of the thumb ventrally in a plane that is at the right angle to the palm of the hand.

The abductor pollicis brevis is a thin subcutaneous muscle that is a part of the thenar eminence. It arises from the flexor retinaculum, tubercles of the scaphoid, and trapezium bone. Its medial fibers are attached to the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, and its lateral fibres join the dorsal digital expansion of the thumb.

It helps in the abduction of the thumb. 

Other muscles of the thenar eminence

Medial to abductor pollicis brevis muscle is the flexor pollicis brevis. It flexes the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb.

Adductor pollicis arises by oblique and transverse heads. The oblique head attaches to the capitate bone, bases of the second and third metacarpal bones, palmar ligament, and tendon of flexor carpi radialis. However, the majority of the fibers unite to form a tendon which is attached to the ulnar side of the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. It helps in the adduction of the thumb. Adduction is the approximation of the thumb to the palm of the hand.

Opponens pollicis muscle lies deep to the abductor pollicis brevis. It is attached to the lateral half of the palmar surface of the metacarpal bone of the thumb. It flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.

All the thenar muscles are supplied by the median nerve with the exception of the deep head of flexor pollicis brevis and adductor pollicis which are supplied by ulnar nerves.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient was brought to you by his wife, who complains that he tends to collect unwanted things and does not allow these things to be thrown away. She shows you the following photograph of their house, which has gradually become this way over the last 8 years. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

choices.text: Driven by an obsessive fear of losing important items
Patients do not perceive this as a problem
Full remission is achieved after treatment
CBT is the most effective management

questions.solution:
The image shows the house of a person with hoarding disorder. Full remission is rarely achieved, as patients lack insight into their behavior. 

The disorder is characterized by acquiring and not discard­ing things that are of little or no value, resulting in excessive clutter of living spaces, driven by an obsessive fear of losing important items that the person believes may be useful in the future. It was con­sidered a subtype of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) but is now considered to be a separate diagnostic entity. 

Most hoarders do not perceive their hoarding as a problem and believe it is a reasonable part of their identity. There is an inability to organize their possessions and they often hoard to avoid making decisions about discarding items. Patients with hoarding disorder overemphasize the importance of recall­ing information and possessions.

Commonly hoarded items include newspapers, mail, magazines, clothes, bags, books, and notes. Clutter accumulated from hoarding can lead to deaths from fires or patients being crushed by their possessions. It may also attract pest infesta­tions.

The most effective treatment for the disorder is cognitive-behavioral therapy which involves training in decision making and categorizing exposure and habituation to discarding, and cognitive restructuring. This includes both office and in-home sessions. It is less respon­sive to classic treatments for OCD such as exposure therapy and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRis).

questions.text: A 54-year-old lady who is a known case of diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years, presents with rashes over shin as shown in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is necrobiosis lipoidica.

The given image shows an erythematous rash with ulceration and healing over the shin. This clinical presentation in a diabetic patient is indicative of necrobiosis lipoidica.

Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is a rare chronic and granulomatous skin disorder that is seen in diabetic patients. The most likely etiology is microangiopathy. Most rashes are located on the legs, especially above the tibiae. The patches are initially brown and later may progress to yellow atrophic plaques.

Option A: Granuloma annulare is most commonly found in children and females <30 years. It manifests as groups of 1-2mm papules that range from skin-colored to violaceous, in an annular arrangement over distal extremities. There is no confirmed association with diabetes.

Below image shows granuloma annulare

Option C: Sarcoidosis is commonly associated with erythema nodosum. In addition to these, there is the involvement of the lymph nodes, lungs, eyes, and other organ systems.

Below image shows skin lesions in sarcoidosis

Option D: Necrobiotic xanthogranuloma manifests as reddish-brown nodules and plaques over the legs and trunk. It is associated with hematological malignancies.

Below image shows lesions of necrobiotic xanthogranuloma

questions.text: A  newborn male baby was found to have a very small occiput and posterior fossa. MRI imaging showed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a baby with a very small occiput and posterior fossa and an image showing herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum is suggestive of Chiari malformation. It is the most common malformation of the posterior fossa and hindbrain.

Children present with headaches that are worse with straining and other maneuvers that increase intracranial pressure. Symptoms of
brainstem compression, such as diplopia, oropharyngeal dysfunction, spasticity, tinnitus, sleep apnea, and vertigo, can occur due to brain stem compression. Incidental Chiari malformation with radiological findings compatible with Chiari malformation with no clinical manifestations of the disease is also seen. 

Chiari malformations are classified based on their morphology and severity of anatomic defects, typically through imaging or autopsy to Chiari I - Chiari IV. The Chiari I malformation is the most common type evaluated using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), typically in a child or adult. Chiari II to IV malformations is often first evaluated by ultrasound in utero, with fetal MRI assessment performed for further characterization.

Muscle relaxants, NSAIDs, and the temporary use of a cervical collar are used to treat headaches and neck pain.  The main treatment for re-establishing the CSF flow across the craniovertebral junction and relieving pressure on the cerebellum and hindbrain by decompressing the posterior fossa in Chiari malformation is surgical. This can be achieved by a suboccipital craniectomy in conjunction with C1 and C2 laminectomy. 

Other options:

Option A- Mega cisterna magna/ Arachanoid cyst can also cause hydrocephalus. It is characterized by an enlarged CSF space inferior and dorsal to the cerebellar vermis. Persisting Blake pouch is a cyst that obstructs the subarachnoid space. 

The image below shows a CT of an arachnoid cyst. 

 

Option B- Joubert syndrome is an autosomal recessive ciliopathy associated with cerebellar vermis hypoplasia and molar tooth sign (a deepening of the interpeduncular fossa with thick and straight superior cerebellar peduncles). It is characterized by developmental delay, hypotonia, ataxia, breathing abnormalities including episodic apnea and hyperpnea.

The image below shows an MRI of Joubert syndrome demonstrating the molar tooth sign.  

 

Option C- Dandy-Walker syndrome is a congenital malformation that involves:

  • Cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle
  • Hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Enlargement of the posterior fossa.

The below MRI shows dilation of the fourth ventricle with hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented with diarrhea, floating stools, and weight loss for 3 months. The biopsy of the intestine is shown below. His symptoms improved with folic acid intake. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a young man presenting with diarrhea, floating stools, and weight loss with histopathology showing partial villous atrophy and marked intraepithelial lymphocytosis indicating inflammation of lamina propria and improvement with folic acid intake is suggestive of tropical sprue.

Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition that causes chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, and folate and vitamin B12 malabsorption. It occurs in some tropical regions and is often considered a postinfectious complication. Diagnosis is based on a small intestinal biopsy showing villous atrophy and chronic inflammation, similar to celiac disease. However, tropical sprue is unresponsive to a gluten-free diet.

Treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., tetracycline for up to six months) and folic acid supplementation, which can lead to improvement within weeks. Patients often recover fully if they leave the endemic area. Folic acid alone can improve symptoms and correct hematologic deficiencies, but antibiotics are typically needed for complete resolution.

Other options:

Option A: Celiac disease is a gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Patients present with iron deficiency anemia, weight loss, diarrhea, and malabsorption. A biopsy reveals blunting of the villi, crypt hyperplasia, and inflammation propria. Tissue transglutaminase is involved in the pathogenesis of this disorder. Patients respond to a gluten-free diet. The image below shows histopathological findings seen in celiac disease.

Option B: Whipple's disease is a multiorgan disease caused by the bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It is characterized by arthralgia, arthritis, weight loss, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and psychiatric manifestations. The organism can be detected by tissue immunohistochemistry and tissue staining for PAS-positive macrophages. The below image shows the PAS stain in Whipple's disease.

Option D: Short bowel syndrome is characterized by extensive removal of the small intestine. The loss of small-bowel surface area leads to severe diarrhea, weight loss, and problems absorbing fat, protein, and carbohydrates.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presents with complaints of foggy vision. He mentions that he cannot read newspapers. He is a heavy tobacco smoker for the past 30 years. Examination revealed a centrocecal scotoma. What is the most important step in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of tobacco-induced optic neuropathy. Complete abstinence from smoking is the most important step in management in this case.

Tobacco-induced optic neuropathy (previously termed toxic amblyopia) is caused by excessive use of tobacco by smoking and chewing. The toxic agent involved is cyanide found in tobacco.

The illustration given below shows the pathogenesis of tobacco-induced optic neuropathy.

It is characterized by bilateral gradually progressive impairment of central vision, and a centrocecal scotoma - a type of central scotoma involving both the blind spot and macula. Fundus examination may be normal or slight temporal pallor of the disc may be seen.

Treatment includes

  • Complete cessation of tobacco and alcohol consumption.
  • Improvement may be hastened by hydroxocobalamin 1000 μg intramuscular injections weekly for 10 weeks. Though intramuscular vitamin B12 injection may hasten the recovery, eliminating the causative factor i.e. tobacco cessation should be the mainstay of treatment. 
  • Nutritional supplements.

Causes of central/centrocecal scotoma

  • Optic neuritis
  • Compressive lesion eg. pituitary adenoma
  • Optic neuropathy due to
    • Poor nutrition
    • Tobacco
    • Alcohol
  • Drug-induced optic neuropathy
  • Toxin-induced optic neuropathy
  • Hereditary optic atrophy
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Leukemia

questions.text: After crowning was established in a patient in labor, the obstetrician uses the instrument shown below to give a liberal episiotomy. By doing so, what grade of perineal injury is the obstetrician iatrogenically inflicting?
questions.solution:
The image shows an episiotomy scissor, which can be identified by its angulation. It is used to perform an episiotomy. During episiotomy, the obstetrician iatrogenically induces a second-degree perineal tear.

Episiotomy refers to the surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor. It is an induced second-degree perineal tear that involves the perineal muscles but spares the anal sphincter. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

Timely episiotomy prevents third and fourth-degree perineal tears, which affect the anal sphincter.

Structures cut in episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, levator ani muscles
  • Fascia covering the muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and perineal skin

The objective is to enlarge the vaginal introitus so as to facilitate easy and safe delivery of the fetus and to minimize overstretching and rupture of the perineal muscles and fascia, which might end up in complete tears.

Episiotomies are either midline or mediolateral:

Midline Episiotomy Mediolateral Episiotomy
Surgical Repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is lesser Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative comfort is maximum

Postoperative discomfort is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the rectum

Relative safety from rectal involvement from extension 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: FIGLU (Formiminoglutamic acid) excretion test is used in the assessment of the deficiency of which of the following vitamins?
questions.solution:
FIGLU excretion test is used in the assessment of deficiency of Vitamin B9 (Folic acid).

FIGLU is converted to L-glutamate by the enzyme glutamate formimino transferase. This enzyme uses folate (vitamin B9). In Vitamin B9 deficiency, FIGLU accumulates in the body and is excreted in the urine.

Folic acid is a water-soluble vitamin, and its active form is tetrahydrofolate (THFA). It acts as a carrier of one-carbon groups. These one-carbon groups are attached either to the 5th, 10th, or both 5th and 10th nitrogen atoms of THFA.

The methyl group in N5-methyl THFA is used for the synthesis of active methionine. This takes part in transmethylation reactions required for the synthesis of choline, epinephrine, creatine, etc.

Folate deficiency results in

  • Reduced synthesis of DNA
  • Macrocytic anemia
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia
  • Neural tube defects in the fetus like spina bifida

questions.text:
A male child presents with poor growth. Examination reveals bowing of legs, frontal bossing, and pectus carinatum. The X-ray is shown below. Laboratory investigations reveal that the disease is due to decreased dietary intake. Which of the following would not be seen in this patient?

PTH - Parathyroid Hormone

ALP - Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of rickets and decreased serum PTH would not be seen in this patient. PTH is elevated in rickets.

The clinical vignette describing a child with bowing of legs, frontal bossing, poor growth, pectus carinatum, and x-ray findings showing cupping and fraying of the bilateral distal metaphysis of radius and ulna with growth plate widening are suggestive of rickets. The laboratory findings on rickets would be:

  • Normal/decreased serum calcium
  • Decreased phosphorous
  • Elevated PTH, and
  • Increased ALP levels

Rickets occurs due to a nutritional deficiency in vitamin D. Decreased vitamin D leads to decreased calcium and phosphate due to reduced absorption. The decreased calcium stimulates increased PTH production. ALP level is increased as it is involved in bone mineralization.

Clinical features of rickets include general features such as malnourishment, abdominal distension, proximal muscle weakness, etc.

Head-

  • Softening of the skull bones, called craniotabes. 
  • Delayed closure of fontanells.

Chest-

  • Typical rachitic rosary i.e. widening of the costochondral junctions that give the feeling of rosary beads on palpation.
  • Harrison's groove, a horizontal groove in the lower chest, may appear from the inward pull of the softened ribs by the diaphragm during respiration.

Other bony abnormalities-

  • Vertebral column abnormalities like scoliosis, kyphosis, and lordosis can also appear
  • In the distal extremities- widening of the wrists and ankles, varus/ valgus deformities, windswept deformity (valgus on the side and varus on the contralateral side), anterior tibial bowing, etc

An image showing cupping and fraying is shown below-
