Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: During your labor room postings, you perform a cardiotocography (CTG) on a woman who is in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. The tracing that you obtain is as shown in the image below. Which among the following is commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows late decelerations. The fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Causes of late decelerations:

  • Placental pathologies like - post-maturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

The CTG given below shows early decelerations. The deceleration coincides with the uterine contractions. It seen in fetal head compression.

The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: An 82-year-old male patient dies of severe congestive heart failure. An autopsy was done, which revealed the following appearance of the aortic valve. Blood investigations done before death revealed normal levels of serum sodium, potassium, calcium, and chloride. Which of the following pathological processes is likely to have resulted in the appearance of the aortic valve as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows extensive calcification of the aortic valve resulting in stenosis. Calcification of the valve, in an elderly patient, with normal serum calcium levels, occurs due to dystrophic calcification.

When the deposition of calcium occurs in dead or dying tissues, it is called dystrophic calcification. This occurs in the absence of derangements in calcium metabolism, i.e. the calcium levels are normal. Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type including coagulative, caseous, or liquefactive, and in foci of enzymatic fat necrosis.

Some examples include atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis and areas of caseous necrosis in tuberculosis. It also commonly develops in aging or damaged heart valves.

Other options:

Option A - Cardiac amyloidosis may occur secondary to systemic amyloidosis or as a result of aging (senile amyloidosis). It is associated with the deposition of hyaline, eosinophilic amyloid, in the conduction tissue, interstitium, and coronary vessels. These deposits may be seen on Congo red staining.

Option B - Monckeberg medial sclerosis is a vascular pathology of aging characterized by calcifications accumulating in the medial layers of muscular arteries. Since there is no vascular compromise (no luminal narrowing), it is usually an accidental finding.

Option D - Metastatic calcification occurs in normal tissues, in the presence of hypercalcemia. It is usually a consequence of excessive parathyroid hormone.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl child is brought for a routine health check-up. On examination, the attending physician hears an additional third heart sound. What is this probably due to?

choices.text: Late ventricular filling through active atrial contraction
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Rapid filling phase of the ventricular diastole
Closure of mitral  and tricuspid valves

questions.solution:
The third heart sound is due to the rapid filling phase of the ventricular diastole.

In about one-third of the way through diastole, a soft low-pitched third heart sound is heard in many normal young individuals. It occurs probably due to the vibrations set up by the inrush of blood during the early phase of ventricular diastole, not during ventricular systole.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with amenorrhea for the past 4 months. On performing USG, you notice the presence of twin gestation, with a characteristic appearance as shown in the image below. When will the division of the inner cell mass occur in this type of twin gestation?
questions.solution:
The given USG image depicts the T sign, which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation, for which division of the inner cell mass occurs at 4–8 days. 

Time of division Type of twin gestation
<3 days  Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) 
4–8 days Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
>8 days Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days  Conjoint twins

 

"T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, the twins are separated only by the two amniotic membranes, with no intervening chorion. So, a thin T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the latter part of the first trimester or at the beginning of the second trimester. In monochorionic monoamniotic gestation, there is an absence of a dividing membrane.

In dichorionic gestation, the twins are separated by amniotic membranes and an intervening chorion. So, a thicker twin peak sign or lambda (λ) sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the first trimester.

Related Pearl: Twinning

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 52-year-old lady came to you in the outpatient department in the peripheral setting. She repeatedly self-medicates with antacid tablets. She complains of numbness in her hands. Which of the following is false with regards to the condition she is suffering from?

choices.text: Pernicious anemia is the most common cause
Upper limbs are affected before lower limbs
Methylmalonic acid, homocysteine levels are elevated
Myopathy is a key feature of the disease

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario indicates vitamin B12 deficiency due to chronic antacid use, leading to neuropathy. Myopathy is not a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency.

A myopathy is a muscle disease that is unrelated to any disorder of innervation or neuromuscular junction. The common symptoms of myopathy include muscle weakness, impaired function in activities of daily life, and very rarely, muscle pain, and tenderness. 

Acid lowering agents like proton pump inhibitors alter the hydrogen ion secretion into the stomach leading to an increase in gastric pH. The change in pH modifies the bioavailability and absorption of vitamins and minerals, like vitamin B12. 

Pernicious anemia is the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency may produce several neurological manifestations.

A preferential large-fiber sensory loss affecting proprioception and vibration with sparing of small-fiber modalities occurs in Vitamin B12 deficiency. Upper limb paresthesias occur before lower limbs are affected. 

An unsteady gait may be seen due to sensory ataxia.

Severe cases may show optic neuropathy and behavioral changes ranging from mild irritation and forgetfulness to severe dementia and frank psychosis.

Serum methylmalonic acid and homocysteine are elevated because the enzymes which metabolize them require B12 and in a deficient state these products start building up.

questions.text: You had ordered to centrifuge a tissue sample and separate the mitochondria out to extract mitochondrial DNA for genetic evaluation. Which of the following is an enzyme marker to identify the mitochondria?
questions.solution:
ATP synthase is the enzyme marker used to identify the mitochondria. It is present in the inner mitochondrial membrane.

The membranes of cell organelles contain various proteins, some of which are enzymes. Certain enzymes are located only in particular membranes. These enzymes may be used as markers following the purification of these membranes. 

The mitochondrial matrix is enclosed by an outer membrane and a selectively permeable inner membrane. The inner membrane contains the respiratory chain enzymes, ATP synthase, and membrane transporters. 

A cytogenetic study involving mitochondrial DNA is generally done when you suspect a genetic disease inherited through the mt-DNA. 

Human mitochondria contain dsDNA that makes up approximately 1% of total cellular DNA. This mitochondrial DNA codes for mt-specific ribosomal and tRNAs as well as for 13 proteins that play roles in the respiratory chain.

Mitochondrial DNA has a high mutation rate, 5-10 times that of nuclear DNA. It is transmitted by maternal non-mendelian inheritance because all mitochondria are contributed by the ovum during the formation of the zygote.

The image attached below shows the pedigree chart pattern of mitochondrial pattern of inheritance.

questions.text:
A young man with a history of blunt abdominal trauma was brought to the emergency department. He was hemodynamically unstable, and a FAST examination revealed free fluid. An immediate laparotomy was done. The maneuver shown in the image below was performed due to severe bleeding near the liver. However, the bleeding continued. What could be the probable source of the bleeding in this case?

FAST - Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

choices.text: Both hepatic arterial and Portal venous bleeding

questions.solution:
The image shows clamping of the hepatoduodenal ligament, which is done in the Pringle maneuver. Bleeding that is not controlled by this maneuver suggests that the source of the bleeding is the hepatic vein. 

The Pringle manoeuvre is performed in surgery when there is excessive bleeding from the liver to temporarily arrest the bleeding and identify the source of the bleed, and is especially helpful in traumatic liver injury. With the occlusion of the portal triad, the inflow from the hepatic artery and portal vein are controlled, but backflow from the IVC and hepatic vein persists. After performing this maneuver, the liver laceration can be explored, and further bleeding can be controlled.

It is one of the 4 Ps in the management of liver injuries, which include: 

  • Push- Compression of the edges of the laceration
  • Pringle- Applying pressure on the portal triad
  • Plug- The defects are plugged with silicon tubes
  • Pack- Apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding

Ischemia and portal hypertension are complications that result from either prolonged clamping time during the Pringle maneuver or normal clamping time in patients with compromised liver function (eg, from cirrhosis).

questions.text: During your rotation in the forensic medicine and toxicology department, you notice the specimen of a fetus with a  length of 16 cm. What is the age of the fetus likely to be?
questions.solution:
The age of the fetus in months, calculated using the Rule of Haase, is √16 = 4 months. 

Rule of Haase enables the estimation of the age of the fetus in months from its crown-heel length (in cm) in the first 5 months. It is a rough method of calculating the age of the fetus. During the first five months of pregnancy, the square root of the length gives the approximate age of the fetus in months.

Haase's Modification of Morisson's Law:

During the last five months, the length of the fetus (in cm) divided by five gives the age in months.

Example - A fetus of length 40cm is likely to be 8 months old.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds is predominantly responsible for the disinfecting property of bleaching powder?
questions.solution:
The disinfectant property of bleaching powder is predominantly due to the action of hypochlorous acid. It is 70-80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.

Bleaching powder, also known as chlorinated lime (CaOCl2), has 33 per cent of chlorine in it. When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids. The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water. The hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen ions and hypochlorite ions, as follows:

H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl

HOCl → H + OCl

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

  • Storage
  • Filtration:
    • Slow sand filters
    • Rapid sand filters
  • Disinfection:
    • Chlorination
    • Ozonation
    • UV radiation
    • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

  • Household purification of water:
    • Boiling
    • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
    • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.
    • UV radiation
    • Multi-stage reverse osmosis
  • Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with primary infertility. She has no other complaints. On the hysterosalpingogram, the right fallopian tube has a tobacco pouch appearance. Which part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in this underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario of primary infertility and a hysterosalpingogram finding of the "tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube is suggestive of tuberculous salpingitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The ampullary part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in genital tuberculosis.     

The fallopian tubes are almost always involved in genital tuberculosis. The lesions are generally bilateral. The mode of spread of the disease is hematogenous, arising from a primary infective focus in the lung. The ampulla is most commonly affected, while the fimbriae and interstitium are spared. 

Genital tuberculosis is almost always secondary to a primary focus elsewhere. The most frequent location is the lungs (50%), although it can also come from lymph nodes (40%), kidneys, joints, the gastrointestinal system, or as part of a broad miliary infection. It mostly spreads via the haematogenous route or lymphatics sometimes. 

In Genital tuberculosis, the leading presenting complaints include infertility, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and suspicion of neoplasm. 10-15% of women are found to be asymptomatic as well. 

Hysterosalpingogram may reveal the following: 

  • Tobacco pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • Lead pipe appearance (rigid, nonperistaltic pipe)
  • Beading and variation due to filling defects
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Cornual block
  • Jagged fluffiness of tubal outline

Hysteroscopy will reveal the presence of synechiae, partial obliteration of the cavity, the golf-hole appearance of the tubal ostia, and the presence of ulcers.

questions.text: Plaster was applied to the leg of a patient with a tibial shaft fracture. This patient now presents with severe pain in the leg. On examination, the distal pulses are absent and feels pain on passive stretching of the limb. On opening the plaster, the leg appears edematous and numerous blisters are seen. What would be the most appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: Opening of the plaster is sufficient

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests acute compartment syndrome, and it is treated immediately with fasciotomy.

The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 Ps:

  • Pain: Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. Ischemic muscle is highly sensitive to touch. On the passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited. 
  • Paresthesia: Paresthesia and hypoesthesia may be noted due to compression of nerves traversing the affected compartment. They are the first signs of nerve ischemia.
  • Pallor: Pallor of the skin may not always be seen. The skin outside the compartment may be normally perfused, as only the intra-compartmental perfusion may be affected.
  • Paralysis: Paralysis of muscle groups affected in that compartment is a late sign.
  • Pulselessness: Usually, the peripheral pulses and capillary return are intact in the early stages, unless there is a major arterial injury. If pulses are absent, arteriography is indicated. 

The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as the differential pressure (ΔP). A differential pressure (ΔP) of less than 30 mm Hg (4.00 kilopascals) is an indication for immediate compartment decompression.

The threatened compartment must be promptly decompressed, merely splitting the plaster is not helpful and the limb must be kept flat. This is because elevating the limb causes a further decrease in end capillary pressure and aggravates muscle ischemia. In the case of compartment syndrome in the leg, fasciotomy should be performed. This involves opening all four compartments via medial and lateral incisions. Wounds to be left open and inspected 2 days later, if tissues are healthy, the wounds can be sutured. If there is muscle necrosis, debridement to be carried out.

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient is very conscious about her body image. She started a diet having only 20 g per day of carbohydrate or less, but with unlimited consumption of fats and proteins. Her previous diet usually had an average of 100-120 g/day of carbohydrate. What will be the effect of this new diet plan?

choices.text: Inhibits gluconeogenesis and promotes weight loss
Increases gluconeogenesis and promotes weight loss
Inhibits gluconeogenesis and promotes weight gain
Increases gluconeogenesis and promotes weight gain

questions.solution:
The given patient has adopted a very low carbohydrate diet as a new diet plan and this promotes weight loss and gluconeogenesis.

A very low carbohydrate diet, that is less than or equal to 20 grams per day of carbohydrates with unlimited consumption of fat and protein, has been promoted as an effective regime for weight loss. Since a lower amount of carbohydrates are consumed and there is a continual demand for glucose, gluconeogenesis from amino acids occurs. The associated high ATP cost is then met by the oxidation of fatty acids.

A ketogenic diet is similar. It consists of high fats, moderate proteins, and very low carbohydrates. In a 2000 kcal per day ketogenic diet, carbohydrates should be 20-50 grams per day.

When there is low carbohydrate availability, gluconeogenesis and ketogenesis come into action. When glucose availability drops further and, the endogenous gluconeogenesis cannot keep up with the needs of the body, ketogenesis begins. Ketone bodies replace glucose as a primary source of energy.

During ketogenesis, due to low blood glucose feedback, insulin secretion is also low, which reduces fat and glucose storage. There is also an increased breakdown of fats that result in fatty acids, which get metabolized to ketone bodies. This metabolic state is referred to as 'nutritional ketosis.' The nutritional ketosis state is considered safe, as ketone bodies are produced in small concentrations without changes in blood pH.

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. His sputum sample showed acid-fast bacilli. What is the appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Start ART and then ATT after 2 weeks
Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
In an HIV patient with TB, start antitubercular therapy (ATT) first and then start antiretroviral therapy (ART) as soon as ATT is tolerated (between 2 weeks and 2 months) by the patient. This is done to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS).

Among persons living with HIV with TB meningitis, ART should be delayed for at least 4 weeks (and initiated within 8 weeks) after treatment for TB meningitis is initiated.

Patients with HIV-related TB may experience a temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ART (IRIS). This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to the simultaneous administration of ART and ATT.

It is characterized by high fever, lymphadenopathy, expanding intra-thoracic lesions, and worsening of chest X-ray findings. Diagnosis should be made only after ruling out treatment failure and other infections. For severe cases, prednisone 1-2 mg/kg is used for 1-2 weeks and then gradually tapered.

Note: CBNAAT is the preferred diagnostic technique for testing TB in PLHIV (people living with HIV). Smear microscopy has poor sensitivity in detecting TB in PLHIV due to fewer organisms in sputum, and hence is not preferred.

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with arachnoiditis, classified as type II on MRI. What is the characteristic finding you are expecting to see?

choices.text: Mass of soft tissue in the spinal canal

questions.solution:
Empty thecal sac sign is seen in type II arachnoiditis.

Arachnoiditis refers to inflammation of the meninges and subarachnoid space. It is characterized by the thickening of the arachnoid membrane and dura mater. The most severe form of arachnoiditis is adhesive arachnoiditis, where scar tissue compresses the nerve roots, disrupting blood supply and flow of cerebrospinal fluid.

Rarely, there may be ossification or dystrophic calcification leading to arachnoiditis ossificans, or ossification of the spinal arachnoid.

The causes of arachnoiditis include:

  • Meningitis
  • Chronic spinal infections like tuberculosis
  • Intrathecal hemorrhage
  • ​Intrathecal drugs - contrast media, anesthetics, steroids 
  • Surgery

MRI is the imaging study of choice for the diagnosis and evaluation of arachnoiditis. Three morphological patterns seen on MRI are:

Type I: nerve roots are clumped together and distorted
Type II: nerve roots are adherent to the theca resulting in an empty thecal sac sign
Type III: nerve roots and theca are clumped or matted together into a single soft tissue mass centrally within the spinal canal

questions.text: While working as a resident in a hospital, you are asked by the consultant to prescribe a certain proton-pump inhibitor (PPI). It should be given only orally once daily before breakfast, even though it has a half-life of no more than 3 hours. What is the rationale behind this once-daily dosing?

choices.text: The drug can inhibit all gastric pumps.
The drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.
The drug is gradually released irrespective of its formulation.
The drug suppresses basal but not stimulated acid production.

questions.solution:
The rationale behind the once-daily dosing is that the drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.

Proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs) are prodrugs that are activated only after undergoing an acid-catalyzed cleavage in the canaliculi of the parietal cells of the stomach.

On administration, they are absorbed in the proximal small bowel and eventually, block the H+/K+ ATPase enzyme, the "proton pump" in the parietal cells of the stomach. The secretion of protons by an activated H+/K+- ATPase (proton pump) in the parietal cells into the gastric lumen is the final step involved in the production of gastric acid and inhibition of this enzyme prevents acid secretion into the stomach.

Once PPIs irreversibly inactivate the H+K+-ATPase pump, acid secretion resumes only after new pump molecules are synthesized and inserted into the luminal membrane. This leads to prolonged suppression of acid secretion for up to 24-48 hours, despite having a shorter plasma half-life of only 30 minutes to 3 hours.

In most individuals, once-daily dosing is enough to achieve effective acid inhibition. If necessary, a second dose can be given before an evening meal.

The number of H+K+-ATPase pump molecules increases after fasting and food decreases the oral bioavailability of the drug. Hence, PPIs are given around 30 minutes before the first meal of the day.

PPIs cannot inhibit all gastric acid pumps with oral dosing because not all pumps are active during the short half-life of the PPI in the blood. 

PPIs cause maximum suppression of gastric acid. They reduce the daily production of both basal and stimulated acid secretion by 85–90%. 

There are available in the form of delayed-release tablets, capsules, and oral suspension packets and for immediate acid suppression, there are intravenous formulations for PPIs like lansoprazole, pantoprazole, and esomeprazole. Therefore, the release of the drug depends upon the drug formulation.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is related to the triangle shown below?
questions.solution:
The image depicts Passaro’s triangle, which is related to gastrinomas. Around 90% of gastrinomas are found within this triangle. 

The three points forming this triangle are the junction of the cystic duct and the common bile duct, the junction of the second and third portion of the duodenum, and the junction of the neck and body of the pancreas.

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES)/Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumor characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. It occurs more commonly in a sporadic pattern but can be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia-1 (MEN-1) syndromes in the familial pattern.

Other options:

Option (A): Insulinomas are insulin-secreting tumors of the pancreas that cause hypoglycemia. They are found either in the pancreas or attached directly to it. They are not found specifically within this kind of anatomical triangle. 

Option (B): Glucagonoma should be suspected when a patient has diabetes associated with dermatitis. Necrolytic migratory erythema is one of the classical skin manifestations seen in these patients. These tumors are found in the body and tail of the pancreas.

Option (D): Vasoactive intestinal peptide tumor (VIPoma) is also called watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA) syndrome. It is a tumor that is most commonly found in the distal pancreas.

Related Pearl: Passaro’s Triangle

Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this triangle.

Its boundaries are as follows:

  • Junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct
  • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum
  • Junction of the body and neck of the pancreas

Related Pearl: Clinical features of gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome)

Most common symptom: Abdominal pain.

Gastrin hypersecretion stimulates gastric acid secretion, leading to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple.

Diarrhea is due to

  • Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa
  • Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach
  • Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH
  • Precipitation of bile salts.

The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text:
You are planning to administer spinal anesthesia to a young female. Which of the following needles would be the least suitable for reducing the risk of a post-dural puncture headache?

G- gauge
questions.solution:
Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is most commonly seen with 22G Quincke needle (22G has a larger diameter than 25G). So it should be avoided in cases with a higher risk of PDPH.

The spinal needles given in the image are-

A- Quincke spinal needle 

B- Whitacre spinal needle

 

Types of spinal needles: 

Cutting needle Non-cutting (Splitting, pencil point, blunt) needle
Cut the dura Split the dura
Hence the higher incidence of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) due to cerebrospinal fluid leak Hence, a lower incidence of PDPH
Technically less challenging as loss of resistance is well appreciated during lumbar puncture Technically more challenging as loss of resistance is not well appreciated
Eg: Quincke-Babcock, Pitkin  Eg: Whitacre, Sprotte

 

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text: A 53-year-old man complains of fatigue, constipation, and weakness in the dorsiflexion of his foot. Laboratory examination reveals anemia, and the peripheral blood smear is shown below. What is the likely cause of his findings?
questions.solution:
The slide shows basophilic stippling (punctate basophilia), seen in chronic lead poisoning (also called plumbism or saturnism). 

The hematological findings that are associated with lead poisoning are anemia, ringed sideroblasts, and basophilic stippling of the RBCs.

Clinical features include:

  • A - Anemia with basophilic stippling
  • B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)
  • C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)
  • D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy
  • E - Encephalopathy (seen in infants- ataxia, vomiting, stupor, convulsions, and even coma)
  • F - Facial pallor (earliest sign)

Other options-

Option A: Minamata disease resulted from the consumption of fish contaminated with methylmercury. Chronic mercury poisoning would not present with anemia with ringed sideroblasts and basophilic stippling.

Option C: Chronic iron toxicity can be seen in conditions like hemochromatosis, thalassemia (increased absorption due to defective hemoglobin synthesis), or because of excessive oral consumption. Iron overload in various organs can present as liver cirrhosis, hypogonadism, skin pigmentation, diabetes, etc. These patients would have increased serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation. Sideroblastic anemia may present with iron toxicity and how certain similarities to this peripheral smear, but the patient would not present with foot drop.

Option D: Arsenic Poisoning is seen in people working in smelting and ore refineries. Toxicity can present with normocytic normochromic anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Patients would not have basophilic stippling on peripheral smear. Foot drop is also not a feature of arsenic toxicity. Peripheral neuropathy in a glove and stocking pattern may be seen.

questions.text: A histologist is studying the structure of lymphoid tissue. The below finding is seen in which of the following lymphoid tissues?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows Hassall's corpuscles; these are seen in the thymus. These are small rounded structures present in the medulla of the thymus. They have a central core of degenerated epithelial cells that stain pink. Around this is a circle of epithelial cells that stain pink with hematoxylin and eosin stains. The function of these corpuscles is not clearly understood.

Histology of thymus

The thymus is a lymphoid tissue that is arranged in the form of lobules. The lobules are separated from each other by connective tissue. 

Each lobule is made up of an outer darker staining cortex and an inner pale-staining medulla. The medulla contains pink rounded masses called Hassell's corpuscles.

Structure of a lymph node

Each lymph node is bean-shaped. The concave part consists of the hilum, through which the blood vessels enter and leave the node. Microscopy shows the following features:

Each lymph node is surrounded by a thin capsule. Below the capsule is the clear space, which is called the subcapsular sinus. 

The lymph node contains the outer cortex and an inner medulla. The cortex consists of densely packed lymphocytes and therefore stains dark. Numerous follicles can be seen in the cortex. Each nodule has a pale-staining germinal center surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. The medulla consists of lymphocytes arranged in the form of anastomosing cords. It appears pale. Numerous blood vessels can be seen in this area.

The image below shows the histology of the lymph node:

Structure of spleen (Option A)

The spleen is the largest lymphoid organ of the body.

Microscopic features of the spleen:

It is surrounded by a thick capsule. This capsule extends into the organ forming trabeculae. The substance of the spleen consists of red pulp and white pulp. In red pulp, the lymphocytes are diffusely distributed and contain numerous sinusoids. In white pulp, the lymphocytes are densely packed and arranged in the form of cords around the arterioles.

When cut transversely, the cords are similar to the nodules in the lymph nodes. They have a pale germinal center surrounded by a ring of densely packed lymphocytes. However, there is an eccentrically placed arteriole within the germinal center.

The image below shows the spleen: WP- white pulp, RP- Red pulp, CR- central arteriole.

Structure of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (Options B and C)

The aggregations are in the form of lymphatic follicles. Germinal centers may be present. Between the nodules, there is diffuse lymphoid tissue, which is called a parafollicular zone. The nodules predominantly consist of B lymphocytes with T lymphocytes in the diffuse areas.

They lie close to the epithelium. They are not surrounded by a capsule and also do not have connective tissue septa. They have a supporting network of reticular fibers. Examples are palatine tonsils, Peyer's patches, and lymphoid nodules in the vermiform appendix.

The image below shows Peyer's patches.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presented to the OPD with frontal bossing, enlarged hands and feet, and a protruding lower jaw as shown in the image.  The physician prescribed pegvisomant for his condition. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this drug?

choices.text: It is a growth hormone receptor antagonist
Liver function tests should be monitored in all patients

questions.solution:
The statement 'it activates JAK-STAT signaling pathway' is incorrect about pegvisomant.

Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist. It is indicated for the treatment of acromegaly which has been described in the clinical scenario given above. Pegvisomant binds to the growth hormone receptor but does not activate JAK-STAT signaling or stimulate IGF-1 secretion.

The drug is administered subcutaneously (a 40-mg loading dose, followed by an administration of 10 mg/day).

Liver function tests should be monitored in all patients because of the risk of elevation of hepatic transaminases. Lipohypertrophy can also occur at injection sites.

Acromegaly is a result of growth hormone secretion by a pituitary adenoma. It can also occur from extra pituitary lesions. Hypersecretion leads to acral bony overgrowth. This manifests as frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement, and prognathism (protruding lower jaw). If this occurs before the fusion of the growth plates at puberty, it leads to gigantism. 

Acromegaly can be treated by transsphenoidal resection. It can also be managed medically by using octreotide, a somatostatin analog, pegvisomant, dopamine agonists, or radiation.

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy received an intravenous opioid for analgesia. A few minutes later, his heart rate decreased from 72/min to 58/min. Which among the following drugs is least likely to be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Meperidine (pethidine) is least likely to be associated with bradycardia.

Intravenous meperidine produces tachycardia as it has a structure similar to atropine. Unlike other opioids, meperidine causes mydriasis due to its anticholinergic effect.

Other options-

Option (A, B, and C): Fentanyl, Sufentanyl, and Alfentanyl are all opioid agonists that produce bradycardia.

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate is being evaluated for severe generalised edema. On examination, his blood pressure is within normal limits. Investigations revealed hypoalbuminemia and hemoglobin of 14 gm/dL. Urine analysis showed foamy urine and protein 4+. What is the most likely cause of this patient's edema?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a 1-day-old baby with generalized edema along with proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia points toward congenital nephrotic syndrome.

Nephrotic syndrome manifesting at birth or within 3 months of life is termed congenital nephrotic syndrome. It may be:

  • Primary - due to inherited disorders caused by mutations in NPHS 1, NPHS 2, WT1, or LAMB2.
  • Secondary - due to in-utero infections like cytomegalovirus infection, toxoplasmosis, syphilis, HIV infection, hepatitis B virus or hepatitis C virus HCV infection, infantile systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), or mercury exposure.

Infants with congenital nephrotic syndrome most commonly present at birth with edema caused by massive proteinuria, and they are typically delivered with an enlarged placenta.

Severe hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and hypogammaglobulinemia occur due to the loss of filtering selectivity at the glomerular filtration barrier. 

The presence of elevated maternal and amniotic α-fetoprotein levels helps in prenatal diagnosis. A diagnosis of congenital nephrotic syndrome is made clinically in newborns or infants who demonstrate severe generalized edema, poor growth, and nutrition along with hypoalbuminemia, increased susceptibility to infections, hypothyroidism (from urinary loss of thyroxin-binding globulin), and increased risk of thrombotic events.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with nephritic syndrome classically present with tea- or cola-coloured urine due to hematuria, edema, hypertension, and oliguria. 

Option C: Neonatal haemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is characterized by a triad of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and impairment of renal function. It usually presents with severe anemia within a few hours after birth and progressively develops acute renal failure.

Option D: Hydrops fetalis can occur due to Rh incompatibility or other various non-immune causes ( infective causes include syphilis, parvovirus B19 infection, and intrauterine TORCH infections). These babies present with severe anemia.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man complained of unsteadiness while walking. The examination is suggestive of cerebellar disease. An MRI revealed cerebellar hemangioblastomas. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have multiple retinal hemangiomas and bilateral renal masses. Based on the histopathological image of the tumor below, what is the likely subtype of renal cell carcinoma in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical features mentioned are consistent with a diagnosis of Von Hippel Lindau's (VHL) disease. The image shows the presence of cells with clear cytoplasm, hence, the most likely subtype of RCC he is suffering from is the clear cell type of RCC.

VHL disease is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and is characterized by a predisposition to a variety of neoplasms, particularly hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum and retina. Hundreds of bilateral renal cysts, often multiple, clear cell carcinomas develop in 40% to 60% of affected persons. Those with VHL syndrome inherit a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p.

The most common lesions associated with VHL disease, are hemangioblastomas and typically occur in the cerebellum, spinal cord, or retina.

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) arises most commonly from the epithelial cells of the proximal convoluted tubule. It is more common in men and is found incidentally in many patients. The common subtypes are clear-cell, papillary, and chromophobe RCC. When confined to the kidney, surgery is the mainstay of treatment. Once the disease metastasized, tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) and mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin) inhibitors can be used. 

Other options-

Option (C): Papillary RCC- It exhibits various degrees of papilla formation with fibrovascular cores. The histopathological section is shown below. 

 

Option (B): Chromophobe RCC-The cells of this type have clear granular cytoplasm with distinct cell membranes. The nuclei are surrounded by halos of the clear cytoplasm. The histopathological section is shown below.

 

Option (D): Collecting duct carcinoma (Bellini duct)- arises from collecting duct cells in the medulla. Several chromosomal losses and deletions have been described, but a distinct pattern has not been identified. Histologically these tumours are characterized by malignant cells forming glands enmeshed within a prominent fibrotic stroma, typically in a medullary location.

The given image shows a pathological examination of collecting duct carcinoma-

questions.text: A young person is brought to the hospital following a snake bite. The attendants have also brought the snake with them for identification. The image of the snake is given below. The poison of the snake is mainly:
questions.solution:
The image shows a banded krait. The poison of this snake is mainly neurotoxic.

The banded krait can be identified by the alternating black and yellow cross-bands along its back and the presence of hexagonal scales. Its tail has a blunt ending with a swelling at the tip. In addition, a black mark can be found on its neck that extends to the eyes.

The initial presentation includes vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, blurred vision, perioral paresthesia, hyperacusis, dizziness, vertigo, and piloerection ('gooseflesh').

Ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia is the first sign of paralysis to set in followed by involvement of the face, tongue, neck muscles, and muscles of deglutition. 

Ultimately, respiratory failure is precipitated either by airway obstruction or paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

The neurotoxic symptoms of the banded krait bite are reversible with the use of antivenoms or anticholinesterase drugs. In some cases the symptoms may even subside spontaneously after a week.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with diphtheria and diphtheria antitoxin is administered to him. After 10 days, he presents with urticarial rashes, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and a palpable spleen. Which of the following statements is not true about the type of hypersensitivity seen in this condition?

choices.text: This is a systemic form of  hypersensitivity
Can be seen following an injection of penicillin
It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction
A single injection can cause a hypersensitivity reaction

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of serum sickness, which is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction. It is a systemic form of type III hypersensitivity.

This appears 7-12 days following a single injection of a high concentration of foreign serum such as the diphtheria antitoxin. The clinical syndrome consists of fever, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, arthritis, glomerulonephritis, endocarditis, vasculitis, urticarial rashes, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.

Serum sickness differs from other types of hypersensitivity reactions in that, a single injection can serve both as the sensitizing dose and the shocking dose. It is more commonly seen following an injection of penicillin or other antibiotics.

In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating the complement system. The inflammatory reaction causes tissue injury.

The pathogenesis of systemic immune complex disease can be divided into three phases:

  • Formation of immune complexes
  • Deposition of immune complexes
  • Inflammation and tissue injury.

Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Serum sickness
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus

questions.text: The pressure in a capillary is 36 mm Hg at the arteriolar end. The interstitial hydrostatic pressure is 0 mm Hg. The colloid osmotic pressure is 25 mm Hg in the capillary and 1 mm Hg in the interstitium. The net force-producing fluid movement across the capillary wall at its arteriolar end is
questions.solution:
The net force-producing fluid movement across the capillary wall is 12 mm Hg out of the capillary.

The net force across the capillary wall can be calculated by

= (Pressure at the arteriolar end- interstitial hydrostatic pressure)- (capillary osmotic pressure-interstitial osmotic pressure)

= (36-0)-(25-1)

= 36-24

=12 mm of Hg

The rate of filtration at any point along a capillary depends on a balance of forces sometimes termed Starling forces.

The two main forces are hydrostatic pressure and osmotic pressure. The hydrostatic pressure gradient is calculated by subtracting the hydrostatic pressure of the interstitial fluid from the hydrostatic pressure in the capillary. The interstitial fluid pressure varies from one organ to another. It is positive in the liver and kidneys and as high as 6 mm Hg in the brain.

The other force is the osmotic pressure across the capillary wall. This component is directed inward. Osmotic pressure gradient is calculated by subtracting the colloid osmotic pressure of the interstitial fluid from the colloid osmotic pressure of plasma. Colloidal osmotic pressure is exerted by the plasma proteins in the capillaries.

questions.text: A young man deliberately ingested a poisonous liquid in an attempt to commit suicide. The bottle from which he ingested the liquid is shown below. Emergency management was done as soon as he was taken to the hospital. When examining the urobag a few hours later, what color will you expect the urine to be?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of carbolic acid/phenol poisoning.  A few hours later, the urine in the urobag will be expected to have a smoky green or olive green color. This urine color change occurs due to the oxidation of the metabolic products of phenol—hydroquinone and pyrocatechol.

Carbolic acid or phenol is an organic acid that is used as a disinfectant and solvent. It has a characteristic phenolic odor. Poisoning by carbolic acid is called carbolism.

On exposure to the skin, carbolic acid coagulates the proteins and causes the formation of an eschar that will come off as slough later. It can damage the nerves and cause tingling and numbness.

On ingestion, a burning sensation may be felt, along with nausea and vomiting. Vomiting puts the patient at risk of aspiration pneumonia. The acid can also cause pulmonary and laryngeal edema, leading to difficulty breathing, and ultimately respiratory failure. Systemic features include headache, dizziness, syncope, and even coma.

Diagnosis of carbolic acid poisoning can be made by adding a few drops of 10% ferric chloride to the patient's urine sample. If the sample turns violet or blue, it indicates the presence of phenolic compounds. The urine sample would also reduce Benedict's and Fehling's solutions.

Treatment involves removing contaminated clothing and washing the skin. If the patient has ingested the poison, cautious gastric lavage with 20% alcohol, glycerol, or vegetable oil should be carried out. MgSO4 or liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach to remove surface phenol and prevent deep penetration. Parenteral saline can also be administered to correct the circulatory depression, dilute the carbolic acid content of the blood, and promote its excretion. Hemodialysis can be carried out if there is renal failure.

Post mortem, the viscera should be preserved in a saturated salt solution. The skin has a reddish appearance with necrosis or ulceration. The body has a characteristic phenolic odor. The esophagus may look reddish and like parchment. The internal surface of the stomach may show prominent rugae with a leathery appearance, due to the opaque, coagulated, grey, or brown mucosa.

Other options-

Option (B): Pale yellow is the color of normal urine, so this is not the correct answer.

Option (C & D): Orange-red color of urine can be seen in patients on rifampicin therapy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with complaints of redness of his eye which started 3 days ago. He has no pain, no discharge, and no complaints about his vision. There was no history of trauma. His blood pressure is 126/84 mmHg. He is not on any anticoagulants. The eye appears as shown in the image below. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows a subconjunctival hemorrhage in the eye. Blood gets absorbed gradually in 1-3 weeks' time without treatment. Hence, reassurance to the patient is the most appropriate management.

A subconjunctival hemorrhage is also called subconjunctival ecchymosis. It is due to the rupture of small blood vessels and can occur spontaneously in elders with fragile vessels, those with systolic hypertension, or after local trauma. The condition is usually associated with a benign course.

It appears as a flat sheet of homogeneous bright red color with well-defined limits. The vision is usually unaffected. Recurrent episodes warrant investigations for a bleeding diathesis or leukemia. 

Spontaneous resolution is typical. The use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.

Other options:

Option A: CT scan of the head would be appropriate if the patient gives a history of trauma, which raises a suspicion of skull/orbit fracture.

Option B: Anti-hypertensive therapy would be given if the patient has high blood pressure. 

Option D: INR levels will be checked if the patient is on any anticoagulant medication or if there are recurrent episodes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presents with complaints of right flank pain for the past 2 months. His blood counts, urinalysis and renal function tests were normal. Abdominal ultrasound showed right hydronephrosis. A retrograde ureteropyelogram showed a right-sided fish-hook ureter with hydronephrosis. Which of the following embryological abnormality is responsible for his condition?

choices.text: Incomplete fusion of the urethral folds
Failure of  fusion of the paramesonephric duct
Two ureteric buds arising from mesonephric duct
Persistence of the posterior cardinal vein

questions.solution:
The clinical features and a right-sided fish hook ureter are suggestive of the retrocaval ureter, and it is due to the persistence of the posterior cardinal vein.

The circumcaval ureter, or retrocaval ureter, is a developmental anomaly of the inferior vena cava (IVC). This congenital abnormality occurs due to the persistence of the posterior cardinal vein, and the ureter passes posterior to the inferior vena cava. The anomaly always appears on the right side, as this is the side of the normal IVC.

This condition occurs in 1 in 1500 individuals. Most commonly, it does not produce any clinical manifestations, but rarely, it can cause upper ureteric obstruction. Even though it is a congenital anomaly, the clinical manifestations are not seen until 3rd and 4th decades of life. The clinical manifestations are a result of right-sided hydronephrosis, which can be due to kinking of the ureter, an adynamic ureteric segment, or compression of the ureter against the psoas muscle.

The classical appearance of the retrocaval ureter is termed a fish-hook ureter. As the right ureter hooks behind the IVC, it has also been referred to as an S-shaped ureter.

Other options:

Option A: Incomplete fusion of the urethral folds leads to hypospadias, a condition in which abnormal openings of the urethra occur along the ventral aspect of the penis.

Option B: Failure of fusion of the paramesonephric duct produces duplication of the uterus(e.g., Uterus didelphys, bicornuate uterus, etc.)

Option C: Two ureteric buds arising from the mesonephric duct lead to duplex ureters.

questions.text: A lady was found to have the feature seen in image A, which is characteristic of a certain disease. On further investigations, she was found to have the immunofluorescence pattern seen in image B. Positivity of which of the following antibodies would predict a high risk of interstitial lung disease in her?
questions.solution:
Image A showing classical prominent perioral radial furrowing and microstomia and image B showing nucleolar pattern are suggestive of systemic sclerosis. Anti-Scl-70 positivity in this disease is useful in predicting those at high risk for interstitial lung disease.

Scleroderma or systemic sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features is seen in scleroderma. Initially, the fingers may be puffy and have nonpitting edema. The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly. Severe pruritus, vasospasm, and digital ulceration may be present. 

Mask-like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia (fish mouth appearance), perioral furrowing, and beak‐like nose.

Around 90% of patients suffering from scleroderma have dysphagia and gastroesophageal reflux at the level of the esophagus. The intense sclerosis of organs and primarily the fibrosis of the skin has devastating effects on the affected patients.

The nucleolar pattern (some spots of fluorescence within the nucleus, representing antibodies against RNA) is most often seen in systemic sclerosis. 

Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) and anti-RNA polymerase III are seen in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis, which can have pulmonary manifestation as interstitial lung disease.

Other options:

Option A - Anti-U3-RNP (anti-fibrillarin) autoantibodies are associated with patients of Afro-Caribbean origin and can identify patients with SSc who are younger at disease onset and display a higher prevalence of myositis.

Option B - Anti-centromere antibody is most specific for CREST syndrome.
 
Option D - Anti-U1-RNP is seen in mixed connective tissue disease.

Related Pearl: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.
