questions.text: Which among the following statements is incorrect regarding the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway?

choices.text: Ubiquitin binds to the protein by non–α-peptide bonds
Defect in this pathway leads to Angelman syndrome

questions.solution:
Ubiquitin mainly targets extracellular proteins is an incorrect statement. It mainly targets intracellular proteins for degradations.

The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway is the pathway to degrade regulatory proteins with short half-lives, and abnormal or misfolded proteins present in the cytoplasm. This pathway requires ATP. Ubiquitin is a polypeptide present in all eukaryotic cells. It mainly targets the intracellular proteins. On identifying the target protein, it binds to it with the non–α-peptide bonds. The target protein may be bound by a single ubiquitin or multiple ubiquitin molecules. The tagged proteins are then degraded by proteasome.

Genetic disorders that result from the defect in the ubiquitin proteasome pathway include Angelman syndrome, autosomal recessive juvenile Parkinson disease, von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, and congenital polycythemia. 

For the discovery of ubiquitin-mediated protein degradation, Aaron Ciechanover and Avram Hershko of Israel and Irwin Rose of the United States were awarded the 2004 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the casualty by his friends after the consumption of the recreational drug- magic mushrooms. On examination, he is delirious and has visual and auditory hallucinations. Blood and urine samples are sent for toxicological analysis which shows the presence of d-lysergic acid. Which among the following did the boy consume?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing hallucinations and the presence of d-lysergic acid is suggestive of the consumption of Psilocybe species of mushrooms/fungi which exhibits mycetism.

Mycotic poisoning is of two types: Mycetism and Mycotoxicosis

Mycetism:

The fungus when eaten, itself causes toxic effects. The hallucinogenic agents (d-lysergic acid and psilocybin) produced by Psilocybe species have attracted attention as recreational drugs in recent years. 

Other fungi which that show mycotic poisoning in the form of mycetism include:

  • Claviceps → Ergot poisoning
  • Coprine → coprine poisoning
  • Inocybe → muscarine poisoning

Mycotoxicosis:

Fungal toxins contaminate food and cause toxic effects.

Examples:

  • Aflatoxins: These are a type of mycotoxins produced by Aspergillus species of fungi, such as A. flavus (secretes B1) and A. parasiticus (secretes B1, B2, G1 and G2)
  • Fusarium toxins

questions.text: A 17-month-old girl presented with abnormal vaginal bleeding. A gynecological examination showed abnormal vaginal tissue protruding through the introitus. Histopathological analysis showed sheets of spindled cells in a myxoid stroma, which stained positive for desmin and Myo-D1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sarcoma botryoids, which is a variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. It is a malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation. 

Rhabdomyosarcomas are the common soft tissue sarcomas of childhood and adolescence, classified into four subtypes: alveolar, embryonal, pleomorphic, and spindle-shaped/ sclerosing.

  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma: It contains sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma. Sarcoma botryoids is a variant that occurs in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile duct, bladder, and vagina.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma: consists of the network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters or aggregates, creating a crude resemblance to pulmonary alveoli. 
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma - consists of large, sometimes multinucleated, bizarre eosinophilic tumor cells.
  • Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma - Consists of fusiform cells with vesicular chromatin arranged in long fascicles or in a storiform pattern.

On immunohistochemistry, they are positive for desmin, myoglobin, myogenin, MyoD1, and vimentin. Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults.

The botryoid variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma has the best prognosis, while the pleomorphic subtype is often fatal.

questions.text: 400 mg of a drug was administered to a patient, of which 40 mg is excreted in 60 minutes. Assuming the drug follows first-order kinetics, how much of the drug would remain after 2 hours?
questions.solution:
After 2 hours, 324mg of the drug will remain.

In first-order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. 

In the given question, 40 mg out of 400 mg is excreted in 60 minutes ---> 40/400 = 0.1 fraction is eliminated every 60 minutes.

After 60 minutes; 400 mg - 40 mg = 360 mg remains 

The next 60 minutes (after 2 hours) = 360 * 0.1 = 36 mg is eliminated and 360 - 36 = 324 mg remains.

Simpler way -

  • 1/10 fraction is excreted in 60 minutes → 9/10 remains after 60 minutes.
  • 2 hours (120 min) is 2 times of 60 minutes.
  • So 400 * (9/10)(9/10) = 324 mg remains after 120 minutes.

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text:
The synthesis of melanin occurs in melanosomes from a precursor amino acid. Which of the following are not derived from the same amino acid?

DOPA- dihydroxyphenylalanine, GABA- Gamma-aminobutyric acid
questions.solution:
The precursor amino acid involved in the synthesis of melanin is tyrosine. GABA is not derived from tyrosine. Glutamate is the precursor of GABA (γ-aminobutyric acid). Tyrosine is a precursor of thyroxin, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).

  • Formation of DOPA: Tyrosine is hydroxylated by tyrosinase to form dihydroxy phenylalanine or DOPA. Tyrosinase is a monooxygenase that contains copper.
  • Formation of melanin: Tyrosinase acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which is then converted to indolequinone. The indolequinone is polymerized to form melanin.
  • Formation of catecholamines: Epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. They are produced by the adrenal medulla and sympathetic ganglia.
    • Tyrosine is first hydroxylated to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) by tyrosine hydroxylase.
    • DOPA is decarboxylated by DOPA decarboxylase to form dopamine.
    • Dopamine is further hydroxylated to norepinephrine or noradrenaline
    • Norepinephrine is then methylated by the enzyme N-methyl transferase (NMT) to form epinephrine or adrenaline. S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) is the methyl donor.

The series of reactions involving the production of catecholamines is shown in the image below.

  • Formation of thyroid hormones: Tyrosine residues are iodinated to form 3-mono-iodo-tyrosine (MIT) and 3,5-di-iodo-tyrosine (DIT). These are coupled to give rise to triiodothyronine (T3) and tetraiodothyronine (thyroxine or T4)

Note- GABA is an inhibitory neurotransmitter. It is formed by the decarboxylation of glutamate by l-glutamate decarboxylase.

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient had a sudden tearing type of chest pain. He is a known hypertensive patient for the past 15 years and has not been on regular treatment. Acute coronary syndrome was ruled and he is hemodynamically stable. Considering aortic dissection, which is the next investigation to be performed?
questions.solution:
CT is the initial investigation for aortic dissection. As it is more widely available and takes a shorter time compared to MRI.

MRI, though highly accurate for acute aortic disease evaluation, is usually confined to cases of severe renal insufficiency or absolute contraindications to iodinated contrast medium.

Ultrasound and aortography are not the investigation of choice for aortic dissection. Aortography used to be the gold standard. It involved the injection of high-flow contrast into the vessel. It has been replaced by noninvasive imaging. Intravascular ultrasound can be performed, but the procedure is expensive and requires experience.

The below image depicts a CT chest indicating Type A aortic dissection from the aortic root. (A) Axial view and (B) sagittal view. Arrows indicate intimal flap.

The Stanford classification of aortic dissection is based on whether the ascending aorta is involved:

  • Type A: affects ascending aorta and arch:
    • Requires urgent surgical management
  • Type B: begins beyond brachiocephalic vessels:
    • Dissection commences distal to the left subclavian artery
    • Medical management with blood pressure control

The DeBakey classification divides dissections into:

  • Type I: involves ascending and descending aorta (= Stanford A)
  • Type II: involves ascending aorta only (= Stanford A)
  • Type III: involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavian artery (= Stanford B)

questions.text:
Match the following influenza viruses with their corresponding pandemics.
Influenza strain and period Pandemic
1. (H1N1) virus, 1918-1919 A. Hong Kong flu
2. (H2N2) virus, 1957-1958 B. Swine flu
3. (H3N2) virus, 1968 C. Asian flu
4. (H1N1) virus, 2009-2010 D. Spanish flu
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

Influenza strain and period Pandemic
1. Influenza A(H1N1) virus, 1918-1919 D. Spanish flu
2. Influenza A(H2N2) virus, 1957-1958 C. Asian flu
3. Influenza A(H3N2) virus, 1968 A. Hong Kong flu
4. Influenza A(H1N1) virus, 2009-2010 B. Swine flu

Endemics :

The constant recurrence of a disease or infectious agent within a particular specified geographical region or population group is known as an endemic disease. An endemic disease might burst into a pandemic, given the right conditions. 

Epidemics :

The occurrence of an illness or a health-related event in a community or region in excess of normal expectancy is known as an epidemic. The community or region and the period in which the cases occur must be specified precisely.

Pandemics :

A pandemic is an epidemic occurring over a very wide area, crossing international boundaries, and usually affecting a large number of people. Examples: Influenza pandemics and cholera pandemics.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about bevacizumab:

choices.text: Has a half life of 11-50 days
Used with FOLFOX regimen in metastatic colon cancer
Should be stopped atleast 4 weeks before elective surgery

questions.solution:
Option B is the false statement about bevacizumab. 

Bevacizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against vascular endothelial growth factor A (VEGF-A). It blocks the interaction between VEGF-A and the VEGF receptors (VEGFR), on the surface of endothelial cells.

The binding of VEGF-A to VEGFR-1 and VEGFR-2 leads to endothelial cell proliferation and the formation of new blood vessels/ angiogenesis. Therefore, the administration of bevacizumab inhibits microvascular growth and angiogenesis and is used for this purpose in the setting of cancer treatment to inhibit malignant cell growth and blood vessel formation.

It is given as an intravenous infusion and has a half-life of around 11-50 days.

It is used as a part of the FOLFOX regimen for metastatic colon cancer to increase patient survival. It is also used for the management of cervical or ovarian cancer, glioblastoma, and wet macular degeneration.

Due to the long half-life, there needs to be a gap of at least 4 weeks before and after elective surgery. This is because patients on bevacizumab have a higher rate of wound-healing complications.

Other adverse effects include hypertension, an increased incidence of arterial thromboembolic events, gastrointestinal perforations, and proteinuria.

questions.text: A nutritionist is studying the blood levels of various lipoproteins. One of the samples shows elevation of LDL and total cholesterol levels. Which of the following might be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Type 2 hyperlipoproteinemia shows increased levels of LDL and total cholesterol.

Type 2 hyperlipoproteinemia or familial hypercholesterolemia occurs due to a defect in LDL receptors. It is an autosomal dominant condition. Defective LDL receptors cause a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and total cholesterol rise. Clinical features include the presence of tendon xanthomas, atherosclerosis, and coronary heart disease.

LDL receptors (apo B100 and apo E) are expressed on multiple types of cells. They are expressed when the cell needs cholesterol for metabolic needs. LDL molecule binds to this receptor and is endocytosed. 

It is a tightly regulated step and involves PCSK9. Therapy targeting PCSK9 has been developed to control the blood levels of LDL.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: All of the following are indications for tonsillectomy except:
questions.solution:
All of the above are indications for tonsillectomy except during an episode of acute tonsillitis. This is because the incidence of bleeding is more in acute infection.

The absolute indications for tonsillectomy are:

  • Recurrent infections of the throat, defined as:
    • Seven or more episodes in 1 year or
    • Five episodes per year for 2 years or
    • Three episodes per year for 3 years or
    • Two weeks or more of lost school or work in 1 year.
  • Peritonsillar abscess
  • Tonsillitis causing febrile seizures
  • Hypertrophy of tonsils causing airway obstruction, difficulty in swallowing or phonation
  • Suspected malignancy

The relative indications are:

  • Diphtheria carriers who have not responded to antibiotics
  • Streptococcal carriers who may be a source of infection for others
  • Chronic tonsillitis with halitosis unresponsive to medical treatment
  • Patient with valvular heart disease having recurrent streptococcal tonsillitis

It is also indicated as a part of other procedures like palato- pharyngoplasty, glossopharyngeal neurectomy, removal of the styloid process.

Contraindications:

  • Hemoglobin level less than 10g%
  • Presence of acute infection like acute tonsillitis due to increased incidence of bleeding during infection
  • Children under 3 years of age due to poor surgical risk
  • Cleft palate
  • Bleeding disorders
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease (diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension, asthma
  • During menses

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is being administered morphine for pain control. However, he develops constipation subsequently. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage his constipation?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient develops constipation following administration of opioids and the most suitable drug for the management of constipation is naloxegol as it is a peripherally acting opioid antagonist.

Naloxegol is an opioid receptor antagonist. It is similar structurally to naltrexone but does not cross the blood-brain barrier. As a result, naloxegol reverses the peripheral effects of opiates like constipation by increasing spontaneous bowel movement frequency. It does not interfere with the central nervous system effects of opiates, such as pain relief.

Its side effects include abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, flatulence, anxiety, restlessness, and sweating. Withdrawal symptoms can occur upon discontinuation of the drug. In patients not on opioid therapy, naloxegol has minimal effects on constipation. It. can also give rise to hypersensitivity reactions and gastrointestinal perforation.

Other peripherally acting opioid antagonists include:

  • Methylnaltrexone
  • Naldemedine
  • Alvimopan

Other options:

Options A and D: Naltrexone and naloxone are opioid receptor antagonists that are used in the management of morphine poisoning. They act centrally.

Option C: Loperamide is an opioid receptor agonist. It decreases bowel motility and intestinal secretions. Fecal continence is improved by enhancement of anal sphincter tone.
